story:
I have been working for 4 weeks now with a very talented group of dancers in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

We've been making great progress and I'm thrilled to see the concepts I've had in my head for years being brought to life. Since childhood I have struggled to comprehend the tragedies and atrocities of the Holocaust. This project tackles the subject in various ways. I have divided the project into six "letters" or scenes: In the Shadow, Papieren, Questioning, Bloodlines, Defiance and Garden Gate.

I am originally from the San Francisco Bay Area where I was raised with my sister and brother by my German mother and American father. I first learned about the Holocaust at the age of eight when my grandmother died. I didn't understand why I had never met my grandmother. How could my mother explain easily the circumstances that had destroyed her family, the imprisonment that had made my grandmother too weak to travel?

I retired from teaching dance for the University of Minnesota, Morris in 2009. After 25 years of working with college students, it is wonderful for me to finally have a chance to work with professional dancers. I have received some funding from the University of Minnesota Retirees Association which will pay the dancers but we need more money to cover all the expenses of our film crew, equipment rental and lighting technicians. When completed, this film will be entered in dance film festivals and made available as a way to teach about this period of history.

By contributing to this campaign you will help in the creation of a powerful exploration of loss of innocence, anti-semitism, hatred, grief, fear, hope and defiance. Everyone comes to grips with the reality of the Jewish Holocaust in different ways. This is my way.

If you think this is a worthy project, please help us spread the word.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
SHORT SUMMARY

Hello! It’s Impulse Theatre here. We are a Victoria-based multidisciplinary theatre company specializing in transformative physical performance. We started on a rock in James Bay with our first piece, Conversations with the Sea, in 2010. Since then, we’ve created fifteen original works and facilitated the growth of dozens of local artists and administrators through projects like our annual Peek Fest. 

This year, we’re supported by a summer team of administrators and artists who are working tirelessly on a brand-new show to add to Impulse’s catalogue, how to pull your heart out through your throat. 

how to pull your heart out through your throat dives into questions of identity, self, and the fabricated “me” we present through social media. With the (very loose) format of an exciting and visceral “how-to” guide, how to pull your heart out through your throat explores questions of individuality, self-creation, and the need to be seen authentically. 

This show is a collaborative creation led by Impulse’s Artistic Producer Andrew Barrett. The cast and creative team include local early-career theatre practitioners  Emma Dickerson, Veronica Harland, Chase Hiebert, Rachel Levy, and Julie Mombourquette.

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU GET

This Indiegogo will help us cover the Production Expenses associated with how to pull your heart out through your throat. This means we need money to support: lighting design, set design and construction, props, and costumes. 

Impulse Theatre is fortunate enough to have received funding through the Canada Summer Jobs Program, allowing us to cover most of our administrative costs and pay the performing artists involved in this show (above minimum wage!). Everything we raise goes directly towards production costs that come with the creation of new performance!

Of course, it wouldn’t be an Indiegogo campaign without some exciting perks! We’ve got tonnes of ways for you to get to know the Impulse team and get involved in our office life and creative process. So let us make you a playlist or have a live dance party with us via Instagram--we can’t wait!

 

EXPENSES 

Designer Fees: $650
Administrative and Artist Fees: $6,750
Production/Technical Fees (set, props, and costuming)—$1000
Fringe Application Fee: $620
Marketing Expenses: $350
Indiegogo Fees: $30 

TOTAL EXPENSES   $9,400

 

REVENUES

Box Office: $1150
Canada Summer Jobs Funding: $6,750 
Indiegogo: $1500

TOTAL REVENUE  $9,400

 

Even if we don’t make our fundraising goal, all of the money we receive will go towards the production expenses of how to pull your heart out through your throat. Every bit helps offset these expenses!

We recognize that not everyone who gives to this campaign will be able to see the show in person, so we’ve created some exciting perks that will let you be a part of the magic! At some levels, you can purchase a ticket that will be reserved as part of our accessibility program--so someone who might not otherwise be able to see the show will have a chance to do so! AND, for every donation over $100, we’ll donate 15% of what you give to the Victoria Youth Clinic, one of our favourite Not-For-Profit organizations in the city. They provide medical services to youth between 12-24 years of age, with an emphasis on helping at-risk youth. 

 

IMPACT

Impulse Theatre is a leader in Victoria when it comes to employing emerging artists and providing them with an opportunity to produce and create new work. Without providing artists with these opportunities at home, Victoria risks losing them to other major centres where there’s a greater concentration of work. Your donation helps us encourage and develop the creative ecology in this city, giving the next generation of artists and administrators the option of staying in Victoria while furthering their careers. This will only benefit the city, as artists continue to create work that is responsive to the social issues affecting our region.

This particular show will ask audiences to engage with the concept of their online and offline self and the ways we present our personal “brand” through social media. It will raise questions of authenticity in our behaviour, online and in real life. We hope that audiences will come away questioning their interactions with other people, looking more deeply at themselves and the ways in which we communicate.

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

Thankfully, our summer team is supported by the Canada Summer Jobs program, but we’re also looking to craft an exciting and thrilling show that is supported by the strong visual and aesthetic elements that Impulse is known for. Without sufficient funds, the artistic vision of the piece will not come to fruition. 

Impulse works to keep its prices low and, therefore, accessible year-round. If you think that offering multidisciplinary theatre arts created locally with locally trained artists, please consider donating today. Impulse is an emerging leader and your generosity allows us to establish a foundation in the city. We certainly have our challenges, but we are confident in our work and determined to bring you something new, relevant, and diverse.

story:
Who are we?

The Void Theatre Company is a theatre making group founded in 2018 by three young Romanian actors. We are driven by big dreams, honesty and passion for art and a lot of determination. We create work through collaboration, experimentation and play.

Old Clown Wanted is our second production and it is created in collaboration with Ementior Dance Company. This is a performance based on a script by Matei Visniec and it is a brave project that combines the Arts of Theatre, Dance, Physical Theatre and Circus. All the members of the team are currently students of the Academy of Music and Theatre Arts from Falmouth University.

Theatre is a great asker of questions, rather than a way or delivering answers and we care about the world and the people who live in it. Therefore, our work is dedicated to everyone who wants to try new theatrical experiences. Constantly working in gender, age, nationality mixed groups, The Void Theatre Company tries to explore diversity and the multi-cultural environment of our current world.

The invite to the Sibiu International Theatre Festival is an honour, but it is also a great challenge for us as an emerging Theatre Company. Every bit of support is important to us because we want to promote Cornwall, Falmouth University, as well as values we deem as important such as diversity, multi-culturalism and communication in a centre that gathers the most important artists and makers from the Theatre, Dance and Performance world.

What do we need?

The Sibiu International Theatre Festival is covering our stay in Romania, and provide us with the fully equipped venue to perform in. However, we must pay for our own transport to Romania and back. The budget that we have set is exactly what we need for the travel and it splits as follows:

Old Clown Wanted Team

We are a team of passionate, creative and young students and we are:

Director: Eusebiu-Mihail Tudoroiu
Choreography created by Ementior Dance Company

CAST

Filippo – Robert Bogdanov-Schein
Nicollo – Eusebiu-Mihail Tudoroiu
Peppino – Jack Arthur

Circus performers:

Andrea Rios Ruiz
Andrea (Andy) Isaksen
Ben Mandeville
Brandon Holloway
Carla Montero
Jaz Rifat
Laura Cutlan
Nathan Tabberer
Teodor Tincu

Costume design: Cosmin Stancu
Make-up design: Andrea (Andy) Isaksen & Jaz Rifat

Light design: Ethan Kent
Sound design: Ryan Lillie
Stage manager: Elenie Hajibey & Ned Siuipys

Photography: Melissa Ivana & Katie O'Neill

Producers: Robert Bogdanov-Schein and Eusebiu-Mihail Tudoroiu

Graphic design: Melissa Ivana

Special thanks to The Academy of Music and Theatre Arts of Falmouth University

More information

Please find more information about the Sibiu International Theatre Festival at: http://www.sibfest.ro/sibiu-international-theat...

The Void Theatre Company social media:
https://www.facebook.com/TheVoidTheatreCompany
https://www.instagram.com/thevoidtheatrecompany/
https://twitter.com/TheVoidTheatre

Ementior Dance Company social media:
https://www.instagram.com/ementiordance/

story:
"This is definitely not proper grieving behavior."

In the aftermath of 25-year-old Connor’s suicide, his girlfriend, sister, and roommate try desperately to make things right, place blame, and confront their own battles with mental illness. Wickedly funny and shockingly tender, Coping explores and explodes our experience of grief, mental illness, and family.

CAST

Rebecca Ballinger (Sarah), Madelyn Farris (Stage Manager), Michelle Hill (Janie), Melissa Hmelnicky (Jessica), Maggie Robertson (Taylor), and Daniel Rovin (Lucas).

CREATIVE TEAM

Jacob Marx Rice (Playwright), Joshua W. Kelley (Director), Green Spark Productions (Producer), Patrick Landes (PSM), Audrey Bodek (Scenic Design), Jordana Abrenica (Sound Design), and Daniel Mori (Lights and Costume Design), Sarah Weitzman (Graphic Design).

We've put together an incredible team to work on this project and are so excited about bringing this play to DC audiences, but...

We need your help!

Every penny donated will go towards this production. Our costs includes Fringe fees, cast and creative team expenses, insurance, costumes, set, lights, and marketing. All essential elements to make this production a success. 

Here's a breakdown of our budget:

By donating, you'll become a part of this exciting process. You will also receive the perks outlined to the right and our deepest thanks and gratitude. 

All donations are tax-deductible for the full amount except for the perks with other amounts noted.

Risks & Challenges

Producing fringe theatre is challenging and about being scrappy with the resources we have. We have created a very cost-effective production, but there are some costs we simply can't avoid. We think this play is important enough to lose all of our money over, but we would love to break even with your help.

Other Ways You Can Help

We recognize that not everyone is in a position to donate. You can also help us out by spreading the word! Please share our Indiegogo with your friends and like our Facebook page. Most importantly, please support us by coming to see Coping, July 8th-23rd at the Mead Theatre Lab - Flashpoint in DC. 

Website - Facebook - Tickets



COPING is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of COPING must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
UPDATE: WE DID IT! Many many many tack, you are simply amazing! Love: The Team. 

 

When was the last time you had sex on top of a mountain?

//Wann hast du das letze Mal auf der Spitze eines Berges Sex gehabt? 

- an interactive staged reading 

at GOTHENBURG FRINGE FESTIVAL 2017 | 1th 2nd 3rd of September

 

Three women. A three-headed creature from and between Hungary and Germany. Three theatre-makers. Three points of view. We. We read out loud. We sing sometimes. Wir stellen Fragen. In 14 different languages. About crucial moments. Über Politik. About destiny. About responsibility. About personal issues and priorities. Är det intressant, what we say? Do you understand me? Ymmärrätkö mitä sanon? És ha nem, akkor mi van? 

Does everything have to be understood? When did you ask yourself the last time? When was the last time you had sex on top of a mountain? Do we confront each other with personal questions? Do we react? Does one of us wear a mermaid costume? Do we interact? Do we open? – Yes. We do. Här och nu. 

from and by Adrienn Bazsó, Charlotte Mednansky, Panni Néder

mermaid costume: Rózsa Sebő

subtitling: Zsófi Lili Kovács

text & direction: Panni Néder

trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wMnaLZ8q594 

festival page: https://www.gothenburgfringefestival.com/sexontopofamountain 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

-----------scroll down/görgess le für deutsche Version & magyar szöveg --------------

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 ENGLISH SUMMARY: 

The autobiographical production begins with a Hungarian director in Berlin, facing a dilemma: she has been asked to set up a production and she is scared. Her own diversity as a native of Hungary and Berliner by choice prompts some questions: 

What can, should, must one tell a foreign audience? Is what she has to say even interesting? Will they understand her? 

These questions lead to solutions to the initial conflict. Three performers, including herself, speak for the director's ideas, bounce back and forth in time and space, pick up burning political, social and personal topics and revisit the initial conflict again and again.

The performance is the work of three independent theatre makers with no financial support. Since its debut, "When was the last time you had sex on top of a mountain?" has been shown in Berlin and Geneva and it is invited to this year's Gothenburg FRINGE Festival. We are delighted.

In order to be able to produce our guest performance, we need your support. Our travel expenses are paid-for by the Goethe-Institut, but we need to cover the festival fee, rehearsal and material costs, local travel expenses and meals. 

If our labor of love resonates with you, then support us with a small (or large) amount. And you love our perks, don't you? 

We would be very grateful for every donation. Thank you, merci, köszönöm, tack! 

Kind regards, 

The Team.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

 AUF DEUTSCH: Ausgangspunkt der Inszenierung ist eine in Berlin lebende ungarische Regisseurin, die sich gerade in Produktionszwang befindet: sie muss inszenieren und hat davor Angst. Ihre eigene Diversität als gebürtige Ungarin und Wahlberlinerin konkretisiert sich in Fragen:

Was kann/soll/muss man einem fremden Publikum erzählen? Ist es doch interessant was sie sagen will? Wird man sie verstehen?

Entlang diesen Fragestellungen wird die Ausgangssituation aufgelöst: drei Performerinnen (einschließlich sich selbst), die die Gedankengänge der Regisseurin repräsentieren, hüpfen zwischen Zeiten und Orten, greifen brennende politische, gesellschaftliche

und persönliche Themen auf und kehren immer wieder zur Ausgangssituation zurück.

Die szenische Lesung wurde ohne finanzielle Unterstützung von drei unabhängigen Theatermacherinnen kreiert. Seit ihrer Premiere war "Wann hast du das letzte Mal auf der Spitze eines Berges Sex gehabt?" in Berlin zu sehen, sie tourte in Genf und jetzt wurde sie auf das Göteborg FRINGE Festival eingeladen. Wir sind hocherfreut.

Um unsere Gastspieleinladung realisieren zu können, brauchen wir Eure Unterstützung: unsere Fahrtkosten übernimmt das Goethe-Institut, aber wir müssen die Festivalgebühr, Probe- und Materialkosten, Fahrtkosten vor Ort und Verpflegungskosten abdecken.

Wenn ihr unser HerzStück mögt und denkt, dass das ein Kribbeln (oder Schmetterlinge) im Bauch hinterlässt, dann unterstützt uns mit einer kleinen (oder großen) Summe. Und unsere Geschenke (perks) sind hervorragend, nicht wahr?

Wir freuen uns über jeden Beitrag. Thank you, merci, köszönöm, tack!

Liebe Grüße,

Das Team.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

MAGYARUL: Az önéletrajzi előadás kiindulópontja egy Berlinben élő fiatal magyar rendezőnő, aki épp kihívással szembesül: rendeznie kell. És fél tőle. Magyar és berlini identitásai konfliktusba kerülnek egymással, majd különböző kérdésekben öltenek testet:

Mit kell/lehet/tud ő egy külföldi közönségnek prezentálni? Érdekes, amit mondani akar? És egyáltalán érthető?

A kérdések önálló életre kelnek, majd burjánzanak tovább. Az alaphelyzet hamar szertefoszlik: a rendezőnőt képviselő három előadó (köztük ő maga is) különböző helyek, idősíkok, égető politikai-társadalmi és személyes témakörök között ugrál, majd vissza-visszatér a kiindulóponthoz.

A "Mikor szeretkeztél utoljára egy hegy tetején?" c. előadás anyagi támogatás nélkül, három független színházi alkotó önerejéből jött létre. A berlini bemutató óta megjártuk Genfet, most pedig meghívást kaptunk a Göteborgi FRINGE Fesztiválra. És elképesztően boldogok vagyunk.

A vendégjáték megvalósításához viszont szükségünk van a támogatásotokra: az utazási költségeinket a Goethe Intézet finanszírozza, az egyéb fennálló összeget viszont mindenképpen össze kell gyűjtenünk, hogy felléphessünk Svédországban. Amire kalapozunk: a fesztivál illetéki díja, próba- és anyagköltség, utazási költség a városon belül, ellátás.

Ha tetszik a szívügyünk, és netalántán pillangók röpködnek tőle a gyomrotokban, támogassatok minket egy kisebb (vagy nagyobb) összeggel. A cserébe adott ajándékaink pedig kitűnőek, nem igaz?

Minden hozzájárulással nagy örömöt szereztek nekünk. Danke, merci, köszönjük, tack!

Sok szeretettel:

A csapat.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

THE CREATORS

ADRIENN BAZSÓ studied acting in Budapest and played in various theatres in Hungary. In 2012 she moved to Berlin and took her master's degree "theatre education" at the University of the Arts (UdK) in 2015. Since graduation, she is working as a freelance actress for the Grips Theater. She is the director of the youth club at the Staatsoper in the Schiller Theater in Berlin. "Moon calling", her first production with the Youth Choir of the Staatsoper Berlin, was staged in Schiller Theater in May 2015. Her second production, the self-developed musical theatrical piece "Drahtseilakt" was premiered in June 2016.

In addition, she plays in off-theater productions (among others in the LOFFT, Deutsches Theater, HAU and Sophiensaele), in which she deals with relevant social and social themes and experiments with the limits of the theater.

Webpage: www.adriennbazso.com

CHARLOTTE MEDNANSKY studied acting from 2011 to 2015 at the University of the Arts in Berlin. She studied at the Hansotto Theater Potsdam and the Deutsches Theater in Berlin and played in "Death and Resurrection of the World of My Parents in Me" (directed by Hermann Schmidt-Theater) at the UNIT Theater of the University of the Arts. For this production she received the ensemble prize of the Acting Schools Meeting 2014 in Munich together with her year. In addition, she appeared in some short films as well as in the films »Vision - From the Life of Hildegard von Bingen« and »The House of her Father«.

She is engaged in tjg. Theater youth generation Dresden since May 2015.

PANNI NÉDER is a Berlin and Budapest-based Hungarian stage director, educated at the University of Theatre and Film Arts Budapest and at the HfS “Ernst Busch” University in Berlin. She has worked both for established repertoire houses and independent companies in her home town while she began to spend more and more time Berlin. In the last few years, she has devised and directed there several independent performances.

She is passionate about autobiographical theatre, the process of group devising and writing, and the creation of “theatre as an interactive public space” - the possible dialogue between performers and the audience. Artistic focus: personal story-telling on the stage; personal responsibility in/for the society; processing and talking about trauma memories - family patterns, political and social issues.

She's currently a PhD candidate at the University of Theatre and Film Arts Budapest, and a mentee at "PAP Berlin Mentoringprogramm".

Webpage: www.nederpanni.com
story_txt:
UPDATE: WE DID IT! Many many many tack, you are simply amazing! Love: The Team. 

 
When was the last time you had sex on top of a mountain?
//Wann hast du das letze Mal auf der Spitze eines Berges Sex gehabt? 
- an interactive staged reading 
at GOTHENBURG FRINGE FESTIVAL 2017 | 1th 2nd 3rd of September
 
Three women. A three-headed creature from and between Hungary and Germany. Three theatre-makers. Three points of view. We. We read out loud. We sing sometimes. Wir stellen Fragen. In 14 different languages. About crucial moments. Über Politik. About destiny. About responsibility. About personal issues and priorities. Är det intressant, what we say? Do you understand me? Ymmärrätkö mitä sanon? És ha nem, akkor mi van? 
Does everything have to be understood? When did you ask yourself the last time? When was the last time you had sex on top of a mountain? Do we confront each other with personal questions? Do we react? Does one of us wear a mermaid costume? Do we interact? Do we open? – Yes. We do. Här och nu. 
from and by Adrienn Bazsó, Charlotte Mednansky, Panni Néder
mermaid costume: Rózsa Sebő
subtitling: Zsófi Lili Kovács
text & direction: Panni Néder
trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wMnaLZ8q594 
festival page: https://www.gothenburgfringefestival.com/sexontopofamountain 
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-----------scroll down/görgess le für deutsche Version & magyar szöveg --------------
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 ENGLISH SUMMARY: 
The autobiographical production begins with a Hungarian director in Berlin, facing a dilemma: she has been asked to set up a production and she is scared. Her own diversity as a native of Hungary and Berliner by choice prompts some questions: 
What can, should, must one tell a foreign audience? Is what she has to say even interesting? Will they understand her? 
These questions lead to solutions to the initial conflict. Three performers, including herself, speak for the director's ideas, bounce back and forth in time and space, pick up burning political, social and personal topics and revisit the initial conflict again and again.
The performance is the work of three independent theatre makers with no financial support. Since its debut, "When was the last time you had sex on top of a mountain?" has been shown in Berlin and Geneva and it is invited to this year's Gothenburg FRINGE Festival. We are delighted.
In order to be able to produce our guest performance, we need your support. Our travel expenses are paid-for by the Goethe-Institut, but we need to cover the festival fee, rehearsal and material costs, local travel expenses and meals. 
If our labor of love resonates with you, then support us with a small (or large) amount. And you love our perks, don't you? 
We would be very grateful for every donation. Thank you, merci, köszönöm, tack! 
Kind regards, 
The Team.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 AUF DEUTSCH: Ausgangspunkt der Inszenierung ist eine in Berlin lebende ungarische Regisseurin, die sich gerade in Produktionszwang befindet: sie muss inszenieren und hat davor Angst. Ihre eigene Diversität als gebürtige Ungarin und Wahlberlinerin konkretisiert sich in Fragen:
Was kann/soll/muss man einem fremden Publikum erzählen? Ist es doch interessant was sie sagen will? Wird man sie verstehen?
Entlang diesen Fragestellungen wird die Ausgangssituation aufgelöst: drei Performerinnen (einschließlich sich selbst), die die Gedankengänge der Regisseurin repräsentieren, hüpfen zwischen Zeiten und Orten, greifen brennende politische, gesellschaftliche
und persönliche Themen auf und kehren immer wieder zur Ausgangssituation zurück.
Die szenische Lesung wurde ohne finanzielle Unterstützung von drei unabhängigen Theatermacherinnen kreiert. Seit ihrer Premiere war "Wann hast du das letzte Mal auf der Spitze eines Berges Sex gehabt?" in Berlin zu sehen, sie tourte in Genf und jetzt wurde sie auf das Göteborg FRINGE Festival eingeladen. Wir sind hocherfreut.
Um unsere Gastspieleinladung realisieren zu können, brauchen wir Eure Unterstützung: unsere Fahrtkosten übernimmt das Goethe-Institut, aber wir müssen die Festivalgebühr, Probe- und Materialkosten, Fahrtkosten vor Ort und Verpflegungskosten abdecken.
Wenn ihr unser HerzStück mögt und denkt, dass das ein Kribbeln (oder Schmetterlinge) im Bauch hinterlässt, dann unterstützt uns mit einer kleinen (oder großen) Summe. Und unsere Geschenke (perks) sind hervorragend, nicht wahr?
Wir freuen uns über jeden Beitrag. Thank you, merci, köszönöm, tack!
Liebe Grüße,
Das Team.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


MAGYARUL: Az önéletrajzi előadás kiindulópontja egy Berlinben élő fiatal magyar rendezőnő, aki épp kihívással szembesül: rendeznie kell. És fél tőle. Magyar és berlini identitásai konfliktusba kerülnek egymással, majd különböző kérdésekben öltenek testet:
Mit kell/lehet/tud ő egy külföldi közönségnek prezentálni? Érdekes, amit mondani akar? És egyáltalán érthető?
A kérdések önálló életre kelnek, majd burjánzanak tovább. Az alaphelyzet hamar szertefoszlik: a rendezőnőt képviselő három előadó (köztük ő maga is) különböző helyek, idősíkok, égető politikai-társadalmi és személyes témakörök között ugrál, majd vissza-visszatér a kiindulóponthoz.
A "Mikor szeretkeztél utoljára egy hegy tetején?" c. előadás anyagi támogatás nélkül, három független színházi alkotó önerejéből jött létre. A berlini bemutató óta megjártuk Genfet, most pedig meghívást kaptunk a Göteborgi FRINGE Fesztiválra. És elképesztően boldogok vagyunk.
A vendégjáték megvalósításához viszont szükségünk van a támogatásotokra: az utazási költségeinket a Goethe Intézet finanszírozza, az egyéb fennálló összeget viszont mindenképpen össze kell gyűjtenünk, hogy felléphessünk Svédországban. Amire kalapozunk: a fesztivál illetéki díja, próba- és anyagköltség, utazási költség a városon belül, ellátás.
Ha tetszik a szívügyünk, és netalántán pillangók röpködnek tőle a gyomrotokban, támogassatok minket egy kisebb (vagy nagyobb) összeggel. A cserébe adott ajándékaink pedig kitűnőek, nem igaz?
Minden hozzájárulással nagy örömöt szereztek nekünk. Danke, merci, köszönjük, tack!
Sok szeretettel:
A csapat.
------------------------------------------------------------------------

story:
ChloeIsaBow + Co, founded in 2016 by Chloe Isabelle Bowman is a project-based dance company currently based in Brooklyn, NY. It is their mission to make dance more accessible to a wide range of audiences through collaboration and presentation outside of the traditional theater setting. The company has performed in galleries, outdoor spaces and theaters. Associations have been formed with musicians, visual artists and videographers. They have presented work at Manhattan Movement and Arts Center, The Tank (NYC), Celebrate Downtown (RVA), Green Space (NY) and at Peridance’s APAP Showcase. Through collaboration with her dancers Chloe crafts choreography that fosters intimacy through gesture and attention to detail. The company explores gesture and it’s ability to read as loudly as full-bodied movement. It is their belief that gestures are intrinsically revealing and hands have the ability to communicate experiences and emotions through the slightest movement.

After a year of working in the studio we are extremely excited to be presenting our first evening length work Witness at Dogtown Dance Theatre in Richmond, VA. Dogtown offers artists an incredible space for a more affordable price than theater rentals in larger cities. This will allow us as, a young company to present our work in a state-of-the- art theater. However, we still need your help to make this happen. Your donation will help us continue to grow as a young company. Your gift will go directly to pay for the theater rental, costumes and transportation to Richmond from New York, paying the dancers and staffing the show. We greatly appreciate the support! No amount is too small. 

The company is comprised of three VCU dance and choreography graduates and two George Mason dance graduates. After showing excerpts of the evening length work in various informal showings and festivals in New York we are thrilled to be traveling to Richmond where so many of us have dance roots to premiere the completed piece. 

Witness explores different scenarios as the dancers watch, listen, and react through movement: posing the following questions... How do you react to someone else’s fear? How do you react to your own? Once you witness, do you stay, leave, support, speak the truth? How do you present your evidence and hold yourself accountable? The dancers create a world onstage punctuated with moments of intimacy. Chloe crafts gestural movement which reveals multiple layers and complex relationships. 

Chloe will be holding a free community dance-making class at Dogtown Dance Theatre on Saturday June 10th at 2pm. All are welcome to attend and will hopefully gain insight into the process of making dance and create some of your own!  

Thank you for your support and don't forget to mark your calendars! ChloeIsaBow + Co will present Witness at Dogtown Dance Theatre in Richmond, VA on June 9th and 10th at 7:30pm. Tickets $15 for adults and $10 for students and children. Tickets will go on sale at http://www.dogtowndancetheatre.com

story:
Short Summary

As a theatre practitioner, my main interests are in mental health, fantasy, queerness, and cruelty, and I’m a regular collaborator with Sheffield performance artist Charlotte Blackburn. My show aims to engage audiences on the topic of mental illness, using stories from religion and mythology to unpick the ways in which illnesses such as depression force us to see the world in a different way.

I'm making a show about mental health because it's still something that people feel ashamed of, and the experience of dealing with poor mental health is almost impossible to explain. This, sadly, makes it all the more difficult to bear, seek help for, and treat. I want to give people a glimpse into what it's like - how hard it can be, but also how strong and compassionate it can make you, so that we can start understanding and supporting each other better.

What We Need & What You Get

I need £1,100 to enable me to make my vision a reality. For this project I'll be working with local creatives, and I believe it's important to pay people for their work.  Your funding will help us hire equipment, produce publicity materials, and pay everyone involved a fair rate for their dedication.

In return I can offer my backer a range of perks, from social media love, to signed flyers, to your own short story written by me, and at the upper end, an executive producer credit for helping this show become a reality!

The Impact

As a theatre maker I am connected with mental health charities across the South Yorkshire region, and for this show I'm hoping to offer a code through these channels to enable people suffering from mental health issues to access a lower price ticket for the performance. With this, my hope is that we can reach more members of the community who have a personal connection to the subject, and create discussion, understanding, and support for those who need it most.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to donate, but still want to help Apocalypse of the Mind become a reality, please share this campaign to your social media pages, and help spread the word! You can also complete my show survey, and help me to understand the impact of mental health on as many different people as possible: https://goo.gl/NGZqlE

If you're as excited about the show as I am, you can buy tickets through a link on the Facebook event here: https://goo.gl/CPYy8W 

Thanks in advance for anything you're able to do or give!

story:
Victoria and Jess LOVE. THEIR. LIVES. Honestly, they do.

Sure, Victoria would like to make it through the day without getting baby vomit on her. And Jess would like to have one night out that doesn’t result in popping the morning-after pill. Maybe they sometimes want a little bit of what the other has. But that doesn’t mean they’re unhappy, right?

I’ll Have What She’s Having is a devised performance that uses movement, monologue and sketch to explore contemporary womanhood and ask why, when we have more choices than ever before, every decision we make feels like the wrong one.

When: Every day (!!!) from 3rd - 27th August, 12:15pm (Run Time: 1hr)

Where: Assembly George Square, Studio 4, Edinburgh Fringe Festival 

 

We’d like to live in a world where public and private scrutiny of a woman’s life choices is a thing of the past. But in an age where social media dominates, the judgement and pressures put on women is very real. So real, in fact, that we have found ourselves falling into the trap - judging ourselves and each other about our life decisions. And we don’t think we’re the only ones…

So we decided to have a chat about it - in front of a live audience. Our ‘chat’ will involve dance, sketch,  monologues and - naturally - loads and loads of bananas.

We want to explore the unique pressures placed on women to live their lives based on their biological clock (forge a career, partner up, procreate and get on the property ladder - all whilst HAVING SO MUCH FUN and remaining effortlessly attractive) and ask how these pressures are intensified in an age of constant sharing, liking, regramming and retweeting. Are we so caught up in the filtered versions of our lives that we can’t be sure whether or not we’re actually happy?

In an age where the public persona dominates we want to start a much needed conversation about whether it’s possible to feel satisfied and explore how we got to where we are. Be part of that journey!

 

We are Jess Brodie and Victoria Bianchi, two Scottish theatre makers working collaboratively from 400 miles apart. We are interested in women’s stories, our relationship with social media, pop culture and coming-of-age. We are feminists with a deep-abiding love for Lady Gaga and everything we create is rooted in honesty above all else.

Jess is an actress and writer  based in London. She is a member of Soho Theatre Young Writers’ Lab and has performed at the Tristan Bates, the Bread & Roses and starred in short film FERRET which was recently listed as a semi-finalist at LA Cinefest.

Victoria is a writer and performer based in Glasgow. She has developed performances for  The Arches (Glasgow), Camden People’s Theatre (London), The Gaiety Theatre (Ayr) and the National Theatre of Scotland. As a playwright, she has been commissioned by The National Trust for Scotland, Glasgow Lunchtime Theatre and, most recently, was South Ayrshire Arts Partnership’s writer-in-residence (2015-2018).

 

To make the best work that we can and to make our first collaborative show together show a success, your backing and pledges will be invaluable.

By getting involved and backing this project, you’ll be instrumental in the creation of weird and wonderful ways to explore the nature of contemporary womanhood. What’s more, your pledges will mean that  that this amazing project gets the platforms it needs to spread the word and explore the themes with audiences far and wide.

Your pledges will be used in the following ways:

  • £150 will cover our public liability insurance - a must for any public performance.
  • £200 will go towards our print marketing – the all important flyers and posters so that people know about our work.
  • £100 will help us get some smashing costumes and props for the show.  
  • £150 will go towards the administrative costs and additional venue fees that we haven’t covered yet

So, in total, we need to raise £500 to make this project happen.

Anything above and beyond our goal will be used in the following ways:

  • Invest in more costly but advanced and creatively engaging ways of marketing the show (bananagram anyone?)
  • Improved set and costume purchases
  • Pay ourselves and our producer a modest fee (as we’re all doing this for free!)

 

£250: WHO RUN THE WORLD? (SPONSOR STATUS) -- In an epic show of gratitude you’ll be a named sponsor of the show in the programme, PLUS get a Post Show Banana Split, Free Entry, Feminist Flashdrive, Script Snippets, the Programmed Thanks, and the public Shout Out. (2 available)

£150: GIRLS JUST WANNA HAVE FUN (POST SHOW BANANA SPLIT) -- You’ll receive a (platonic) date with the women themselves! Victoria and Jess will take you out after the show and treat you to a coffee/cake/dessert, allowing for chats about life, feminism and the piece. PLUS you’ll get the Free Entry, Feminist Flashdrive, Script Snippets, the Programmed Thanks, and the public Shout Out.  (3 available)

£100: Q.U.E.E.N (FREE ENTRY) -- A pledge worthy of QUEEN status means you get free entry into the show for you and one of your favs and a personalised thank you card from Victoria & Jess. PLUS you’ll get Feminist Flashdrive, Script Snippets, the Programmed Thanks, and the public Shout Out. (4 available)

£50: INDEPENDENT WOMAN (FEMINIST FLASHDRIVE) -- Your inspiring pledge will be rewarded with more inspiration! You’ll receive access to a drive containing exclusive behind the scenes images and a catalogue of our favourite feminist poetry, books, pop songs, philosophies and more! PLUS you’ll get the Script Snippets, the Programmed Thanks, and the public Shout Out.  (10 available)

£25: REBEL GIRL (SCRIPT SNIPPETS) -- Your generous pennies will be rewarded by our thoughts! You’ll get a personalised sample of the show’s script, including the artists annotations and rehearsal notes PLUS your name in the programme, and the public shoutout. (12 available) 

£10: MATERIAL GIRL (PROGRAMMED THANKS) -- Your kindness will be immortalised by a thank you in our programme, PLUS the public shout out. (20 available)

£5: ROAR (SHOUT OUT) -- You'll get a thank you on from us on Twitter and on our Facebook pages so that everyone knows how much we appreciate your support! (50 available)

You can follow us on Twitter: @MsVictoriaBee & @JessicaB0nnie

Say you're attending on our Facebook Event and invite all your friends!  

Share this fundraising page

Keep an eye on our work and come to see the show!

And if you think theres anything else you'd like to help us with, let us know.

 

THANK YOU

As a playwright, she has been commissioned by The National Trust for Scotland, Glasgow Lunchtime Theatre and, most recently, was South Ayrshire Arts Partnership’s writer-in-residence (2015-2018). To make the best work that we can and to make our first collaborative show together show a success, your backing and pledges will be invaluable.By getting involved and backing this project, you’ll be instrumental in the creation of weird and wonderful ways to explore the nature of contemporary womanhood. What’s more, your pledges will mean that  that this amazing project gets the platforms it needs to spread the word and explore the themes with audiences far and wide.Your pledges will be used in the following ways:

£150 will cover our public liability insurance - a must for any public performance.

£200 will go towards our print marketing – the all important flyers and posters so that people know about our work.

£100 will help us get some smashing costumes and props for the show.  

£150 will go towards the administrative costs and additional venue fees that we haven’t covered yet
So, in total, we need to raise £500 to make this project happen.Anything above and beyond our goal will be used in the following ways:
Invest in more costly but advanced and creatively engaging ways of marketing the show (bananagram anyone?)
Improved set and costume purchases
Pay ourselves and our producer a modest fee (as we’re all doing this for free!)
 £250: WHO RUN THE WORLD? (SPONSOR STATUS) -- In an epic show of gratitude you’ll be a named sponsor of the show in the programme, PLUS get a Post Show Banana Split, Free Entry, Feminist Flashdrive, Script Snippets, the Programmed Thanks, and the public Shout Out. (2 available)£150: GIRLS JUST WANNA HAVE FUN (POST SHOW BANANA SPLIT) -- You’ll receive a (platonic) date with the women themselves! Victoria and Jess will take you out after the show and treat you to a coffee/cake/dessert, allowing for chats about life, feminism and the piece. PLUS you’ll get the Free Entry, Feminist Flashdrive, Script Snippets, the Programmed Thanks, and the public Shout Out.  (3 available)£100: Q.U.E.E.N (FREE ENTRY) -- A pledge worthy of QUEEN status means you get free entry into the show for you and one of your favs and a personalised thank you card from Victoria & Jess. PLUS you’ll get Feminist Flashdrive, Script Snippets, the Programmed Thanks, and the public Shout Out. (4 available)£50: INDEPENDENT WOMAN (FEMINIST FLASHDRIVE) -- Your inspiring pledge will be rewarded with more inspiration! You’ll receive access to a drive containing exclusive behind the scenes images and a catalogue of our favourite feminist poetry, books, pop songs, philosophies and more! PLUS you’ll get the Script Snippets, the Programmed Thanks, and the public Shout Out.  (10 available)£25: REBEL GIRL (SCRIPT SNIPPETS) -- Your generous pennies will be rewarded by our thoughts! You’ll get a personalised sample of the show’s script, including the artists annotations and rehearsal notes PLUS your name in the programme, and the public shoutout. (12 available) £10: MATERIAL GIRL (PROGRAMMED THANKS) -- Your kindness will be immortalised by a thank you in our programme, PLUS the public shout out. (20 available)£5: ROAR (SHOUT OUT) -- You'll get a thank you on from us on Twitter and on our Facebook pages so that everyone knows how much we appreciate your support! (50 available)You can follow us on Twitter: @MsVictoriaBee & @JessicaB0nnieSay you're attending on our Facebook Event and invite all your friends!  Share this fundraising pageKeep an eye on our work and come to see the show!And if you think theres anything else you'd like to help us with, let us know. THANK YOU

story:
Sinner: A Musical Comedy

    We, women raised in the Fundamentalist Evangelical church, are trained to be silent, subservient, hunger-less and small. We are taught to relinquish the ownership of anything that could potentially inconvenience or usurp the agreed upon power structure. Our voices, our autonomy, the empathy and nuance of our better judgment, we learn to distrust them; to detach from the sinful nature of the flesh.  We are raised that ‘righteousness’ lives in the slight, silent, beige frame of a co-dependent woman, toiling to anticipate and graciously meet the needs of others, a boundary-less servant, without inconvenient emotion or objection. She is smiling, unquestioning support and a tray of Nanaimo bars at the ready…She is a tool to be utilized; A colourful male accessory.  While she buys-in, mistrusts and relinquished her own essential strength, he is safe; righteous, she belongs, she is called ‘Blessed’…

     But, what happens when someone who you trust as infallible, fails, when the lines blur and the black and white that made you superior can no longer hold the weight of life's messiness? You know you’ve never really fit. You've always felt wrong. But, as the pillars fall, you realize for the first time, that maybe it's not you, maybe you're not fatally flawed and one wrong word or action away from being unlovable or, well, burning for Eternity... maybe you're not broken and there could be another way.  Maybe the failure of the 'gatekeepers' means a door has been left open to somewhere else. Maybe, outside of the Garden; inside of the label of ‘Sinner’ it may not be the dark, mythically dangerous, wilderness warned of since childhood. Fire and brimstone, and judgement, rejection and shame…spiritual death. What if we are strong enough to take the leap off of the righteous dualistic high ground and into ourselves? Breaking down the scaffolded exoskeleton of ideology, and trusting that the ‘sinful nature’ is just bad marketing. What if, by cultivating our voices and owning our bodies, we found, through the arduous, insecure work of rebuilding, a home, a tribe, an orgasm; a connection with everything…what if, in exile, we found the wide open arms of fearless, vulnerable, unclenched, laughing, warrior-love? Out of Eden, eyes watering, feeling a very similar spiritual stirring, alive, welcome, and loved at 3am, sweating, surrounded by 7 foot tall drag queens in 8 inch heels, as we did on a Sunday morning. We build a new foundational home together with open doors to hold space for other exiles. Free to breathe deeply, to lead, to love: as “Sinner”s. What if we found that the darkness outside of the Garden was not spiritual death, but an invitation to start anew, to grow something beautiful, not a tomb, but a womb.

 

    “Sinner” is the story of such a journey. If Ali Wong, Glennon Doyle and Beyonce created a Musical Comedy about Deconstruction, this is it.  Raised that feminine sexuality is dangerous and all-powerful; all at once taught to repress it as the source of all the world’s sin by her church community AND also to weaponize it, in order to establish a valid place in the world.  Marla was raised to be voiceless, disembodied and codependently performative. She tried, but just naturally didn’t fit, she was too much, too emotional, too big, too loud, too intense… 

    “Sinner” is the comedic musical story of her journey from the Fundamentalist Evangelical church, with its purity culture and chastity rings; Patriarchy and control, through Bible College; the wild west of the escapist Expat life in South Korea, terrible sexual encounters, life lessons in fast forward, and the process of building a new internal foundation of worthiness, spirituality and identity from scratch outside of the evangelical community and framework. Finally, coming to see that this “community”, this church “family”, from the outside, descends dangerously quickly into a fear-based mob mentality, and that the walls of Eden, from exile, are obviously topped with barbed wire…

    We see her go through the dark night of the soul that arrises as she realizes how she has internalized that Patriarchy; how the voices, shame and expectations that were once deafening from well-meaning parents, the side eye of the judging church hierarchy, and the weaponized words of the Apostle Paul, now reside within her… in her connective tissue, shame, fear and anxiety, once disguised as a righteous, protective conscience, now a self sustaining ecosystem of orgasmless, boundariless, codependent aching, narrated by a voice that perfectly mimics her own. 

    We see Marla brave the wilderness, singularly slashing through the thick brush that exists between the ‘safe’, “straight and narrow” Patriarchal territory of belonging, and the Promised Land, the warm Holy ground of embodied freedom, the land of ‘Sinner’s. 

 

How we got here: 

    Marla  Torgerson is a Neo-soul Singer/songwriter from Central Alberta, Canada.  A centre of the Canadian bible belt. While a thinner, more late 90’s style belt, it is a bible belt none the less, and the vibe and fundamentalist evangelical fervour is the same.  

    Marla has a BAMu in opera and has traveled the world performing, co-writing, and working with many impressive names that she drops whenever possible. 

    Marla wrote the initial draft for “Sinner” whilst living in Sevilla, Spain in the first few months of 2020. Mid March, Miss ‘Rona arrived in force and she was locked down; police with big guns in the streets. Weeks before her planned departure and move from Vancouver to Toronto, she had to find a way home to Canada. Flight after flight, cancelled, all three jobs lined up in TO, along with her apartment sublet there, dissolving before her eyes, she was terrified. She reached out to her friends in Alberta, who also come from her tradition but have since deconstructed. They took action and before long, she was on a flight back to ‘berta on the only flight left leaving the Sevilla airport that day, to an extra condo, which had been furnished and stocked for her quarantine.  A detour back to the Bible belt where she is working with the Alberta Playwright’s Network on the show, and because of its Christian undergirding, people are friendly and helpful, and during a pandemic, that is a truly soothing and beautiful thing. 

 

What We’ll do with the Money:

    I’m in the middle of the editing phase right now, the pain-staking microsurgery of paring down the origin 100 pages to its core voice.  Working together with Trevor Rueger as dramaturg, Executive Director at the Alberta Playright’s Network, we are listening for what it truly wants to say. This campaign will allow us to workshop the work on a local stage, having a local Artist perform it for myself and a limited team.  We can then play with it, and it will tell us what it needs in order to truly sing.

    Your support will also allow me to create support materials and a Press Kit to apply for festivals. I will apply for festivals both local and abroad from Edmonton Fringe to Edinburgh Fringe. This campaign is crucial to bringing this story to the world.

    Beyond these things, it will give me a little breathing room, a little less anxiety, a little more mental calm, in order find the centre and serve the story with greater ease.

 

What You Get:

    Well, this is an amazing way to secure your tickets, as all “Original Sinner” tickets will get you pre-sale access to the show of your choice.  You will receive an email 48 hours before tickets go on sale for each show, if you choose to use your tix for that show, simply reply to the email saying as much, and I will reserve some great seats just for you! For those of you who want something special, check out the VIP package.

    MERCH!! I’m so excited about this! I worked with Calgary jewelry designer, Rachael Hatala, of “Laughing Sparrow” to create a custom ring and necklace just for this campaign, ONLY available for you, the “Original Sinners”. The Ring is a square design, one side reading “SINNER” and the other “SAINT”, depending on how the Spirit is leading you on that particular day ;)

    I also designed a sweatshirt. This is the beginning of a line of shirts with quotes from the show, but THIS is the first, the OG. The Sweatshirts from this campaign read “Childhood Trauma Made Me Hilarious.   -sinner.” .. I’m sure you can relate 

    I’ve also made “sinner.” t-shirts and toques. The toques even have a rainbow option!!

    If you want something more personal, maybe a House show is the best option.  After Miss ‘Rona takes her leave, i’ll bring a duo or trio into your living room and do a two hour show for your friends and family. My shows are a mix of soul, folk, rock and originals…with a little classical and broadway thrown in at times, just for shock value… What an amazing way to celebrate being able to stand, mask-less in a room together again!

Why?:

    Why did I write this show?  Honestly, I needed it. The music is a culmination of my life as a songwriter and a profesh singer, but the story is a balm that would have truly soothed me on my journey away from everything that felt safe, known, and meaning-making, on the terrifying road into what was totally new, but turned out to be sacred ground. 

    This show is a light, shining from the darkness of exile; meant to give those who feel voiceless or wrong within the “Garden” a beacon to follow, proof of life; a north star into themselves.

Risks & Challenges

    To be honest, I’m nervous. This show is big and loud and irreverent and funny.  This show lays bare things that which those in my life would probably rather I keep in the family, things that those in the Fundamentalist Evangelical church would rather I hold with ‘fear and trembling’ instead of making jokes about… 

    There will likely be backlash for me, both personally and from the broader church community…but an army of Karen’s won’t stop me from making this happen.

    I’m also nervous about how we will get it to the next level and the next after that, but financial help here, means that my reach and my ability to seek help from those who know, is larger. As we build our community of support; a groundswell of likeminded abundance, it will find its’ way to those who need it most.

Broke as a Joke?? : Here’s Another Way You Can Help

I know…it’s a pandemic, maybe you’re SUPER into this project, but you lost your job and your mental health is precarious at best! How can you help?? Copy the link to the project and send it, along with a lil’ personal message to your people.

Reviews: 

"I totally saw this coming.." -Marla's Childhood Pastor

"Women should remain silent in the churches, they are not allowed to speak, but must be in submission...Two thumbs down" -The Apostle Paul

"Suck in your stomach" - Marla's mother

"Too much self promotion, not enough short-term missions trips" - The Top Wrung Righteous Bitches

"Those spaghetti straps made me stumble" - the boner police

"Marla is apparently now a very chewed up piece of gum" -Marla's creepy youth pastor in full light wash denim

story:
Who We Are

From our inception in 2018, we have made it our duty to create a place where comedy can be accessible to everyone. From NSFE to our new name, Court of Jesters, we have been committed to creating an inclusive comedic environment where people of all backgrounds and beliefs can laugh at themselves and the world around them.

In March of 2020, COVID-19 forced us to look at comedy in a new way. Starting that March, we have created an online, live-streamed format of comedy that could be shared on multiple social media platforms. We have also achieved great things, including being joined by Libertarian Presidential Candidate Vermin Supreme, as well as completing our debut short film.

Now that the world is reopening, we have started to book live shows! In order to pull off these live shows, we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

We are currently hoping to raise $650 for:

  • Audio and video equipment to project our meager voices and to share our comedy with the internet.
  • Gas up our cars to reach gigs in far away areas.

When you donate, you'll have the chance to receive:

  • High fives
  • Live shout-Outs
  • Video roasts
  • Locks of Richie's chest hair (not really).
  • And many other things!

The Impact

Your contribution will help us achieve what we set out to do since the inception of our group. We are still committed to and are actively pursuing new ways to make comedy accessible to all people, regardless of who you are.

In the future, we hope to create workshops, compete in festivals, and take over the world of conventional comedy.

Risks & Challenges

As with any comedy group, our risks are shared by most comedians and improv groups in the Northeast U.S. Low attendance, double bookings, and other small irritations all present themselves to us at different times, but we know how to handle such things: with dignity, grace, and throwing up a little.

Other Ways You Can Help

If a monetary donation isn't in the cards for you right now, there are other ways you can help us out:

  • Sharing our Indiegogo page on your respective social media channels.
  • Following us on social media everywhere @courtofjesters.

Thank you so much for helping us out.

story:
*****  WE MADE IT *****  WE MADE IT ***** 

***** WE MADE IT ***

WE MAAAAADE IIIITTTTT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

After securing a two week winter residency courtesy of Dancemakers, Toronto – that means a BIG reduction in our rehearsal costs – some more donated time that's reducing what we originally needed to cover costume and prosthetic fabrication, and a live event this past weekend that raised $1400, we have COVERED ALL OF OUR COSTS. 

Yup, we know that our #s here are showing only about half of our original goal, but that's okay! Indiegogo isn't an "all or nothing" platform, so we receive your donations regardless of whether or not we hit that original estimation (which, thanks to the above, got WAY, WAY reduced).

THANK YOU!

***********************************************************

Hello! Thanks for taking a look at our crowdfunding page! We are Troy James and Ess Hödlmoser, and we are a couple of performers from Toronto, Canada. 

We are (very) late bloomers in the circus world: Troy began his professional performance career LAST YEAR after his inhuman mobility was discovered online and went viral; Ess began training in contortion 3 years ago, after a lifetime of below-average flexibility and an above-average combination of stubbornness and drive to succeed. 

We have been selected to perform in the 40th anniversary of the Festival Mondiale du Cirque de Demain (Jan 31 - Feb 3, 2019) —  this festival is sometimes referred to as ‘the Olympics of Circus’ (!!!) and it’s a once in a lifetime opportunity that changes the lives of those who are given the honour of attending.

What We Need 

Your donations will help cover our immediate costs of rehearsal space fees, engaging our costume designer and costume construction, paying our sound designer, and covering the platform fees for the campaign:

  • REHEARSAL SPACE FEES
  • COSTUME DESIGN & MATERIALS, SPFX
  • SOUND DESIGN

Anything you contribute to the page will go directly to these overhead costs of preparing for this incredible event, and is going to help us make sure that we bring a package that we are proud of – and that YOU guys as our friends, family, community members, and fellow artists can be proud of too! – to this international stage.

And – we will keep YOU GUYS in the loop with updates as to our progress, so that you know where your donations have gone and what they are helping to achieve. We will fill you in on our progress and brought with us on our journey every step of the way with video and written updates posted here to this campaign page! 

GIVING BACK: 

 If our projected costs end up being less than the donations we have received, we would like to donate these funds to the CATALYST program run by the Contemporary Circus Festival of Toronto. CATALYST is a seed program that awards a micro-grant to three emerging contemporary circus artists in Toronto, and gives them rehearsal time and mentorship under a choreographer and artistic director. This program is a strong tool to help independent emerging circus artists develop the skills needed to elevate their craft in our community.  Ess was an inaugural recipient of this program in Fall of 2017.
 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP US!

We know that even if you love the idea of a couple of helping a couple of circus underdogs making their way to the big stage you might not be able to help us with a financial pledge. If that is the case, don't worry! There are other ways to help us: ask your friends, family, coworkers, guardian angels, and arch nemeses to get the word out and make some noise about our project!
story_txt:
*****  WE MADE IT *****  WE MADE IT ***** 
***** WE MADE IT ***
WE MAAAAADE IIIITTTTT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!After securing a two week winter residency courtesy of Dancemakers, Toronto – that means a BIG reduction in our rehearsal costs – some more donated time that's reducing what we originally needed to cover costume and prosthetic fabrication, and a live event this past weekend that raised $1400, we have COVERED ALL OF OUR COSTS. 

Yup, we know that our #s here are showing only about half of our original goal, but that's okay! Indiegogo isn't an "all or nothing" platform, so we receive your donations regardless of whether or not we hit that original estimation (which, thanks to the above, got WAY, WAY reduced).
THANK YOU!
***********************************************************
Hello! Thanks for taking a look at our crowdfunding page! We are Troy James and Ess Hödlmoser, and we are a couple of performers from Toronto, Canada. 
We are (very) late bloomers in the circus world: Troy began his professional performance career LAST YEAR after his inhuman mobility was discovered online and went viral; Ess began training in contortion 3 years ago, after a lifetime of below-average flexibility and an above-average combination of stubbornness and drive to succeed. 
We have been selected to perform in the 40th anniversary of the Festival Mondiale du Cirque de Demain (Jan 31 - Feb 3, 2019) —  this festival is sometimes referred to as ‘the Olympics of Circus’ (!!!) and it’s a once in a lifetime opportunity that changes the lives of those who are given the honour of attending.


What We Need 
Your donations will help cover our immediate costs of rehearsal space fees, engaging our costume designer and costume construction, paying our sound designer, and covering the platform fees for the campaign:

REHEARSAL SPACE FEES
COSTUME DESIGN & MATERIALS, SPFX
SOUND DESIGN

Anything you contribute to the page will go directly to these overhead costs of preparing for this incredible event, and is going to help us make sure that we bring a package that we are proud of – and that YOU guys as our friends, family, community members, and fellow artists can be proud of too! – to this international stage.And – we will keep YOU GUYS in the loop with updates as to our progress, so that you know where your donations have gone and what they are helping to achieve. We will fill you in on our progress and brought with us on our journey every step of the way with video and written updates posted here to this campaign page!

 If our projected costs end up being less than the donations we have received, we would like to donate these funds to the CATALYST program run by the Contemporary Circus Festival of Toronto. CATALYST is a seed program that awards a micro-grant to three emerging contemporary circus artists in Toronto, and gives them rehearsal time and mentorship under a choreographer and artistic director. This program is a strong tool to help independent emerging circus artists develop the skills needed to elevate their craft in our community.  Ess was an inaugural recipient of this program in Fall of 2017. 
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP US!
We know that even if you love the idea of a couple of helping a couple of circus underdogs making their way to the big stage you might not be able to help us with a financial pledge. If that is the case, don't worry! There are other ways to help us: ask your friends, family, coworkers, guardian angels, and arch nemeses to get the word out and make some noise about our project!

story:
The story behind our show - and the reason for our Indiegogo campaign - is a common one.

Most established theaters do not want to risk scaring away their loyal subscribers with unconventional productions. Most theaters have enough trouble keeping the lights on - even when they are giving folks exactly what they want.

In the world of fiction writing, the short story has evolved into an established and acceptable form. If you say you're a short story writer, nobody asks you when you're going to get serious. In theater, however, folks still think of the short play as - you know - a stepping stone to the "real" play.

So, when you have a collection of short plays that you know in your heart are solid enough to make for a great night of theater, and there's nobody willing to foot the bill...well...you just gotta do it yourself.

 

AMERICAN FABLES was an evening of five short one-acts that shifted from a bench in Central Park, to a prison cell in Tehran, to an office at the Pentagon, to a law firm in Manhattan, to a small-town library in New England.

In each play, a simple conversation took an unexpected turn and eventually buckled under the strain of cultural misunderstanding, suspicion and desire. 

 

For this project, we could have gone with a smaller, less expensive theater, and we could have found a less professional cast and crew. We could have done this on the cheap. But we decided to pull out all the stops. This was not a low budget show. Only our good friends Clark Morgan and Alex Heil (director and set designer) volunteered their time and skill - everyone else got paid . And our theater at HERE arts center in Soho is top notch, so the venue rental alone was $10,000.

 

Our show ran for 8 nights, and it was a huge success. It couldn't have come together more beautifully. The actors were brilliant, the direction was visionary, audiences were moved, More than one person - with absolutely no connection to me or the cast - came up to us after the show to say it was the best hour of theater they could remember. 

 

SO HERE'S THE THING. We launched this INDIEGOGO campaign for two reasons:

 1) We managed to get some great audiences during our run, but the box office returns only covered a fraction of our out-of-pocket expenses. We're not looking for a profit, just would love to break even.

2) This show deserves more than 8 nights. It deserves a REAL RUN. We are currently reaching out to producers in the hopes of giving this wonderful show and these superb actors the opportunity they deserve - a real run, real compensation, real reviews. 

WITH YOUR SUPPORT, WE CAN KEEP THIS SHOW ALIVE!!!!

You have two great options here. 1) You can simply click BACK IT and donate. OR, we have put together a great list of perks in exchange for you support. THE BRUNCH AT SOHO HOUSE/DUMBO HOUSE WILL BLOW YOUR MIND. 

Please consider supporting us and giving AMERICAN FABLES the opportunity to have a life beyond our short run.

THANK YOU!!!!!

Eric Fallen

PS. If you have ANY QUESTIONS, pleas call me directly at 917-399-5221

story:
Hello, we are award nominated comedy sketch group Kitten Killers!

 

We are taking our brand new show Kitten Killers: Stallions to the Edinburgh Fringe (Underbelly, 9.30pm)!

 

Taking a show to the Edinburgh Fringe is very expensive.  We are asking for your help to raise £1,500 towards:

  • Theatre hire
  • Technical support
  • Flyers
  • Posters
  • Marketing
  • Promotion
  • Travel
  • Accommodation 
  • Insurance

Everyone who contributes will get a Kitten Killers badge and lots of Social Media shout outs and love!

Thank you in advance for supporting Kitten Killers!

★★★★ (Arts Award Voice)  ★★★★ (Ed Fringe Review) ★★★★ (Female Arts) ★★★★ (Fourthwall Magazine) ★★★★ (Reading Post) ★★★★  (Remote Goat) ★★★★  (Theatre Bubble)

'Brilliant physical comedy and surreal skits' FEMALE ARTS

'Outrageously funny' FOURTHWALL MAGAZINE

'Weird and wonderful sketch show' ED FRINGE REVIEW

'Kitten Killers are surely on the road to small screen success' REMOTE GOAT

'Witty and sharp' THE ARGUS

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Follow us on Facebook or Twitter @KittenKillers
  • Share this page with friends, family and comedy fans alike
  • Book tickets to see our show in Edinburgh http://www.underbellyedinburgh.co.uk/whats-on/k...
  • Come and see us in London : Dates on our Facebook
  • Tell a friend! Better still, tell them publicly on Twitter or Facebook! Or cry it from the rooftops!

story:
What if the apocalypse happened and the only apparent survivors were three bears?  Two captive grizzlies, Growl Bear and Timmy Bear, find themselves stuck in a suddenly deserted zoo.  Enter Susie, a wild-born bear, who convinces them to leave the safety of their cave and venture into the wilderness.  Once there, they must survive in an unfamiliar and hostile environment while coming to terms with what it truly means to be a bear. 

Your donations will primarily go towards paying for production elements and our space at 59E59 Theaters. Your support will help us create the world of the play, in this case a zoo, the wilderness, and its ursine inhabitants in a beautiful, unique facility. We can't do it without you. Thank you so much for all of your continued support.

Sans A Production's Mission:

We believe that how we make something is as important as what we make. Sans A Productions was started by five artists from all disciplines of theatre who seek pure collaboration. We give equal weight to all areas of production in order to tell a story thatâs greater than the sum of its parts. We believe this kind of process yields theatre that reverberates with our audiences.

story:
What makes New Camerata Opera Special?

How are we planning on building new audiences for opera?

  • We are bringing opera into the digital age with YouTube opera shorts, finally taking advantage of new media platforms.
  • A large portion of our endeavor is dedicated to introducing young people to opera, through live performances of new children's opera adaptations. 
  • Our full-length MainStage operas will be fresh and full of theatricality, yet musically precise, and stylistically faithful.  

Fundraising Efforts

Though this campaign is only a portion of our fundraising efforts, the money we raise with it will go a long way in helping us successfully meet our ambitious goals, in our first season.  

Our expenses include:

  • Rehearsal and performance venue rentals.
  • Production staffing.
  • Costumes, set pieces, lights and equipment rentals.

Challenges

    Opera is one of the most challenging forms of theatre to produce, due to its endless number of production-elements (music, dance, acting, sets, costumes, props, etc).  Making operatic movies is even more daunting!  How are we going to pull this off?

    • By ALWAYS living within our means as a company:  we will fundraise as much as we can, but program according to what our season budget is, and what our realistic expenses will be.
    • We will tap into the unique skill-sets and resources of our company members.  We are not just singers, but graphic designers, video editors, and website designers.  

    When PASSION, like ours, meets careful PLANNING, we can meet our goals.  With your contributions, we can help promote opera as a vibrant, communicative and thriving 21st Century theatrical art!

How are we planning on building new audiences for opera?

We are bringing opera into the digital age with YouTube opera shorts, finally taking advantage of new media platforms.
A large portion of our endeavor is dedicated to introducing young people to opera, through live performances of new children's opera adaptations. 
Our full-length MainStage operas will be fresh and full of theatricality, yet musically precise, and stylistically faithful.  


Fundraising Efforts
Though this campaign is only a portion of our fundraising efforts, the money we raise with it will go a long way in helping us successfully meet our ambitious goals, in our first season.  
Our expenses include:

Rehearsal and performance venue rentals.
Production staffing.
Costumes, set pieces, lights and equipment rentals.


Challenges


Opera is one of the most challenging forms of theatre to produce, due to its endless number of production-elements (music, dance, acting, sets, costumes, props, etc).  Making operatic movies is even more daunting!  How are we going to pull this off?

By ALWAYS living within our means as a company:  we will fundraise as much as we can, but program according to what our season budget is, and what our realistic expenses will be.
We will tap into the unique skill-sets and resources of our company members.  We are not just singers, but graphic designers, video editors, and website designers.  


When PASSION, like ours, meets careful PLANNING, we can meet our goals.  With your contributions, we can help promote opera as a vibrant, communicative and thriving 21st Century theatrical art!

story:
The Play, and Who We Are 

Woven Theatre is new company in Nashville, TN founded by three Belmont University B.F.A. Directing Majors, seeking to produce outstanding theatre. Giant Squid will be the first of three full-scale productions happening between June and September. 

New work is the heartbeat that drives theatre. Without the development of new work, new playwrights, and new perspectives, theatre would never evolve. Art grows to reflect the world around it. 

Giant Squid  is new play written by Miles Gatrell, an M.F.A. candidate at the University of Iowa. It follows two sets of young people in their late teens and mid-twenties as they try to find and understand what it means to be happy and accepted. Giant Squid has a strong voice with superb characters and speaks directly to what it means to live in this world today. 

In April of 2016 it was produced as a staged reading as part of Belmont University's New Works Festival. This reading served as a workshop of sorts and since then we've been using the feedback we got to improve the play and make it the best it can be. 

Backing this campaign will help cultivate a new play, a unique perspective, and the next generation of theatre artists.  

Giant Squid has it's world premier June 23rd in the Belmont Little Theatre under Hail Hall in the center of Belmont University's Campus. 

Giant Squid runs June 23rd-26th and July 7th-10th at 7:30 P.M. Central Time.

The Things we Need and the Things you Get

Plain and simple the funding from this will go to producing Giant Squid. 

Which includes the following:

-Paying the Actors=$600

-Paying the Design Team=$500

-Budgets for Poster/Set/Costumes/Props=$400

-Paying the Box Office and Show Run Personal=$400

-Contingency Fund=$200

Total $2100


If any extra funds are left over at the end a portion would go to paying our wonderful people a little more for their amazing work. After that, any remaining funds would roll into future Woven Theatre productions. 


Now here's the fun part! Listed below are the awesome perks you get for contributing to this campaign. 

-$5-The Baby Squid 

Our love and thanks!

-$15-The Toddler Squid Package

Our love and thanks and printed thank you in the program. 

-$25-The Pre-teen Squid Package

The above, plus a ticket to the show, and personally written thank you from a team member. 

-$50-The Teenage Squid Package

The above, plus a digital copy of the production photos. 

-$85-The Man Squid Package

The above, plus another ticket totaling 2, and a signed poster. 

-$100-The Giant Squid Package

The above, plus another ticket totaling 3, and come join us for a rehearsal in person or thru Skype. 

-$150-Attack of the Giant Squid Package

The above, plus another ticket totaling 4, and a meet and greet after the show. 


The Impact of Supporting the Giant Squid 

Creating theatre requires a team and by backing this you become part of the team. 

All of us have been involved with countless productions ranging from acting to building and from designing to running the box office. As cliche as it sounds, this isn't our first rodeo. 

Between us we have Assistant Directed, Sound Designed, and Prop Mastered for Verge Theatre Company. Sound designed for the Nashville Rep and the Nashville Shakespeare Festival. Worked with the Nashville Childrens Theatre and Studio Tenn. Performed and/or Directed with Blackbird, Little Stone, Actor's Bridge, Belmont University, the Nashville Shakespeare Festival, and Lipscomb University. This is just to name a few. Some of us have been nominated and received awards from the Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival.  All this is to say we have extensive knowledge and experience with producing and creating theatre. 

Even if you can't contribute you can still help! Share this campaign! Throw it into the world! Get the word out and if you can, come see the show!
