SUJETS: "Quoi faire?"

Quelle est la chose
juste à faire?
Qu’il ne s’est jamais posé cette question ? Combien
de fois, au moment de prendre une décision importante, pendant que le monde
autour nous serre et que le temps nous presse, la peur de donner une mauvaise
réponse à cette question nous fait hésiter et nous bloque en nous forçant à baisser
la tête et à accepter la vie tel qu’elle est ? La réponse de Jules, Jouin,
Platano, Rirette, Victor et de tous les personnages de ce spectacle – tous
ayant réellement vécu – est une seule et elle est chorale : n’hésitez pas,
osez, faites, car ainsi personne un jour ne viendra nous accuser de pas avoir
au moins essayé.

Tous les personnages de ce
spectacle essayent. Ils essayent de changer le monde entier et de le rendre
plus juste, equilibré ; ils essayent respectivement de mettre de l’ordre
ou de rendre la nation plus sûre ; ils essayent de gérer au mieux leur
enterprise et leur Pays ; ils essayent de favoriser tant que faire se
pourra l’épanuissement d’un amour, d’un fils ou plus simplement ils essayent de
crèer, au moins pour eux-même, une vie meilleure. Mais la vie, telle qu’elle est, ne donne pas que des
solutions claires, elle offre de nombreuses nuances et dégradés: au cri
« les patrons sont tous des porcs » la vie répond par un patron comme
Dupré traitant son chauffer avec respect et amitié ; au slogan « les
subversifs sont tous violents » elle oppose des penseurs accomplis comme
Victor Kibalcic ; à la conviction « les policiers sont tous des conards» la
vie oppose l’acharné chercheur du vrai
qu’est le commissaire Jouin.
C’est ici qu’émerge l’âme de ce croisement de
vies. Car à chaque fois qu’une solution facile se présente, rassurante, telle
l’idée d’un ennemi à combattre ou la possibilité d’un bouc émissaire, une
nouvelle rencontre nous surprend et les appuis solides  préétablis s’évanouissent sous nos pieds, nous
laissant victimes d’une insécurité éternelle. Là est pour nous le centre de notre pièce et c’est
aussi là qu’est le point de départ de notre recherche.
Notre bout est
de nourrir et grandir cette insécurité dedans le public.Nous voulons qu’ils sortent du théâtre munis d’une
question concrète : avec qui se ranger? Une question à laquelle
souvent nous répondons trop vite, d’une façon instinctive, mais qui, si nous
l’analysons vraiment bien, est beaucoup plus complexe que ce que nous pourrions
croire: est-ce que je devrais me ranger du côté de ceux qui se battent
contre la violence du pouvoir ou avec le Pouvoir qui se bat contre les   violentes ? 

Nous sommes mis face à des thématiques tout à fait
actuelles bien qu’elles soient liées a la période d’entre la fin du XIXème et
du début du XXème siècle. On parle de droits ou mieux, de leur absence.
Première chose on parle du droit au travail, de son absence qui amène à la
perte de dignité et du fait que cet absence de dignité amène les gens à
commettre des actions extrême tout en essayant par la même de regagner ladite dignité.
On parle du désir d’un Etat juste, garant d’une vie digne, capable de donner la
voix à tout le monde et agissant de façon légale et transparente, et dans le
même temps il est question d’un désir de l’Etat, pour lui-même, et de ses
fonctionnaires en tant que garants de l’assurance d’un bien être de ses
citoyennes contre des gens qui, pour des raisonnes de justice sociale, agissent
contre l’Etat même. On parle de la négation de la liberté de parole et du choix
entre utopie et réalisme. On se demande ce qu’il voudrait mieux choisir entre
« rébellion » et «révolution» 
et on questionne la si subtile limite entre lutte et terrorisme.
Au fur et à mesure que notre travail progresse et que le spectacle grandit,
plus nous découvrons que tout cela nous parle d’aujourd’hui. Cela établit, nous
continuons à travailler et à découvrir – essayant de pas nous ranger, essayant
de rester sur la frontière fragile où souvent se trouve la vérité. Car la
matière est trop grande, trop actuelle et trop nécessaire pour faire de ce
spectacle le simple manifeste d’une idée.


                              



PERSONNES: B o r g o b o n ó


Un des points
forts de notre travail sont les gens.
Tous les personnes
qui font partie de Borgobonó Cie sont des professionnels du théâtre, passionnés
par leur travail et entrainés dans certaines parmi les meilleures écoles de
théâtre européen:

LAMDA - London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art - Londres
École Internationale
de Théâtre Jacques Lecoq - Paris
Scuola d’Arte
Drammatica "Paolo Grassi" - Milan
Accademia
Nazionale d’Arte Drammatica "Silvio d'Amico" - Rome
Prima del teatro.
European School for the Art of the Actor - Pise

Nous croyons tout
à fait que la diversité soit une source de richesse inépuisable pour nourrir et
alimenter la créativité et c’est pour cette raison que nous l’avons voulue
amener meme au sein de notre projet en faisant en sorte que toutes les
composantes du projet sont venus de différentes formations.



MUSIQUE
           
Un autre point fort de notre spectacle est la musique.                                         
Toutes les
chansons de En tous cas pas de remords
sont joués en direct et composée spécialement pour notre spectacle par Adele
Pardi, violoncelliste, chanteur, compositeur, gagnante du premier prix au
Festival acoustique de Trento, gagnante du prix Pavanello Giovani Cantautori
2012 et pourtant partie intégrante des Borgobonó.
Adèle travaille
avec le réalisateur et les acteurs, composer pendant les essais et en
complétant le travail des acteurs. La musique de Dans tous les cas, aucun
regret ne est jamais une bande-son, mais ce est toujours un acteur sur scène.



MATÉRIAUX ET MOUVEMENT

Le premier point à élucider
était l’utilisation que nous aurions à faire de l’espace. L’histoire de En tout cas, pas de remords se développe
en fait entre France, Italie, Angleterre et Belgique, dans un changement
perpétuel des lieux de scène. De plus, de nombreuses scènes sont des
« intérieurs » qui alternent immédiatement avec les  « extérieurs ». Pour cette raison,
nous avions besoin d’un espace qu’il ne fut pas fixe mais qu’il offrirait la
possibilité au public de nous suivre sans rester fixé dans un seul lieu et
histoire : un espace malléable et prêt à changer tout à fait chaque fois
que nous en avions eu besoin. La solution a été d’utiliser un espace vide.
Grace à cet espace, un mot e un regard suffisent à changer l’espace  et le temps. Ce qui d’ailleurs souligne mieux
les rapports humaines, comme il n’y a rien d’autre : ce sont eux – les
rapports entre les personnes – qui créent le monde autour, le contexte,
l’ambiance. 
Arrivé à ce point-là du travail, nous éprouvions
le besoin de quelque chose pour rendre l’espace concret. Deux choses nous ont
semblé pouvoir être signifiées : le travail dans les usines et la
révolution que la diffusion de l’automobile a provoqué. Nous avons choisi
d’utiliser des pallets et des roues
de vélo comme seules matériaux scéniques. Ils sont des matériaux basiques –
bois et fer – et ils donnent immédiatement la sensation concret du travail en
scierie et des maisons des gens humbles ; ils sont capables – car leur
forme est « brute » – de donner corps à plusieurs images différents
grâce à l’habilité du manipulateur secondée par l’imagination du public.
Le spectacle se développe entre
narration et scènes dialoguées. Les comédiens sur scène seront quatre et ils
changeront en permanence de rôle, passant de narrateurs à personnages et
manipulateurs d’objets, pour donner la vie à plusieurs figures, dans différents
espaces.
                                                     _______________________
A bientôt! 
B o r g o b o n ó

story:
Platinum Studios is a Tax-Exempt NonProfit that provides free and low-cost dance lessons, wellness classes, shoes, and recital costumes to children in the Rochester, MN community, and the surrounding area. In doing so we provide dance opportunities for children whose families may not be able to afford to allow their children to dance. We hope that by providing what we do we will in turn provide a safe, enjoyable environment for these children to pursue their passions. We also provide dance competition scholarships for the children who are wanting to move forward with their passion for the arts. While we had been successful for a year as a For-Profit company we decided that we wanted to make a difference in the lives of children and be something MORE than just the typical dance company.
It is our hope that by providing  free and very low-cost dance training and wellness classes to underprivledged youth we will be able to provide a safe place for children to pursue their passions, educate them on healthy lifestyles, and give them opportunities to take their passions to new levels that they would normally not be able to afford.

story:
Your generous donations will be used for the (2) week creation process of Rockridge Dance Theatre's first company repertoire piece. The company will premiere an excerpt at The Joyce Theatre in New York City on January 30th! We're so grateful for your help! 

Rehearsal/Creation Period: January 16-29th (NYC)

Performance Dates: January 30th (NYC)

FUNDING OUTLINE:

- 6 Company Dancer for two week creation process (NYC)

- Rehearsal Studio for two week creation process (NYC)

- Costume Design and Production 

- Music Composition 

- Travel and Lodging (NYC)

ROCKRIDGE DANCE THEATRE: 

Founded by contemporary visual, dance, and theatre artists RockRidge Dance Theatre was created on the belief that live dance performance and classical narrative based dramatic performance could in 2016 be rediscovered with an elevated union.


RockRidge Dance Theatre is heavily influenced by its founder’s love of classical clown, mask, contemporary ballet, and the work of Philadelphia based Pig Iron Theatre Company.

“We want to make dance performance that invigorates and challenges the viewer…and of course it has to be beautiful!” - Sarah Brinson, Founder & Artist Director

“We believe the theatre is a very special place; our work has to match that belief, we aim to create culturally relevant, approachable, moving dance performance.” - J. Alex Brinson, Founder & Executive Director


Movement with meaning…RDT
Filling every moment with meaning…RDT

Subscribe here for company updates, auditions, and tour info: www.rockridgedance.com

story:
Our Story

  All That JAWS: A Sharktastic New Musical is written by Keenan Camp, Logan Dean and Chris Gorton. Directed by Keenan Camp. Produced by Erin Lane. Lifelong fans of the film, we decided to pay homage to it by recreating it for the stage with a lot of dark/silly humor and musical numbers thrown in. While you could classify it as a parody, we like to think of it as a love letter to one of the greatest films of the twentieth century.

A brief discription of the show:

When a gigantic, lonely, and misunderstood great white shark named Jaws comes to the small island community of Amity looking for friendship, his plans are thwarted by his baser instincts to eat everything and everyone around him.
It's up to Martin Brody, a functioning alcoholic cop from NYC, and Amity's new chief of police, to bring the beast to justice. He is aided by overly passionate oceanographer, Matt Hooper, and a grizzled shark hunter, with too much salt water on the brain, by the name of Bartholemew M. Quint.

Our goals

  Making a show like this is more than just hard work and talented contributors, it also takes a good amount of money to get it off the ground. We are asking for 5,525 dollars in order to make this show a reality.

  Every cent of the money made on this fundraising campaign, even if we don't meet our initial goal, goes to a certain aspect of the shows production including, but not limiited to:

   - Theater Rental (Because space isn't cheap)

   - Crew payment (Choreographer, Music Director, Stage manager, etc)

   - Costumes, Props and Sets (We do have a man-size shark suit after all)

   - Marketing and advertisment (To help us reach all the Finatics we can)

To help us reach this lofty goal, we've created some great perks to show our donors how much we appreciate them, including: Special thanks on our DVD and Program, Tickets to the show and our after party, souvenir photos and posters, copies of the dvd and even t-shirts!

The Impact

   Your contributions will help us bring this fun and unique show to fruition. Our goal has always been to make a show that is not only entertaining, but also an endearing gift to the fans of the film. Members of our production team have successfully created such popular live shows as The Show Below, Attend the Tale of Danny Tanner: A Full House Musical and Jersey Shore: The Musical. These past projects have been a labor of love and this show is no different. Even if we are unable to raise our entire goal, we will strive to put on the best show we can, because that is what we do. 

Other Ways You Can Help

   If money is tight and you just can't find a way to contribute to the campaign, please help us spread the word about this project. By sharing the campaign on your Facebook, Twitter or Tumblr account, you will help us build a larger audience that we would not have immediate access to.

   You can also help by sharing our Facebook page, www.facebook.com/allthatjaws , our Twitter, @AllThatJAWS and our Youtube account www.youtube.com/allthatjaws.  

 

  Thanks for taking the time to check out the project. Hopefully you can help us reach our goal, and if not, please help us spread the word about his amazing project that we are all so very proud of, because we're gonna need a bigger boat.

story:
Our Story

Horse Trade has been producing theater in the East Village since 1998.   We offer inexpensive space rental for self-producing artists; we produce with guest artists, resident artists, and our veteran resident artists. Horse Trade hosts FRIGID New York, a festival that gives 100% of the box office back to the artists, The Fire This Time, a festival that gives voices to emerging African American Playwrights and Imbewu, a contemporary South African theater festival. We bring performers from Canada, South Africa, and all over the United States. We have sent our local New York talent to share their work in Indianapolis, Orlando, San Francisco, New Orleans, Montreal, Toronto, Winnipeg, and Edmonton; and the list keeps growing.

Over the past 13 years we have painstakingly created a home for a community of varied voices which values and displays a vast amount of collaboration, resourcefulness, and innovation. We view ourselves as the research and development wing of American theater. We are proud to provide a training ground for Broadway’s future stars, writers, technicians, designers and other artistic and management personal.


We have been called "A mecca for teriffic off- off Broadway theater," by Martin Denton of NYTheatre.com and  “the epicenter of the independent theater world in New York,"  By Leonard Jacobs Director of the Cultural Institutions Unit at NYC Department of Cultural Affairs. Rachel Chavkin of the TEAM has written that "Companies tend to establish a reputation around the Horse Trade Theaters."


The Impact

The building that houses our UNDER St Marks Theater, one of our three theater spaces, is now up for sale. We hope to purchase 94 St. Marks Place and make a permanent space where artists can create, learn, grow and share. The amount of money we are attempting to raise in this fundraising drive is not enough to buy the building, but it will be enough to launch a capitol campaign that will allow us to do so. 


What We Need & What You Get

We will use the funds we raise to draw up architectural plans, create legal documents, and put together a professional business and marketing packet.  These things cost money and this is why we are asking for your help.  What you will get in return, aside from the trinkets associated with your donation amount, is a permanent home for artists to come and express themselves in front of a live theater audience.  You will have a hand in creating a place for people to share their work, get inspired or just be entertained in the company of others.  If you have seen a show at UNDER St. Marks you understand; if you have not, then help us insure that you get that opportunity.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass word about this campaign to everyone you know, the NYC real estate market is tough to beat but our work goes out to people all over the North America and there is real power in numbers, help us reach those numbers and increase our power.

story:
Our Story

DIONYSIA is Poor Dog Groups’ latest contemporary theatrical saga that condenses the form of festival into a densely layered examination of Greek mythology, image and folklore. Based on fragmented texts by Euripides and other known poets, found at Oxyrhynchus and originally commissioned by The Getty Villa, DIONYSIA transforms space and time as multiple story lines take on shifting and complex perspectives delving deeper into our collective sub-conscience and redefining what is known as the satyr play.

Our mission is to develop original theatrical expression through the creation of new work and radical reexaminations of existing texts; to redefine, educate and expand our own perceptions of performance and theatrical form; to have an accessibility for a new audience; to use experimental methods of the body, text and technology; to craft new American theater; and to develop the cultivation of a limitless and periodic space. PDG is now positioning itself for long term sustainability, providing a wide range of programming initiatives, community outreach programs, innovative performance works, and international collaboration.


The Impact

With project support from outstanding citizens, like yourself, Poor Dog Group will aggressively usurp the full potential of our time at EMPAC by providing artist fees, housing stipends and essential production materials. Founded by Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, EMPAC offers artists, scholars, researchers, engineers, designers, and audiences opportunities for creative exploration that are available nowhere else under a single roof. EMPAC operates nationally and internationally, attracting creative individuals from around the world and sending new artworks and innovative ideas onto the global stage.

 

Due to the technical challenges of our work, single institutions cannot offer full financial support. Now more than ever, it is essential for us to form new relationships with art lovers in order to continue producing innovative theater nationally and abroad. Poor Dog Group is poised for national exposure with established relationships presenting at organizations such as REDCAT, The Getty Villa, EMPAC and festival support such as The Public’s Under the Radar and RADAR LA. With gained financial traction from you, yes you, DIONYSIA can fully be realized and exposed to eager artistic and executive directors from all across our nation. With this high level of visibility we will tour DIOYNSIA hopefully starting in 2012 to communities across the USA and abroad. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please send this page as a link to a friend and together we can hit our goal of $10,000.00! You can also find out more about POOR DOG GROUP and DIONYSIA by going to our website: www.poordoggroup.com or find us on FACEBOOK!

story:
A New Play By

Azure Steel Waters

Directed By

Albion Walker


Synopsis

In a day and age of political correctness people have gotten away from expressing their real thoughts and feelings. Everyone is so polite; so nice. Sometimes we all need to start Talkin Sh##.

 

In the second stage play by Azure Steel Waters, Talkin Sh## ,  focuses on the blunt and controversial opinions of three friends; D’Mone, Larnell, and Marquez.

 

Larnell, a mellow IT administrator, navigates the world and his relationship. Marquez, a charismatic pre-k teacher, contrasts the love and respect he has for children with the complete lack of respect he has for women. D’Mone, an unemployed and homeless philosopher, spouts his rhetoric from the comfort of his friends couch.

 

These friends examine what’s wrong with the world through their unique perspectives but it all boils down to Talkin Sh##.


How You Can Help

ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!!

Every dollar counts as we work towards making this shared vision a reality. The Indiegogo goal is three quarters of the overall budget and we will use the money as a portion of our performance venue's rent, rehearsal space rent, cast and crew wages. 


Can't donate $3,000.00? Don't worry!! Every dollar counts whether its 5 or 500


Other Ways You Can Help

PASS THIS ON!!! There is power in numbers and the more people that see this, the closer we will come to our goal! Anyone who loves theater, believes in new work or straight up loves an opinionated viewpoint can help! Forward away.

 dollar counts as we work towards making this shared vision
a reality. The Indiegogo goal is three quarters of the overall budget and 
we will
use the money as a portion of our performance venue's rent, rehearsal space rent, cast and crew wages. 

Can't donate $3,000.00? Don't
worry!! Every dollar counts whether its 5 or 500



Other Ways You Can Help
PASS THIS ON!!! There is power in
numbers and the more people that see this, the closer we will come to our goal!
Anyone who loves theater, believes in new work or straight up loves an
opinionated viewpoint can help! Forward away.

story:
A Message from No.11 Productions' Co-Artistic Directors Ryan Emmons & Julie Congress

We are thrilled to be presenting our original, interactive musical comedy Quest for the West: Adventures on the Oregon Trail! in the New York International Fringe Festival this August! This is our most ambitious production to date and we need your help to make this show the best it can be! Your tax-deductible donation will provide rehearsal space, materials for set, costumes and props, cover the festival participation fee and publicity costs and, most significantly, provide stipends for our incredibly talented, creative and devoted cast and crew!

We have been developing and workshopping Quest for the West: Adventures on the Oregon Trail! since December of 2010. The musical had its world premiere in the FRIGID New York festival and then went on to productions at the Kentucky Reperatory Theatre, the Capital Fringe Festival and the SaratogaArtsFest. Now, after over a year and a half of developing and refining, we are ready to bring this new and improved version back to NYC!

Quest for the West embodies the mission of No.11 Productions – it highlights the strength of the human spirit and the importance of hope.  We hope this musical brings laughter and a sense of play to everyone who comes to see it as well as the courage to face the unknown, take risks and pursue their dreams.  

Our Goal

We are aiming to raise $5,500 through this campaign. Here’s what your tax-deductible donation will cover:

$2,225 Stipends for cast and crew
$1,300 Publicity
$675 Rehearsal space
$250 Set (materials and fireproofing)
$100 Props
$200 Costumes
$750 FringeNYC participation fee

Anything we raise above our goal of $5,500 will go directly to the cast and crew as additional stipends!

About the Show

1848. Oregon fever has swept the fledgling nation. Jebediah and his wagon party embark on a 2,000-mile journey West.  On the trail, the party encounters rivers (how will they cross? You decide…it’s interactive!), animals to hunt (“get out your balls, it’s time to go hunting”), prickly pear cacti (help them jump over these dangerous succulents!) and the ever present danger of dwindling water rations…and dysentery!  Along their quest, the pioneers’ journey is filled with more than dirt trails.  Romance develops; deep secrets & betrayals are revealed; and Jebediah’s darkness gets…darker.  

This 90-minute musical comedy is a scored interactive game for the audience which works together as a team to determine the events that occur.  Play well and you may just make it onto the Top 10 Score Board!  2,000 miles.  90 minutes. 11 songs.  8 games.  6 characters.

Presented as part of the New York International Fringe Festival. For more info visit www.no11productions.com.

Sat. 8/11 @ 7:00pm
Fri. 8/17 @ 5:30pm
Fri. 8/17 @ 10:30pm
Tues. 8/21 @ 2:00pm
Sat. 8/25 @ 7:00pm

Venue #3 - Theatre 80 St. Marks Place
80 St. Marks Place, NYC 10003

Past Praise for the Show

"In all honesty, this is one of the cleverest new musicals that I have seen in years!" - Lauren Honeycutt, MD Theatre Guide

"Musical hilarity" - J. Jordan, nytheatre.com

"Teaches the lesson that if we persevere, the experiences of our journey will help mold us into the people we want to be." - Stephen Tortora-Lee, The Happiest Medium

The Team

Book by Julie Congress, Ryan Emmons, Zachary Fithian and Jen Neads
Music and Lyrics by Rebecca Greenstein and Danny Tieger

Directed by Ryan Emmons

Musically Directed and Arranged by Enrico de Trizio
Choreographed by Kyle Mullins
Incidental Music by Steve Goodwin
Set and Lighting Design by Ryan Hauenstein
Visual Art by Jen Neads
Costumes by Julie Congress
Stage Managed by Lauren Byrd
Publicist: Paul Siebold, Off Off PR
Associate Producer: Stacey Weingarten
ACR: Sarah Congress

Featuring: John Bambery, Julie Congress, Steven Conroy, Haley Greenstein, Scott Raymond Johnson and Maxwell Schneller

No.11 Productions

No.11 Productions is a non-profit 501(c)3 theatre company committed to revealing the strength of the human spirit and the importance of hope.  Founded in 2008 by graduates of Skidmore College, No.11 has had productions in The New York International Fringe Festival, FRIGID New York, the Band of Puppets Festival, the Capital Fringe Festival and the Saratoga ArtsFest. The company received a grant from the Puffin Foundation in 2010 for a community production of Aristophanes’ Assemblywomen. No.11’s Quest for the West: Adventures on the Oregon Trail!, MythUnderstood and A Christmas Carol were guest productions at the Kentucky Repertory Theatre in 2011.  For more information, visit www.no11productions.com.

The No.11 Ensemble is Julie Congress (Co-Artistic Director), Steven Conroy, Maura Cordial, Ryan Emmons (Co-Artistic Director), Haley Greenstein, Jen Neads, Maxwell Schneller, Danny Tieger and Enrico de Trizio.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share the link to this campaign with your friends
  • Come see Quest for the West in August
  • Tweet about us (@no11productions)
  • Like our page on facebook (No.11 Productions)
  • Join our email list (http://no11productions.weebly.com/contact.html)

story:
A quick overview

We are Rust Co-Operative, an independent Cape Town-based theatre company. One of our productions, The View, has been selected for the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival. We are raising funds to get the writer/director, designer/stage manager, and two actors to Dublin!

Recently nominated for 3 prestigious Fleur Du Cap Awards - Best Actor, Best Supporting Actress and Best New Director.

 

Who we are

We are Rust Co-Operative, a Cape Town-based independent theatre company. Penny Youngleson and Philip Rademeyer founded Rust Co-Operative at the beginning of 2012 in order to create a playspace for young theatre-makers wishing to create new South African theatre works. 

Philip (27 years old) completed his undergrad in the States and returned to Cape Town to complete his Honours and Masters (in Directing), with a focus on queer theory, at University of Cape Town (UCT). He currently teaches part-time in the UCT Drama Department.

Penny (26 years old) did her undergrad and Honours at University of Stellenbosch and went on to do her Masters at UCT (in Theatre-Making). Outside of Rust Co-Operative, she freelances in set and costume design and construction and styling. She also teaches drama and creative writing.

 

About our name 

A co-operative runs on the model of an autonomous group of people who cooperate for their mutual, social, economic, and cultural benefit. We wanted to start a co-operative so that we could collaborate with like-minded artists and help contribute towards building momentum and synergy in the local scene. 


We called it the 'Rust' co-operative because we believe in the value and beauty of things that have got a story to tell. There's not a lot of narrative in perfection; but something or someone that's lived a bit and been weathered by life often has a distressed attraction. We like stories and perspectives of people on the outside or on the edge of groups: the people who don't fit easily into spaces and categories. These are our rusty people.

 

Our project  

One of our shows, The View, has been selected to be part of the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, in May 2013. After sell-out audiences and a very positive critical and public response to the first season last year, we were accepted into the Festival and are proud to represent South Africa on the international stage. 

 

Our campaign

This project aims to raise funds for our co-operative to travel to Dublin in May. The festival has been very generous in waiving participation, technical and venue fees. However, that means we need to raise a substantial amount of money to get to Dublin, have accommodation and subsistence allowances. We are not raising funds for salaries for any members of the co-operative. All money raised will go directly towards performing the show in Dublin, and spreading what we think is a worthwhile message.

 

About the play & its message

In The View, a young man sits alone in a cell at an undisclosed location, looking down at a ruined earth and dreaming of being rescued. A gatekeeper arrives with his final request: a video containing interviews with various people from his life. Through a series of conversations between the boy and these people (including family members, historical figures and characters from his imagination) The View illuminates the boy’s life and relationships, and also reveals the reason for his incarceration. The View deals with notions of loss, grief, memory and hope. The Dublin show will feature Ella Gabriel & Roelof Storm. Written and directed by Philip Rademeyer and designed by Penelope Youngleson.

The play was inspired by an American pastor’s recent comments that gays and lesbians should be contained in isolated enclosures and ultimately become extinct as they will not be able to reproduce. Such comments can be seen as far-fetched, but it is reminiscent of the Holocaust and, a bit closer to home for us, apartheid. In our African context, such threats also take on greater meaning as queer lives seem to be continuously under assault on our continent. In the majority of African countries homosexuality is still illegal, it is punishable by death in some, and even though South Africa offers constitutional protection for queers, many gays and lesbians still suffer. This play explores a world where homophobic rhetoric is institutionalised, and thus offers a picture of a scary future for queers unless we continue fighting for equality.

 

How you can help 

The money we are trying to raise here will go towards making our performance in Dublin possible. We are requesting the following (for 4 people):

$3636 for return flights from Cape Town to Dublin

$1750 for accommodation (for 4 people for 11 days)

$1250 for food and public transport (for 4 people for 11 days) 

$454 for travel insurance

$250 to insure the show

$7340 TOTAL

 

If we don't reach the full goal, we will take out personal loans to fund this project. We believe in the importance of a show such as this, and we'll go to any lengths to make it happen, even if that means accruing personal loans that we have to pay off over a number of years! 

Any help will be greatly appreciated!

story:
Who We Are: People on a Stage

People on a Stage is a performance ensemble gathered by Artistic Director Alexa J. Rittichier in September 2012 as she began her thesis work at Columbia College Chicago. The ensemble is made up of Lydia Feuerhelm, Jenny Garnett, Emily Rose, Courtney St.Clair, Michael Chad St. John, and Don Widmer. The performers come from various movement and artistic backgrounds. Primarily interested in how experience accumulates in the body, People on a Stage makes interdisciplinary performance work grown from the experience of being together as a collective through time. The process of making performance work each week is a form of artistic cross-training with a physical activity: examples include acroyoga, rock climbing, Butoh, modern dance, and cardio weight lifting.   

The ensemble has dedicated itself to nine months of working together to develop their debut performance Collecting Ourselves: Bone Stacking. The commitment to participate in a collective creative practice encourages participants to think about otherness or to think about the self in relationship to others. It is a social revolution. It is a spiritual discipline

What We Are Doing: Performing

Our performance Collecting Ourselves: Bone Stacking has been accepted to be performed at PSi19: Now Then: Performance and Temporality! (https://psi19.stanford.edu)

Collecting Ourselves is a collaborative creative process, a performance and a book. It is a frontier in thinking and acting. Collecting Ourselves addresses our cultural obsession with individualism and fosters a collective cooperative lifestyle that builds harmony and addresses creativity as a group process. The artist book that accompanies the performance is a compilation of the writing and imagery produced by the group.  This document is a concrete representation of the ephemeral time and space spent together in the rehearsal and performance. 

The Performance Studies International Conference 19 will be held June 26-30, 2013, at Stanford University in Stanford, California (early registration ends March 31). This is an amazing opportunity and honor for us to not only attend the conference but present as well. As we are based in Chicago, Illinois, the journey for us will not be inexpensive. As recent graduates and current students of Columbia College Chicago, we are in need!

People on a Stage is fully invested in this project and has already given six months of time, energy, and money to this project. Each ensemble member has donated rehearsal time to this project without compensation and Alexa has put her own money into workshops, costumes, props, and media elements for this project.

What We Need: Travel Funds

To be able to attend PSi19 in June, we need to raise travel and registration funds for the ensemble. We estimate it will cost us a total of $7200 for the seven ensemble members to attend the conference.

Budget Breakdown:

  • Flights: $425 x 7 ensemble members= $2975
  • Food: $125 x 7 ensemble members= $875
  • Early Registration: $200 x 7 ensemble members= $1400
  • Van Rental= $550
  • Lodging= $1400
  • Plus extra to cover Indiegogo's fees

Total Proposed Budget= $7500

We believe this conference is extremely important for us to attend and will use all funds we raise to get us to California. If we don’t raise the full amount through this campaign, we will pursue other fundraising options to be able to travel to the conference.

Why We Are Doing It: The Impact

The opportunity to present our project is not only amazing for us, but we see this work as challenging and important to others as well.

There are cultural, political and social implications for working the way we do.  It is a resistance to the disembodied communications of texting, facebook, twitter and electronic communication, yet it does not deny their usefulness in our culture. By integrating live-ness and remote-ness seamlessly, we become an example of the infinite creative potential of ensemble.  We believe the active embodied practice of our ensemble is hope for our sustained progress.

Other Ways You Can Help

So you can’t contribute monetarily? That doesn’t mean you can’t help!

• Spread the word! We need help spreading the word and making some noise about this campaign. Tell your friends! Tell your family! Shout it from the rooftops... or your facebook page! (For your convenience, you can like use the Indiegogo share tools!) 

• Come see us perform! Collecting Ourselves: Bone Stacking will debut at Columbia College Chicago on April 26 and 27. More info at www.alexajrittichier.com/CollectingOurselves

story:
Suppose you had nightmares, terrible nightmares, every night, night after night.
Exhausted and distraught, where could you turn for rest, for relief, for release?
Suppose there were someone who could lie by your side and dream your nightmare for you, so you could have sweet dreams and deep sleep.

That someone is the Nightmare Dreamer.

 Tattooed Potato are bringing to London this original work of theatre, which premiered last year in Washington, DC.  Our team of fifteen -- actors, designers, production interns and director -- are giving their time and talent; the Blue Elephant Theatre is giving us rehearsal space and a three-week run; and the Royal Victoria Hall Foundation have given us a grant to get started with.  And with a little bit more financial support, we can bring this dream vision into the waking world.


  All funds raised online go directly into the show in the form of:

-- Costumes: Our seven actors play 37 characters!  Making each one slightly different is a huge job.

-- Set-building: We are planning to transform the Blue Elephant Theatre into a vast tent of bedsheets and fort of cushions, a comfortable and safe place to be told a dark and disturbing tale.

-- Prop-making: We have ambitious plans to build from scratch a bed can become anything a sleeper can dream.  We don't want to give away too much about how it will turn and open and unfold, shrink and expand, but suffice it to say that if we have the resrouces to lift it off the drawing board and build it, it will be the stuff of dreams.


  We would love to have your support -- at right, you'll see our scheme to say Thank you with public recognition, artwork by the ensemble, and mementos from the show.  Our most generous donors will be paired with one of the actors, who will give them the inside story through rehearsals and the run of the show, and an Angel donor just might find the Nightmare Dreamer himself knocking at the door, bearing the promise of a night's deep sleep.

  If you're unable to make a financial donation, there are other ways you can support The Nightmare Dreamer.

-- We would love for you to see the show!  Tickets are available at http://www.blueelephanttheatre.co.uk/nightmare-dreamer

-- We would love for you to join us for Nightmare Dreaming, our benefit cabaret and dream bazaar on 16 May!  Pay-what-you-wish tickets are available at http://thenightmaredreamer.eventbrite.co.uk/

-- We would love for you to stay in touch and follow our progress! Visit us at https://www.facebook.com/TattooedPotato and like our page to receive news and announcements!

 Tattooed Potato are bringing to London this original work of theatre, which premiered last year in Washington, DC.  Our team of fifteen -- actors, designers, production interns and director -- are giving their time and talent; the Blue Elephant Theatre is giving us rehearsal space and a three-week run; and the Royal Victoria Hall Foundation have given us a grant to get started with.  And with a little bit more financial support, we can bring this dream vision into the waking world.
  All funds raised online go directly into the show in the form of:
-- Costumes: Our seven actors play 37 characters!  Making each one slightly different is a huge job.
-- Set-building: We are planning to transform the Blue Elephant Theatre into a vast tent of bedsheets and fort of cushions, a comfortable and safe place to be told a dark and disturbing tale.
-- Prop-making: We have ambitious plans to build from scratch a bed can become anything a sleeper can dream.  We don't want to give away too much about how it will turn and open and unfold, shrink and expand, but suffice it to say that if we have the resrouces to lift it off the drawing board and build it, it will be the stuff of dreams.
  We would love to have your support -- at right, you'll see our scheme to say Thank you with public recognition, artwork by the ensemble, and mementos from the show.  Our most generous donors will be paired with one of the actors, who will give them the inside story through rehearsals and the run of the show, and an Angel donor just might find the Nightmare Dreamer himself knocking at the door, bearing the promise of a night's deep sleep.
  If you're unable to make a financial donation, there are other ways you can support The Nightmare Dreamer.
-- We would love for you to see the show!  Tickets are available at http://www.blueelephanttheatre.co.uk/nightmare-dreamer
-- We would love for you to join us for Nightmare Dreaming, our benefit cabaret and dream bazaar on 16 May!  Pay-what-you-wish tickets are available at http://thenightmaredreamer.eventbrite.co.uk/
-- We would love for you to stay in touch and follow our progress! Visit us at https://www.facebook.com/TattooedPotato and like our page to receive news and announcements!

story:
YOU DID IT!!! Thank you so much to everyone who supported this campaign.  We've reached our goal and fully funded this project.  AMAZING!!!


HOWEVER... IT'S NOT OVER YET!  There's still time to make a contribution and support the continued development of Dry Bones: Resurrection of the Living.  There's so much in store for this project and we want YOU to be a part of it!

 

Sydney Schiff Dance Project redefines how we see ancient text-based spirituality in the context of 21st century life.  My newest work, Dry Bones: Resurrection of the Living, is my most ambitious project to date as an independent choreographer in New York City.  The piece follows the personal journeys of three 21st century women striving to take ownership of inherited traditions.  By exploring text study and storytelling in the Jewish tradition, it is my hope that Dry Bones will spark dialogue among all people, no matter their religious or secular affiliations. 

Over the next year, it is my goal to develop Dry Bones into an evening length work.  An excerpt of the piece will preview at the Drisha Arts Fellowship Exhibition on June 13th.  Your support will set the stage for this dialogue.

Become a fan on Facebook and follow SSDP on Twitter to receive exclusive updates and sneak peeks into the rehearsal process.

Thank you for your support!

Sydney Schiff Dance Project

story:
Ever seen a happier smile than that? 

I bet not. But smiles like Ginger's are what Orange Community Players  have been bringing to our county and the wider Triangle and Triad areas since 2006 -- smiles...and laughter...and tears...and practically every other human emotion you can imagine. Joy is what OCP is about, joy among our volunteer actors, actresses, and crew members; and joy for the thousands who have been our audiences. 

We invite you to join us in what we do. A tax-deductible gift to OCP any time in the next 60 days (though if you do it before December 31st you get a 2013 deduction) will make you a partner in advancing our mission and accomplishing the objectives we have in 2014, including a dinner-theater production of the incredibly funny Steel Magnolias at the Orange County Senior Center auditorium in mid-February, our annual summer musical at Orange High School in July, and for the first time since we began nearly 10 years ago, an expanded season with a 3rd show next fall..

Or, have you ever wondered if the way we do "community theater" makes a difference?

Listen to what the mother of one of our summer musical "regulars" had to say recently:

"As a parent of a child with a disability who has spent her past three summers participating in OCP productions, I can honestly say that it is by far the most powerful experience my daughter has had in terms of growth in confidence, self-acceptance, and knowledge of music and theater. I am amazed at how people of different abilities, cultures, and political beliefs come together time after time and work as a team toward a common goal." 

Yes, indeed, OCP does make a difference!

BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP!

*********************

Now, before you get all grumpy...

              

...or go POP!

Let us explain why: 

The fact is...up until now we've been able to pay the bills (for rehearsal and performance space rental, royalties and fees, props, costumes, set construction and the like) from the proceeds from ticket sales (and, fortunately, our audiences have been wonderful) and generous grants from the Hillsborough Tourism Board.

But each year the costs have gone up, and we believe you want us to continue to grow in what we give to the Orange County community by way of excellent amateur theater. 

So...this year, with

                               

                                

last winter and...

                                        

                                                 

this summer, 

our annual budget is $16,530. Next year, with three shows it will be $19,925.

Thus, we, i.e., our participants, audiences, and the arts in Orange County generally, now need our financial help. A gift of $500, $250, $100 (or whatever you can afford) to Orange Community Players will keep the smiles coming...and make them even bigger.

Making your gift is easy to do. Just punch the "Contribute" button, and follow the instructions. And remember: If you make your gift before the end of the year, you get a 2013 tax deduction.

Thanks for your partnership. Come see us. Even better, come join us, and add your smile to all the rest.

story:
Who the heck am I?

I am an 82-year-old solo performer and writer telling my story about the life of a feminist before feminism was really a thing. I never thought of myself as a feminist, but everyone who sees my show says it’s about feminism. I was born during the depression. I trained to become a Registered Nurse, have a BA in Psychology, went on to accomplish further educational goals, gaining a BS in Social Work, and an MA in rehabilitation counseling. Specializing in mental health, addiction, family therapy and AIDS, I received a Certificate of Appreciation from the AIDS Coalition of the Merrimack Valley in 1989 for “outstanding work on behalf of people with AIDS and helping to spread the message of hope, caring and compassion.” I retired from nursing in 2006. 

My feminist rumblings came from making conscious decisions in my own interest instead of placating my husband. It started with my desire to have an abortion. I found myself pregnant with my fifth child because my request to have my tubes tied needed to be approved by my husband – who didn’t find the procedure necessary. Next I decided to go back to school to get my MA in rehabilitation counseling, and figured that it was time to finalize my divorce.

Why would I want to do this?

Performing makes me glow, and this story is worth hearing. In addition to being a cathartic experience for me, the issues addressed in my show are still hotly debated today in our highest courts; women's right to have contraception information and accessibility, abortion, divorce laws and equal pay for women. My historical and personal perspective is valuable and relevant now more than ever.

What I need and what you get?

I've hired a professional film-maker to produce and edit this show so I can pass on my part in the history of all women, to show how one woman dealt with the many choices in her life gaining strength in a male-dominated society. The costs of producing a video can add up, and my own limited funding (remember, fixed-income octogenarian) is already tied up in paying for technical help and theater rental.

If you do contribute you’ll be acknowledged on Facebook for sure. If you donate more, you’ll also get a pair of tickets. And if you can donate more than that, I’ll send you your own personal copy of the DVD for Cheesecake and Demerol.

I ask only what you can afford. If you can’t give money, I totally understand and only ask you to do whatever you can to spread the word.

Thank you so much,

Gene Gore

story:
The Akh'tamar Dance Ensemble is a group of over 80 beautiful, young Armenian girls and boys between the ages of 6 and 25, who over the past twenty years have raised their dance skills to new heights. The Ensemble is divided into two age groups: the younger girls and boys range from age 6 through 11, and the older dancers range from age 12 to 25. 

2015 marks the centennial of the Armenian Genocide.  The Akh'tamar  Dance Ensemble has been invited to perform in the summer of 2015 at various venues and cultural events throughout Armenia. To make this very momentous trip a reality, the Akh'tamar Dance Ensemble needs your support. Funds need be raised to defray  the cost of the trip that is a once in a lifetime opportunity - to dance in the Motherland on the 100th Anniversary of the Armenian Genocide.  

The dancers work hard at weekly rehearsals while taking part in their culture. They form lasting friendships while learning the art of Armenian dance. New choreography is being taught, costumes are being sewn by a team of seamstresses, music is being composed - all in preparation and anticipation for this historic occasion!

Please consider making a contribution. No amount is too small (or too large!). Share our campaign with your friends, family and colleagues.  We thank you in advance for your contribution from the bottom of our hearts! 

(Please visit the gallery on the following page to see pictures from our shows.)

story:
Click on each perk title to see the details!

This Season:

Fresh off another sold-out season, Shakespeare BASH’d returns with our best season yet. This year we tackle three of the most tantalizing, passionate, fun, and dark plays of the Elizabethan/Jacobean period. 

First, we will be continuing our exploration of Shakespeare’s contemporaries with a staged reading of one of period’s most notorious playwrights, John Webster, and his tragedy The Duchess of Malfi. This play has literally everything, including: poisoned bibles, fake cadavers, and werewolves!

Next, the company will be taking on one of Shakespeare’s most iconic tragedies: Othello, Shakespeare’s exploration into love, marriage, sacrifice, race, jealousy, among many modern ideas. It is his deepest examination of domestic life and tragedy. Truly, it is one of Shakespeare’s most challenging and significant plays. 

Finally, Shakespeare BASH’d tackles As You Like It, Shakespeare’s comedy of love, wit, and transformation. We’ll be immersing ourselves in the wide, strange world of the Forest of Arden, with all its fantastic portrayals of shepherds and courtiers in love. 

This coming season, Shakespeare BASH’d continues the intense study of Shakespeare through a modern lense and the wonderful worlds he creates that are still relevant today. Our season will bring to light the very true idea that “All the World’s a Stage.” 
 

How You Can Help:

The truth of the matter is that theatre requires a great deal of money. We at Shakespeare BASH’d are committed to giving the entirety of our box office revenue to the artists that work with us. 

Our goal is to raise money to pay for preliminary costs for the productions this season. We aim to keep costs low, work hard to make our shows simple, and try to allow no waste of time or money into our work. 

Our goals include a hard-working company, great text, and a fantastic night for all at a great Toronto bar! Every dollar donated goes a long way to helping make this possible.
 

The Impact

Any amount of money to this fundraising campaign will go to a number of very important aspects of putting on a play. We need to pay for our venues, rehearsal space, costumes, props, printing of scripts, transportation, photography, promotion/marketing, etc.

Though we keep our costs low, there are a number of different expenses incurred by producing a play. Any amount of money helps us to properly budget our season in a way that prioritizes the experience of our audience and artists.

We are so fortunate to have the privilege to produce theatre in Toronto. We hope that you will support us in any way you can to continue our wonderful company’s tradition of amazing Shakespeare in great bars across the city.

About the Company:

A "Bash" is a crushing blow. It can be about making an attempt, going at it all your own. It can also be a wild night.

Shakespeare BASH’d is an independent theatre company dedicated to the works of William Shakespeare and his contemporaries. Our desire is to present Shakespeare’s plays with a bare bones approach to staging, focusing on the words telling the stories of the plays, and with an emphasis on great acting and company spirit.

We have been producing plays for the last 8 years in Toronto bars across the city, including such well-known bars as the Victory Cafe, the Monarch Tavern, and Junction City Music Hall. For five straight years, we were featured at the Toronto Fringe Festival with sold-out productions, garnering numerous NOW Magazine Best Production and Ensemble notices, and in 2012 we were named Best of Fringe.

During our regular seasons, we have also presented sold-out productions of many of Shakespeare’s most famous plays including: Twelfth Night, Hamlet, Macbeth, Romeo and Juliet, Richard III, and King John.

Finally, in 2015 we made a commitment to present staged readings of plays by Shakespeare's most important contemporaries. To this date, we have produced staged readings of Christopher Marlowe’s Edward II, Thomas Middleton and William Rowley’s The Changeling, the first true Elizabethan verse tragedy Gorboduc, and last year’s huge success of Ben Jonson’s Volpone or The Fox.

Shakespeare BASH’d is insatiably focused on presenting the plays of the Elizabethan and Jacobean period with truth, fun, grace, passion, and honesty.

Other Ways You Can Help

For a company our size, every dollar has a huge impact. But we know that not everyone can make a donation. Help us in other ways by spreading the word on social media, and encouranging your friends and family to make a donation and/or check out a show

story:
The Cinema Theater has been a neighborhood institution since it opened in 1914. By the late 1920's as many as two dozen movie houses served the city neighborhoods of Rochester. With the advent of television and the rise of suburban multiplexes, The Cinema is now Rochester's last neighborhood movie theater.


Over the years, The Cinema has survived to see great renovation projects. The wooden benches and dirt floor of the original 'flea pit' gave way to the Art-Deco makeover in 1949 by Jo-Mor Theaters. In 1985, Jo Ann Morreales rescued The Cinema from the verge of closing and modernized extensively, including innovations like the digital marquee.


We are committed to staying open no matter what it takes. The one change we must make to stay open is the purchase of a digital projector. By early 2014, film prints will no longer be available. The cost of this projector is approximately $70,000. We don't expect our patrons to contribute every penny of this, but every donation from the community brings us closer to our goal.


Please, support your neighborhood movie house! Save The Cinema Theater! Make its 100th birthday the greatest yet!


Check out the great perks your generosity will bring!

story:
Our Show:

Ravishing Medusa unearths the oft-forgotten myth of how Medusa became the hideous Gorgon she is remembered as.
A young resident of the Temple of Athena, Medusa gets caught within a conflict of the gods, where an unpunished crime forever alters her fate.

Featuring performances by Samantha Bergman, Marisa Brau, Holland Hamilton, Alexis Kelley, and Molly O'Keefe.

A world premiere by Rachel Graf Evans, Ravishing Medusa is a narrative combining text, dance and music that contextualizes patriarchy and sexual violence within the birth of Western folklore, and is being produced by Theater For The New City’s Dream Up Festival.

Come join us in making this show a reality!

What We Need:

  • $1300 will be going to the festival fee, Indiegogo's cut, rehearsal space, and marketing materials. 
  • $650 will be going to stipends to help support our actors and designers.
  • $600 will be going to our design budget (set pieces, costumes, make-up, clerical materials, load-in, etcetera)

What You Get:

You’ll be an integral investor in the early life of a dynamic piece of theater. Your support will enable a team of emerging artists to put forward strong work with important themes. We've also concocted some great perks in order to thank you for your support!

Our Artistic Production Team: 

Rachel Graf Evans (Playwright and Co-Producer) is a feminist writer and theatre artist most interested in the telling of forgotten and silenced stories. Her pieces have been workshopped and produced in New York by the Fresh Fruit Festival, Pencil Productions, and Mots de Changer. She has also worked in various capacities with the York Theater Company, New Georges, Early Stages, Tortoise Shell Productions, and Propstar! She has performed in a myriad of cabarets and is in the process of self-producing an original album. Learn more at rachelgrafevans.com

Blaze Ferrer (Director, Choreographer and Co-Producer) is a Brooklyn-based performance maker. He has directed and choreographed pieces for AUNTS, Exquisite Corpse Company, Fresh Ground Pepper, and Pencil Productions.  He has stage managed and assisted on projects with Target Margin Theater, New Dramatists, iRT Theater, NYCFringe (Peter Grosz’s Recipe For Success!: Featuring Chef Michael Denardi), The New Group, and the Oberlin Summer Theater Festival. Blaze has also performed in projects such as We Were Wild Once (Built For Collapse at Dixon Place, dirs. Sanaz Ghajarrahimi and Ben Mann, chor. Ben Hobbs), The Motherfucker With The Hat (Cape May Stage Danger! series, dir. Ben Ferber) A Midsummer Night's Dream (OSTF, dir. Paul Moser), The Cradle Will Rock (OSTF, dir. Joey Rizzolo) The Dickening (2011 Midtown International Theater Festival, dir. Ben Ferber), King Lear (Ovalhouse Theater, dir. Ian Wooldrige) and Intimate Apparel (Oberlin Mainstage, dir. Caroline Jackson-Smith). See more at blazeferrer.com.

Ben Ferber (Dramaturg, Sound Designer and Co-Producer) focuses on new play development. Producing credits include The Dickening at the the Midtown International Theatre Festival, The Little Festival of the Unexpected at Portland Stage Company, and the upcoming Not Afraid with PowerOut Productions. His dramaturgy credits include Outcasts by Scott Barrow, a member of the Tectonic Theater Project, at the Martha’s Vineyard Playhouse. In New York: The Closing Shift with Pencil Productions; and the original studio retreat of Love Kills at the Lark. At Portland Stage Company: Hidden Tennessee, a PEER Award Winning compilation of Tennessee Williams’s plays, poetry, and history; LOVE/SICK by John Cariani; Hitomi by Jeremy Tiang; a partial retranslation of God of Carnage by Yasmina Reza; and Stop the Train for the Young Writers’ Project. He was the dramaturg for all six of Cape May Stage’s mainstage shows of the 2013 season, and co-curated, dramaturged, and directed their Danger! reading series. Ben has sound designed for numerous productions in New York, at Portland Stage Company, and at Cape May Stage, and designs most projects he directs. Ben is also an active playwright, a former Artistic Assistant of Manhattan Theatre Club, and will be assisting Mandy Greenfield, the Artistic Director of the Williamstown Theatre Festival, for the 2014-2015 season.

Abigail Barr (Assistant Director) is a rising senior at Oberlin College (Theater Major, Directing focus) and current Artistic Intern at Primary Stages.  Credits include directing Circle Mirror Transformation by Annie Baker, Central Park West by Woody Allen, 8 by Dustin Lance Black at Oberlin and assistant directing The Tennessee Williams Project with Bedlam Ensemble. She can be also be found in various production roles and managing the Theater and Dance publicity office at school. She is a former intern of Atlantic Theater Company and New York Theatre Workshop.

About Theater For The New City and The Dream Up Festival:

Theater for the New City (TNC) is a venue for new artists and playwrights. TNC is unique in its commitment to both high artistic standards and community service. As the cultural hub of its downtown New York City location, TNC develops new artists and inspires future audiences.

The Dream Up Festival presents new works by various artists, and is an incredible opportunity for emerging artists to produce new work. Conveniently located in the East Village, Theater For The New City is an accessible and affordable festival for New York audiences.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you’re located in the New York area, please come out to see us in August and check out our show! Most importantly, we want to share this piece of work with you. Some of our perks guarantee you a seat, so consider reserving early that way! Tickets can be found here:
http://bit.ly/1nqrebn

If you can’t donate money, please share or link this campaign to your friends via e-mail, facebook, twitter, or however you communicate with them. Any help forwarding this campaign along is deeply appreciated. 

Thanks for taking the time to read about our project! 
We can't wait to share this with you. 
-Rachel, Blaze, Ben and Abby
story_txt:
Our Show:

Ravishing
Medusa unearths the oft-forgotten myth of how Medusa
became the hideous Gorgon she is remembered as.A young resident of the Temple of Athena, Medusa
gets caught within a conflict of the gods, where an unpunished crime forever
alters her fate.Featuring performances by Samantha Bergman, Marisa Brau, Holland Hamilton, Alexis Kelley, and Molly O'Keefe.
A world premiere by Rachel Graf Evans, Ravishing Medusa is a narrative combining text, dance and music that contextualizes patriarchy and
sexual violence within the birth of Western folklore, and is being produced by
Theater For The New City’s Dream Up Festival. 
Come join us in making this show a reality!
What
We Need:

$1300
     will be going to the festival fee, Indiegogo's cut, rehearsal space, and marketing
     materials. 
$650
     will be going to stipends to help support our actors and designers.
$600
     will be going to our design budget (set pieces, costumes, make-up, clerical materials, load-in, etcetera)
What
You Get:
You’ll be an integral investor in the early life of a dynamic piece of theater. Your support will enable a team of emerging artists to put forward strong work with important themes. We've also concocted some great perks in order to thank you for your support!
Our
Artistic Production Team: 
Rachel
Graf Evans (Playwright and Co-Producer) is a feminist writer and theatre artist most interested in the telling
of forgotten and silenced stories. Her pieces have been workshopped and
produced in New York by the Fresh Fruit Festival, Pencil Productions, and
Mots de Changer. She has also worked in various capacities with the York
Theater Company, New Georges, Early Stages, Tortoise Shell Productions, and
Propstar! She has performed in a myriad of cabarets and is in the process of
self-producing an original album. Learn more at rachelgrafevans.com
Blaze Ferrer (Director, Choreographer and Co-Producer) is a Brooklyn-based performance
maker. He has directed and choreographed pieces for AUNTS, Exquisite Corpse
Company, Fresh Ground Pepper, and Pencil Productions.  He has stage
managed and assisted on projects with Target Margin Theater, New
Dramatists, iRT Theater, NYCFringe (Peter Grosz’s Recipe For Success!: Featuring Chef Michael Denardi), The New
Group, and the Oberlin Summer Theater Festival. Blaze has also
performed in projects such as We
Were Wild Once (Built For Collapse at Dixon Place, dirs.
Sanaz Ghajarrahimi and Ben Mann, chor. Ben Hobbs), The Motherfucker With The Hat (Cape
May Stage Danger! series, dir. Ben Ferber) A Midsummer Night's Dream (OSTF, dir. Paul Moser), The
Cradle Will Rock (OSTF, dir. Joey Rizzolo) The Dickening (2011 Midtown International Theater Festival,
dir. Ben Ferber), King Lear (Ovalhouse
Theater, dir. Ian Wooldrige) and Intimate Apparel (Oberlin
Mainstage, dir. Caroline Jackson-Smith). See more at blazeferrer.com.
Ben Ferber (Dramaturg, Sound Designer and Co-Producer) focuses on new play development. Producing credits include The Dickening at the the Midtown International Theatre Festival, The Little Festival of the Unexpected at Portland Stage Company, and the upcoming Not Afraid with PowerOut Productions. His dramaturgy credits include Outcasts by Scott Barrow, a member of the Tectonic Theater Project, at the Martha’s Vineyard Playhouse. In New York: The Closing Shift with Pencil Productions; and the original studio retreat of Love Kills at the Lark. At Portland Stage Company: Hidden Tennessee, a PEER Award Winning compilation of Tennessee Williams’s plays, poetry, and history; LOVE/SICK by John Cariani; Hitomi by Jeremy Tiang; a partial retranslation of God of Carnage by Yasmina Reza; and Stop the Train for the Young Writers’ Project. He was the dramaturg for all six of Cape May Stage’s mainstage shows of the 2013 season, and co-curated, dramaturged, and directed their Danger! reading series. Ben has sound designed for numerous productions in New York, at Portland Stage Company, and at Cape May Stage, and designs most projects he directs. Ben is also an active playwright, a former Artistic Assistant of Manhattan Theatre Club, and will be assisting Mandy Greenfield, the Artistic Director of the Williamstown Theatre Festival, for the 2014-2015 season.
Abigail Barr (Assistant Director) is a rising senior at Oberlin College (Theater Major, Directing focus) and current Artistic Intern at Primary Stages.  Credits include directing Circle Mirror Transformation by Annie Baker, Central Park West by Woody Allen, 8 by Dustin Lance Black at Oberlin and assistant directing The Tennessee Williams Project with Bedlam Ensemble. She can be also be found in various production roles and managing the Theater and Dance publicity office at school. She is a former intern of Atlantic Theater Company and New York Theatre Workshop.

About Theater For The New City and The Dream Up Festival:
Theater for the New City (TNC) is a venue for new
artists and playwrights. TNC is unique in its commitment to both high artistic standards
and community service. As the cultural hub of its downtown New York City
location, TNC develops new artists and inspires future audiences.
The Dream Up Festival presents new works by various
artists, and is an incredible opportunity for emerging artists to produce new
work. Conveniently located in the East Village, Theater For The New City is an accessible
and affordable festival for New York audiences. 
Other
Ways You Can Help:
If you’re located in the New York area, please come out to see us in August and check out our show! Most importantly, we want to share this piece of work with you. Some of our perks guarantee you a seat, so consider reserving early that way! Tickets can be found here:
http://bit.ly/1nqrebn
If you can’t donate money, please share or link this campaign to your friends via e-mail, facebook, twitter, or however you communicate with them. Any help forwarding this campaign along is deeply appreciated. 


Thanks for taking the time to read about our project! We can't wait to share this with you. 

-Rachel, Blaze, Ben and Abby

story:
THE HOUND

A solo, one-act play adapted from the classic, short horror story by H.P. Lovecraft.

Sometimes it's best to let a sleeping dog lie.

 

The Story

Midnight. Late December, 1937.  Reed, a discredited archeologist and aesthete, is running for his life. Having stolen an ancient amulet from the fetid grave of a neglected Holland churchyard, he locks himself in the library of his London townhouse in order to evade the pursuit of some 'malign being.'  In shocking detail, he recounts a gruesome testimony of unnatural occurrences surrounding the totem's theft...and the appalling consequences for all who come to possess it.

 

2019 Capital Fringe Festival

I'm really excited to bring this show to the 14th Annual Capital Fringe Festival in Washington, DC this July, but I need your help!  Every aspect of producing a high quality Fringe show like THE HOUND -- from the initial participation fee to insurance, renting rehearsal space, marketing,  props, costumes, stipends for our talented creative team & crew, set materials and transportation -- all costs money.

 

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to fund-raise $2,000 in the next 15 days to help cover these costs.  Please consider a donation and check out the perks available to you as a backer:

LOVECRAFTIAN ($10) - Our gratitude and a donation "Thank you" in our program.

GRAVE ROBBER ($25) - A donation "thank you" in our program + an 8.5x14, color e-poster (digital file).

FRIENDS OF ST. JOHN ($50) - A donation "Thank you" in our program + an 8.5x14 color poster (hard copy) mailed to your address within the continental United States.

MISKATONIC CLUB ($100) A donation "Thank you" in our program + 2 Complimentary Tickets to ANY CapFringe performance of THE HOUND, July 12-25. 

CULT OF LENG ($250) - A donation "Thank you" in our program + 2 Comp Tickets to ANY performance of THE HOUND, July 12-25  + 2 HOUND T-shirts (Sm, Med, Lg, XL, 2XL) available for pick-up at the Box Office or shipped to your address within the continental United States.

 

A Proven Track Record: The Critics Speak...

Review highlights from the 2016 Capital Fringe production of POE, TIMES TWO:

“Poe, Times Two sets a high bar for the remainder of Fringe 2016.  Greg Oliver Bodine has taken two very difficult but very Fringe-y types of theater, the horror genre and the solo performance form, and hit them both out of the ballpark."
–DC Theatre Scene, 5/5 Rating: “Pick of the Fringe”

“Bodine absolutely crushed the role of Alfred.  He showed Alfred’s sorrow, disgust, anger and the despair of a man on the eve of his execution with skill unparalleled.  I was floored by how astoundingly great his performance was.”
–DC Metro Theater Arts, 5 Stars: “Best Of The 2016 Capital Fringe”

Review highlights from the 2011 NYC production of THE HOUND:

“Deliciously creepy…a well-realized piece indeed.  Clever writing complemented by excellent sound and light make for a most entertaining evening”
--NYTheatre.com

“Riveting…[Bodine's] savviness in the art of adaptation is just as apparent as his acting abilities...any fan of H.P. Lovecraft’s works (or horror in general) shouldn’t miss this show...a unique evening of theater that is entertaining, educational and strangely unsettling.”
--Theatre Is Easy

“The most delightful thing we have ever seen anyone pull off on a stage, anywhere, ever, and if you are in New York you must go see it.  You must.  You REALLY MUST.”
--The Rejectionist

“The Hound is a smart and lively adaptation by a fantastic actor…deliciously macabre.”
--Tor.com

 

Our 2019 CapFringe Team

Greg Oliver Bodine (Writer / Performer / Producer) has performed in numerous productions of regional, stock and New York theatre.  His plays include A Requiem for Sherlock Holmes, Dark Soundings, Poe Times Two (three 2012 NYIT Award Nominations), Wicked Tavern Tales, I, Carpenter (published by Playscripts, Inc.), The Fatwā of Corspman Johnny Jones (2012 Semi-Finalist, Samuel French Off Off Broadway Short Play Festival), and adaptations of The Yellow Wallpaper by Charlotte Perkins Gilman, The Hound by H.P. Lovecraft, To Build a Fire by Jack London, Mary Shelley's Frankenstein, The Secret Sharer by Joseph Conrad, (Playscripts, Inc.) and Charles Dickens’ classic tale, A Christmas Carol — a solo, one-act play, (Playscripts, Inc.)  Greg is a graduate of Hobart College and the M.F.A. Drama Program at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.   Proud member of Actors' Equity Association, SAG-AFTRA and The Dramatists Guild.   www.gregoliverbodine.com

DeLisa M. White (Director / Sound Designer) received the 2014 New York Innovative Theatre Award (IT) for Outstanding Director for Vincent Marano’s Lights Narrow (IT noms: Best Production -Play, Best Full-Length Play). She has also directed: Retro Productions’ An Appeal to the Woman of the House (nom: Best Production - Play, Best Full-Length Play and Best Actress winner - Heather Cunningham); Greg Oliver Bodine’s multiple IT award nominee Poe, Times Two for the Capital Fringe Festival, Cape May Stage and Workshop Theater Company; Nat Cassidy in Ed Malin's Generic Magic Realism (IT nom: Best Solo Performance), and Mr. Cassidy in the IT Award-winning Things at the Doorstep.

Laura Schlachtmeyer (Production Stage Manager) has worked from coast to coast, from Tony N'​ Tina's Wedding (Chicago) to Killing My Lobster sketch comedy (San Francisco) to the New York Neo-Futurists. Her translations of Woyzeck and Masse Mensch were produced at Manhattan Theatre Source. Laura serves on the Board of the Russian Chamber Chorus of New York and has produced several independent sci-fi feature films (stream them on Netflix and Amazon Prime!). Proud recipient of the New York Innovative Theatre Award for Outstanding Stage Manager.

Piper Phillips (Lighting Designer) Piper's FRINGE credits include: The Hound, An Evening with Lola Montez, American Tranquility, Shopworn.  REGIONAL: The Theatre Lab: The Hunchback of Notre Dame, Curtains, Alix in Wonderland, Newsies; TheatreMcLean: Lord of the Flies, Urinetown, 9 to 5, Volume of Smoke, The Children’s Hour.  B.F.A. Emerson College.

Jason McKittrick (Property Designer) is an artist and owner of CRYPTOCURIUM, a New Jersey-based maker of “Handmade Horrors”, ranging from Lovecraft to Slasher Flicks, Halloween to Cryptozoology.   You can check out his work at cryptocurium.com

Paula Hoza (Graphic Designer) has designed theatrical postcards, flyers, brochures and posters for shows by North Shore Theatre Productions since 2007, including: Poe, Times Two, A Christmas Carol, The Yellow Wallpaper, Dark Soundings and The Fatwā of Corspman Johnny Jones.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't make a donation, please get the word out and make some noise about our Indiegogo campaign!  Share it on Facebook, Twitter and other social media platforms, along with our 2019 Capital Fringe Video Teaser -- any and all help is so very much appreciated!
