We have set a goal of $10,000 for this campaign, but even that does not cover
all of the expenses weâ€™ll incur by opening day. Ticket sales will help
contribute to our bottom line once the play opens, but like most live theater
productions, theyâ€™ll only cover about 50 percent of our total cost. 
So, letâ€™s see how much we can raise above and beyond the $10,000 goal!
Donations of every amount are welcomed. No amount is too smallâ€”or too large!So why PRIVATE LIVES?

â€œDevastatingly funny.â€ â€œAn iridescent bubble of a play.â€ â€œSomething to go silly
over.â€ â€œAll but continuous laughter.â€
Those are just a few of the accolades heaped upon the original 1930 production
of PRIVATE LIVES, which follows the saga of perpetually dueling lovers Amanda
and Elyot, two divorcees who unwittingly book adjoining rooms while
honeymooning with their new spouses. They soon realize the folly of their new
marriages and impulsively flee together to , only to be caught days later by their
jilted spouses. 
This stylish, savvy and still-timely comedy is loaded with pointed barbs about
modern romance that anyone can relate to. 
Written in 1930, the original production of Private Lives starred NoÃ«l Coward,
Gertrude Lawrence, Adrianne Allen and Laurence Olivier. The play has been
revived many times on Broadway (including a memorable 1983 production that
starred Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton), and has been produced in theaters
throughout the world. 
Now, with your help, PRIVATE LIVES will be coming to GTC Burbank.Who is Table for Two Productions?

Table for Two Productions was founded by Stasha Surdyke and Christopher
Trela to create and host theatrical & culinary fundraising events
for arts organizations, as well as present professionally produced plays in
venues throughout. 
 
Christopher and Stasha co-write the Table for Two dining
column in the Newport Beach Independent, and they are the co-editors of Coastal
Food and Wine, a website devoted to covering epicurean experiences along the
coast of So Cal.
Nominated for a 2011 Women in Business Award from the Orange County Business
Journal, Stasha Surdyke is an Ovation nominated actress and vocalist who has
appeared in numerous commercials, films, television shows and theatrical
productions throughout ,
including a starring role in An Empty
Plate in the CafÃ© du Grand Boeuf at The Laguna Playhouse. 
 
A graduate of
University of Washingtonâ€™s School of Drama, she was one of eighteen students
accepted into the schoolâ€™s prestigious two-year Suzuki program and received her
BA in Drama and a minor in Communications from UW. Stasha is a proud member of
Actorâ€™s Equity and Screen Actors Guild.
In addition to her performing credits, Stasha oversees media relations and
other creative services for the boutique PR agency, ArtsPR. Stasha designed the
award-winning press kit for Laguna Playhouseâ€™s production of The :
Can You Be More Pacific? which won the 2011 PROTOS Award of Excellence
this year. 
 
She is a member of the Southern California Restaurant Writers
Association, Orange County Press Club, and the NoÃ«l Coward Society.
Twice nominated for Entrepreneur of the Year by the Orange County Business
Journal, Christopher Trela is the owner and president of ArtsPR, a boutique PR
agency that specializes in public relations services for arts organizations.
Current clients include The Laguna Playhouse, Irvine Barclay Theatre, Long
Beach Symphony Orchestra, Festival Ballet Theatre, Chance Theater, The Queenâ€™s
Gallery/MUZEO, Costa Mesa Playhouse, Young Singers of OC, and Classical Mystery
Tour (a Beatles tribute band that performs with orchestras around the world). 
He is also the founder of New Voices Playwrights Workshop, and has written
plays that have been produced at venues throughout , , and .

 
Christopher is President of the Orange County Press Club, serves as an Arts
Commissioner for the City of , and
is an Adjunct Professor of Public Relations at .
Christopher is a member of the Public Relations Society of America.
Stasha and Christopher thank you for your support! 
For more information on Table for Two Productions and PRIVATE LIVES, visit our
website: www.Table4Two-PrivateLives.com.

story:
Our Story - 

The Acrobatic Conundrum is a Seattle based contemporary circus company that was founded in 2012 by Terry Crane and Joselynn Engstrom. The company is dedicated to creating sustainable performance experiences that engage and delight audiences and performers alike. The company has produced three shows to date.  The most recent show, 'The Way Out', headlined the first Chicago Contemporary Circus Festival this past January (thanks to indiegogo supporters!).  In March of 2014, Joselynn and Terry amicably parted ways as co-founders. This creation is the first under the sole directorship of Terry Crane. 

Our Project - 

The Acrobatic Conundrum returns fresh to the studio to explore new possibilities and combine the techniques of circus with the language of dance, in an all new contemporary circus show. The show will feature six established artists (Terry Crane, Erica Rubinstein, Carey Cramer, Ty Vennewitz, Jacki Ward, and Nicolo Kehrwald) newly allied together for this creation.  Under the artistic direction of seasoned dancer/choreographer, KT Niehoff, the work has already begun to take shape.

The show will debut at host and sponsor location: SANCA, the School of Acrobatics & New Circus Arts in Seattle, August 15, 16 & 17.  We would love to see our supporters there! 

Project 2014 will then fly to New York City to take part in Summerstage, a seasonal series of performances presented by the City Parks Association.  The performance on August 21st will feature 3 cutting edge circus companies, and Acrobatic Conundrum will be headlining.  A big thank you to Circus Now for facilitating our involvement. 

The next phase of the project will focus on continued rehearsals at SANCA and culminate in presentation of a further developed show at CircusFest, the first edition of a new circus festival in November in Vancouver, BC.  We hope that these performances and participation in the Western Arts Alliance will generate sufficient bookings to tour our show extensively in the Pacific Northwest in 2015.

Our Needs - 

Although we have a couple of paying performances already scheduled, they won't come close to covering our production budget.  Some of our largest expenditures include:

   - Hiring a professional director.  Audiences will be pleased to see Terry back on stage performing KT Niehoff's innovative new work alongside his ensemble.                 

  - Airfare to New York City...and back again. Summerstage was able to cover half of this expense, but we would love to come back home, and tickets aren't cheap.

  - Sets and costumes, an important and often expensive piece of ACreation.

We think a goal of $6000 is a reasonable target considering our campaign last year raised more than $13,000 to take us to Chicago. YEAH!!!  It is difficult for us to continue asking for support as we strive for sustainability. With the intense competition for very limited government funding of the arts, crowdsourcing campaigns have become an integral fundraising tool for new companies like ours. That said, we are shifting the balance of our fundraising toward grant writing and most importantly new bookings. It is absolutely our goal to eventually become self-sustaining. 

As a collective we are donating hundreds of hours of our time to this project. It is truly a labor of love, yet we won't be able to continue the work we are so passionate about without your support. 

Our Guest Director, KT Niehoff


KT Niehoff is Seattle based artist who makes events, dances, music, films, classes, spaces and fosters creative communities.

In 1996 she began making her own dance dominant performances – immersive full-length works with an emphasis on original (often live) music. In 2007 her creative pursuits began focusing on audience/artist/ proximity, resulting in the majority of her work since then happening in non-traditional spaces. Her work has been presented throughout the U.S. and internationally in Japan, Ecuador, Germany and Canada.

She was featured in Dance Magazine’s “International Women in Dance” (’08) and on the covers of Dance Teacher Magazine (’12) and City Arts Seattle (’13).

In 2011 opened her own creative research space on Capitol Hill called 10 degrees.

“I am driven by the desire for a deeper connection between what I make and who comes into contact with it. I am an event maker, party planner, space builder, gift-giver and connection seeker. I have exchanged traditional stages for cabarets, bars, street corners, screens and letter writing. I have stretched time with performances scattered over seasons and films that last forever.

My works have had wildly different requirements, ranging from completely pedestrian to over the top spectacle. Yet each project has, in its own way, used duration (spanning months), proximity (the freedom to stand near, talk to and touch a dancer) and/or direct communication with audience (dances built on information garnered from the receiver) as a means to develop a deeper intimacy.

I want audiences that come into contact with my work to feel as if they own each project. I believe belonging and ownership can promote the most active, creative, inspired parts of us individually and as a society.”

Terry Crane (Founder)

By committing acts of daring on available vertical surfaces at the tender age of 1 year old, Terry began a lifelong quest to ascend to higher heights and provoking ever more shock and awe. Originally a native of Snoqualmie, WA, his journey has taken Terry to the Beijing International Arts School, the National Circus School of Montreal, the San Francisco Circus Center, the School of Acrobatics & New Circus Arts, and Oberlin College--all institutions which claim him as an alumnus. Although inspired by lineages of various performance and movement disciplines ranging from capoeira to neo-buffoonery, all of Terry's work remains his fiercely unique, original style. Since finishing higher education--so to speak--Terry has performed his antics in 10 countries on 3 continents, met a king and a prime minister, starred on TV shows, been raved about by afficionadoes, colleagues, and critics. Performance credits include:  Honolulu Punch, Talvisirkus Hurjaruuth, and Circuses Starlight, Monti, and Flora. An advocate of collaboration of all kinds, he has founded two performance companies: Circus Syzygy, and the Acrobatic Conundrum. Terry continues to revel in the sublime experience of circus performance, and sharing his aerial hijinks with all his audiences. 

Get to know our director better in this ridiculous montage of the outtakes from our campaign video!


August 4th: Breaking News!

Today we decided on the title of our new show.  Drum rollllllllllllllllll!

"A book is not a ladder"

It comes from a footnote in the "The library of babel" by Jorge Luis Borges.  This story has been a major inspiration for the piece from the beginning.  The ladder reference will also become very clear when you see the amazing set we just finished building today!  

Meet the Cast of "A book is not a ladder"


Here is our latest video, where we formally introduce you to the cast, and they talk about some of their favorite moments from the show we are putting together!

Carey Cramer - Rope Artist

Carey Cramer comes from a diverse background in classic ballet, tap, jazz, modern dance, muay thai kickboxing and acrobatics. After her first taste of circus just over 6 years ago, she trained intensively under the coaching of Terry Crane for two years before attending the prestigious National Circus School of Montreal. There her professional formation included acrobatics, hand balancing, clowning, singing, and her primary discipline of rope. Influence from hip hop, break dance, and contact improvisation styles along with a passionate love of movement and psychology have transferred to Carey’s work on the rope empowering her with a unique, raw, and dynamic style. She has brought her wide variety of skills to the stage performing in Montreal, Seattle, Vancouver, and even touring with the band "Heart" last year. She has just recently moved on from the National School and The Acrobatic Conundrum is the first circus company she has the pleasure to work with.

Erica Rubinstein – Hand to Hand Acrobat

Erica Rubinstein first discovered circus while studying neuroscience and dance at Oberlin College. With a background of eight years in competitive gymnastics, circus seemed a natural fit. Since college she has trained extensively in her specialty of basing acrobatics at Circus Center (San Francisco, under the guidance of Lu Yi, & Xiaohong), NICA (Australia), DoJump (Portland) and SANCA (Seattle). Past performances include the Chicago Contemporary Circus Festival 2014, Teatro Zinzanni’s Mezzo Lunatico, Circus Bella, and the Moisture Festival. In addition to performing she is director of the Youth Performances Companies at the School of Acrobatics and New Circus Arts (SANCA) in Seattle, Washington where she works with advanced students ages 8 – 18. She has also helped organize multiple national circus conferences and is currently Community Manager for Circus Now, a non profit organization promoting circus across the United States. Erica performs with Terry Crane as duo Retro Verso, a genre and gender challenging partner acrobatics duet that flips our preconceptions on their head.

Ty Vennewitz

Ty Vennewitz grew up and up in Washington state. He discovered dance in higher education and graduated from Western Washington University at the top of his class. His dance credits include the Portland Opera, the A-Wol Dance Collective and a dental commercial as a ballet dancing molar. Ty’s obsession with circus lured him across the continent to the National Circus School in Montreal, where he put on the world’s smallest mask, a red nose, and seriously studied clowning.  He has performed his original  material throughout Quebec, China, and Dubai.  Content to be back in the North West, he is excited to join the Acrobatic Conundrum in their newest creation. 

Anna Thomas-Henry – Production Manager

Anna Thomas-Henry is a Seattle native who has been in the performing arts since childhood. Her formative education began locally in the drama department of Seattle Academy of Arts and Sciences (Seattle, WA) and the preparatory dance program of Cornish College of the Arts (Seattle, WA). She has won merit scholarships to attend musical theatre conservatory at both CAP21 (New York University) and AMDA (NYC. Graduate). Anna was the first American to study in the musical theatre and voice department of the Shanghai Conservatory of Music (Shaghai, China). The Circus arts are a relatively new endeavor for her having began training as an aerialist and acrobat just four years ago. Training includes the Professional Preparatory Programs at both Circus Warehouse (NYC) and SANCA Seattle (First Graduating Class). She has worked as a vocalist, dancer, actor, aerialist and choreographer in NYC, on tour and in Seattle. This is Anna’s first foray into performing arts administration and she is thrilled to support Acrobatic Conundrum. 

Jacki Ward - Contortionist

With a history of gymnastics, theatre and visual arts, Jacki entered the circus world in 2005 and pursued her training in Seattle, San Francisco and Buenos Aires. Jacki’s first passion was contortion and hand-balancing, the discipline she has performed locally and abroad.  She has since branched out into a variety of aerial apparatus, and is currently specializing in duo straps and lyra.  Additionally, Jacki is a certified hatha yoga instructor and holds a B.A. in Anthropology of the Performing Arts from the University of Puget Sound. She was a 2011-2012 recipient of the Thomas J. Watson Fellowship, through which she traveled to Mongolia, China, India, France and Canada to study local performance traditions and training methods in contortion and the circus arts. She has coached at the School of Acrobatics and New Circus Arts (SANCA) in Seattle, Cirque du Sound in Tacoma and conducted multiple workshops from Olympia, WA to Malaysia.  She currently teaches and performs with Night Flight Aerial and the Circus Project in her hometown of Portland, OR.

Nicolo Kehrwald - Acrobat, Aerialist

Nicolo Kehrwald began with dance, studying tap, ballet, modern and capoeira and he quickly took to the circus arts when he joined Do Jump! Extremely Physical Theatre in 2001.  During his 12 years as a company member, he developed a high level of skill and versatility as he performed floor acrobatics, trapeze, hoop, straps, Chinese pole, and more.  His passion for circus inspired him to study at circus schools around the globe – some recent highlights include returning to Montreal to train with Yury Bozyan, studying under Claude Victoria in France, and  training with the amazing acrobats of Mongolia under Yanjinbileg and Bud Tumurbaatar.  His first love is handbalancing and floor acrobatics yet he is well versed in aerial apparatus of all sorts.

The Acrobatic Conundrum is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of The Acrobatic Conundrum must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

You can also give reward-free donations directly via Fractured Atlas here.

We understand that times can be tight.  If you cannot donate financially, we appreciate you spreading the word about our work to people you think might appreciate what we are doing.  You can find us at www.acrobaticconundrum.com and on Facebook at www.facebook.com/acrobatic.conundrum

Thank you so much for your generous support.

story:
Short Summary

Highly Impractical Theatre is gearing up to put on a fully-immersive, site-specific, rendition of Anton Chekhov's Three Sisters set in a Brooklyn that's burning.

Re-imagined in a dystopian mid-21st Century Brooklyn where economic inequality and police surveillance have become the dominant social realities, audiences for Three Sisters are invited to seek refuge with the Prozorov family as they sing, dance, and philosophize their way through the night following actors through a magnificent historic building in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.

Built into the production is a social experiment.  Tickets range from 99¢ to $99 as audiences can choose their own experience of the play by purchasing tickets by class levels. Experiences range from working alongside the servants as a Serf ($0.99 a ticket) and entering through the "Poor Door" of the building, to a luxury experience as a Tsar ($99 per ticket) where audience members will be showered with gifts and enjoy the finest seats in the theatre.  Discounts are given for returning audience members so that they can experience the full social spectrum of the play.

With your help, we can transform a three-story building into a lush world in which every nook and cranny explores the divisions and desires which span a century and a continent. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our costs go to two main locations: 

1) Paying the artists and staff (not enough to live, but enough to afford the subway tickets to rehearsal).

2) Creating the set, costumes, food, and all the other little details that make this production not just a play, but a full-sensory experience. 

Total Budget 7490
Stage Manager   1000
Actors ($100 X14)   1400
Costumes   500
Set   500
Set Designer   100
Costume Designer   100
Lighting Designer   100
Publicity   500
Food/Drink   1000
Insurance   500
Props   500
Lights   500
Video   100
Photography   200
7% Administrative Fees from Fractured Atlas and Indiegogo   490
We are also selling tickets, so while not every single dollar for the show needs to come from this campaign, donating will help give us the capital we need get supplies ahead of time, pay people on time, and ensure that Highly Impractical Theatre has the capital it needs for future productions.

Plus by donating you get access to some great perks, everything from discounted tickets to songs written in your honor!  But there are other great thank you gifts, like prints of the beautiful production photos.   

Highly Impractical Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Highly Impractical Theatre must be made payable to Fractured Atlas. Any contribution above the value of the perks received is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Risks & Challenges

We're called Highly Impractical Theatre for a reason! We love putting on plays that transform unintentionally theatrical spaces into fully-realized worlds for audiences to explore. This is no easy task and something could always go wrong.  The building could collapse, the actors could all get sick, no one might come. 

But this isn't the first highly impractical play that we've put on!  

In 2010, fellows (aka "interns") from Berkeley Repertory Theater got together to create a theatre company that would produce and develop socially relevant plays for unconventional spaces and engage audiences in an active, sensory experience of stories.  In the past we have created plays inspired by and performed in exhibits at the Brooklyn Museum, transformed the daily grind of the offices of a San Francisco marketing firm into surreal adventures, and brought to life the history of a small town in Oregon by inhabiting its founding farmstead. And of course, our founding production was turning a two-story Berkeley townhouse into the battleground of the 1950's housewife revolution!  Every one of the productions seemed like a wild idea at the time, but every single one received excellent reviews from critics and sincere appreciation from the communities that hosted us.  Read a review from the Huffington Post, KQED (San Francisco NPR Station), or the SF Examiner, or scroll through the photos on the HIT Facebook page to see pictures of previous productions.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Think this sounds awesome, and want to help above and beyond giving money?  Great!  First off, please encourage your friends to see the show! Secondly, consider helping ushering or staffing the box office.  Contact Sarah Brown.

    Who's All Involved?

    Three Sisters is directed by Elana McKelahan and features scenic design by Ventiko, costume design by Misha Pyle, lighting design by Jonathan Cottle, sound design by Gahyae Ryu, props design by Machel Ross and original music by Stephen Bennett.

    The talented cast includes Karin Agstam, Rebecca Behrens, Gabriel Christian, Carolina Do, Andy Ingalls, Meridith Jones, Camara McLaughlin, Terrence Montgomery, Thomas Muccioli, Stacy Salvette, Eliza Simpson, Mac Wallach and Akyiaa Wilson.
story_txt:
Short Summary Highly Impractical Theatre is gearing up to put on a fully-immersive, site-specific, rendition of Anton Chekhov's Three Sisters set in a Brooklyn that's burning.

Re-imagined in a dystopian mid-21st Century Brooklyn where economic inequality and police surveillance have become the dominant social realities, audiences for Three Sisters are invited to seek refuge with the Prozorov family as they sing, dance, and philosophize their way through the night following actors through a magnificent historic building in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn.
Built into the production is a social experiment.  Tickets range from 99¢ to $99 as audiences can choose their own experience of the play by purchasing tickets by class levels. Experiences range from working alongside the servants as a Serf ($0.99 a ticket) and entering through the "Poor Door" of the building, to a luxury experience as a Tsar ($99 per ticket) where audience members will be showered with gifts and enjoy the finest seats in the theatre.  Discounts are given for returning audience members so that they can experience the full social spectrum of the play.
With your help, we can transform a three-story building into a lush world in which every nook and cranny explores the divisions and desires which span a century and a continent.    What We Need & What You Get Our costs go to two main locations: 
1) Paying the artists and staff (not enough to live, but enough to afford the subway tickets to rehearsal).
2) Creating the set, costumes, food, and all the other little details that make this production not just a play, but a full-sensory experience. 



Total Budget
7490


Stage Manager
 
1000


Actors ($100 X14)
 
1400


Costumes
 
500


Set
 
500


Set Designer
 
100


Costume Designer
 
100


Lighting Designer
 
100

500


Food/Drink
 
1000


Insurance
 
500


Props
 
500


Lights
 
500


Video
 
100


Photography
 
200


7% Administrative Fees from Fractured Atlas and Indiegogo
 
490

We are also selling tickets, so while not every single dollar for the show needs to come from this campaign, donating will help give us the capital we need get supplies ahead of time, pay people on time, and ensure that Highly Impractical Theatre has the capital it needs for future productions.Plus by donating you get access to some great perks, everything from discounted tickets to songs written in your honor!  But there are other great thank you gifts, like prints of the beautiful production photos.   
Highly Impractical Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Highly Impractical Theatre must be made payable to Fractured Atlas. Any contribution above the value of the perks received is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

And of course, our founding production was turning a two-story Berkeley townhouse into the battleground of the 1950's housewife revolution!  Every one of the productions seemed like a wild idea at the time, but every single one received excellent reviews from critics and sincere appreciation from the communities that hosted us.  Read a review from the Huffington Post, KQED (San Francisco NPR Station), or the SF Examiner, or scroll through the photos on the HIT Facebook page to see pictures of previous productions.

story:
What's Going On?

TACONIC PARKWAY, a play written by Sudipta Bhawmik, and directed by Bruce "Master B" Baek  will be staged at the Thespis Festival 2015, July 16 - 19, at the Hudson Guild Theater (441 W. 26 St, NY, NY). 

Now, some background information.  

On September 30, 2014, the Dramatist Guild of America arranged a playwright-director exchange in New York. The objective of this gathering was to connect directors with playwrights with the hope of building successful collaborations to produce new work.  It was at this meeting where New Jersey-based playwright Sudipta Bhawmik  met  New York-based director Bruce “Master B” Baek. Bruce read a couple of scripts of Sudipta and fell in love with TACONIC PARKWAY. The playwright and director met few more times and felt that this play must happen on New York stage.  The play was submitted to the Thespis Festival 2015 where it got accepted.  The collaboration then moved on to the next steps - fundraising, casting, rehearsals and the final staging.  And this campaign is about the most important step in the process - fundraising.

Oops! We almost forgot to introduce the key players - the playwright and the director. 

Sudipta Bhawmik is an acclaimed and award-winning  playwright whose plays tell the stories of immigrant south Asians. His plays have been staged around the world in multiple languages and he has two books of plays (in Bengali) to his credit. TACONIC PARKWAY is one of Sudipta’s most popular plays that has been staged in Bengali and Marathi languages in New Jersey and California.  Sudipta is excited to work with Bruce to bring the English version of this  play to the New York stage.

The director, Bruce “Master B” Baek, SDC, is a New York City-based professional theater director and an actor. Originally trained as a film director, his production often brings the richness of detailed storytelling with unmistakably noticeable organic acting on the stage.   

But What Can I Do?

To make this collaboration a success, we need another partner - YOU! 

We need your active support through a small financial contribution which would help in making this project a reality - a New York premiere of TACONIC PARKWAY

You will agree that art is another form of a therapeutic element. We artists can heal people with our craft. And to accomplish this somewhat daring goal, the production needs to happen. It is by no means any fancy and unnecessary presentation.  To be able to ‘heal’ even one person, the art form needs to come alive.  The painting needs to be on canvas, the music needs to be played, the song needs to be sung,  the movements need to be danced, and the play needs to be on stage. The contribution isn’t only about funding the production. It is for a much bigger purpose - to heal and to be healed.

That's Good. But What is This Play About?

It's about our inner battles. The past seems always like a shadow to the present and it often delves into the future.  It is like an invisible tattoo.  It never fades.  Especially the deep and dark ones. In TACONIC PARKWAY, you will witness the inner battles of three desolate characters with their abusive and dark past. 

But is it all real? Don’t we often have this feeling that maybe our life is just a play or a movie? Or maybe it's a game, a play. TACONIC PARKWAY lays the beautiful and mysterious path to this dangerous game of  truth or dare.  And guess what? We ALL dare  play this game in life more often than we want.

Here is what our Production Assistant Esha Tewari has to say about the play:


The Plot Line, Please?

Sorry! Here you go.

Manasij, a veteran Indian screen actor is visiting USA with a theater group to stage some shows in multiple cities. During his first stop in New York, he is hosted by Deepak and Sharika at their multi-million dollar mansion in upstate New York. The enthusiastic host, Deepak, expresses his desire to make a film with Manasij as the hero and their daughter Pom as the heroine. But Sharika objects to this proposal vehemently. She would never let Pom take part in this dream project of Deepak. Manasij tries to mediate, but soon realizes that he is being pulled into a dark vortex of suspicion and animosity that was carefully camouflaged by the opulence and the veneer of apparent happiness of an affluent immigrant Indian family.

Fine! Just Tell Me, How Much You Need?

Not much really. The production is planned on a shoestring budget by considering only the bare essentials. Your contribution will pay for the following:

Cast & Crew remuneration :  $1500.00

Rehearsal space rental  :         $1000.00

Light/Sound  :                                 $300.00

Sets/Props  :                                   $200.00

Miscellaneous (fees etc.)  :          $500.00

Total  :                                               $3500.00

This funding is of the type “all-or-none”. That is, if we don’t receive the entire budgeted amount, we get nothing. So please support us with whatever amount you feel comfortable. See the sidebar for the suggested contribution amounts.

And What Do I Get?

As a token of our appreciation for your support, we offer some exciting perks. Just check the sidebar on your right. These gifts may not be of great financial value, but they carry our heartfelt gratitude and thanks and also something to remember our production by.

But Why CrowdFunding? Why IndiGoGo?

Between Sudipta (and his theatre company ECTA) and Bruce (SQTheatreWorks), we have the experience of producing and directing more than twenty plays. But for those productions we used the traditional funding model of sponsorship, grants, and ticket sales. For TACONIC PARKWAY,  we try the crowdfunding model for the first time.  The production will be premiering at the Thespis theater festival where we have no financial controls. Hence, traditional funding models are not viable. We also believe that good theatre is a community art initiative and it can only be sustained by the active support of the community.  Hence, crowdfunding is the most appropriate financing model for theatre for it is the only possible cure for  the infamous “Baumol’s Cost Disease” that plagues the economic world of performing arts.  

Great! I am Sold. Any Other Way I Can Help?

You sure can help us in many other ways.

  • Help spread the word. Tell your friends and family of this project and the campaign. Share on your Facebook/Twitter/Tumblr/Instagram timelines and reach out.

  • Forward this as an email to your friends.

  • Talk about it to your friends/co-workers/family during get-togethers, parties, lunches or hangouts.

  • Come and watch the show.

Your contribution will go a long way to support South Asian theater in New York.  Thank you from the bottom of our hearts.

story:
John and Beatrice


Written by Carole Fréchette

Directed by Richaud Valls

With Jean Brassard, Hélène Kuhn, Sofi Lambert and Max Van Bel

Produced by Simonet Productions

Performed from June 6th to 12th at the Theater for the New City, 155 First Ave, New York, NY 10003.


What is it all about?


Everything starts with the eagerness of Richaud Valls to stage Carole Fréchette's play. Highly motivated, he surrounds himself with a great team of actors and coworkers to carry out this project.


Performed in New York in both English and French, John and Beatrice will move each one of you.


WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT
 There are about 10 people on the team. We all are professionals and doing thing in this way. But we need your financial support to get the best of this story and to make it happen.
So, if you believe in our project, don't hesitate and CONTRIBUTE NOW!


Other ways you can support
Spread the word and make some noise about our campaign by telling all your friends!

Find more informations about us on http://simonetproductions.com



Jean et Béatrice


Écrit par Carole Fréchette

Mise en scène par Richaud Valls

Avec Jean Brassard, Hélène Kuhn, Sofi Lambert et Max Van Bel

Produit par Simonet Productions

Du 6 au 12 Juin, au Theater for the New City, 155 First Avenue, New York, NY 10003

Qu'est-ce que c'est?
Tout commence avec l'envie qu'a Richaud Valls de monter la pièce de Carole Fréchette. Très motivé, il s'entoure alors d'une bonne équipe d'acteurs et collaborateurs pour mener à bien ce projet.

Jouée à New York à la fois en Anglais et en Français, Jean et Béatrice touchera chacun d'entre vous.

Synopsis
Béatrice, poussée par le manque d'amour et lassée de sa solitude, placarde sur les murs de la ville une affichette promettant une récompense à celui qui saura l'intéresser, l'émouvoir et la séduire.
Jean, chasseur de prime, se présente pour tenter sa chance.

Dans un lieu confiné, dans une ambiance survoltée, il va y avoir explosion de deux univers, choc de deux personnalités.
Ils vont s'affronter, se frôler, s'étreindre, selon les règles du jeu fixées par Béatrice, dans l'espoir d'une réalité de vie commune, pour elle, dans l'attente d'une rétribution pour lui.
Jusqu'à ce que se profile, non sans humour et émotion, la vérité des personnages.

ON A BESOIN DE VOUS
Nous sommes une équipe d'une dizaine de personnes, incluant nos excellents acteurs. Nous sommes tous des professionnels et agissons dans ce sens. Mais nous avons besoin de votre soutien financier pour que ce projet voit le jour.

Alors, si vous croyez en notre projet, n'hésitez plus et contribuez dès à présent!!

Autres moyens de nous aider
Faites parler de nous en transférant cette page à tous vos amis.

Vous trouverez plus d'informations sur nous à l'adresse suivante : http://simonetproductions.com

story:
The Need

It is a well known fact that actors love the spotlight. What is less well known is that, next to the spotlight, the place actors desire to be most is in big empty poorly lit rooms known as "studios" or "rehearsal spaces." Actors aren't accustomed to the harsh rays of the Texas sun. They need the clammy cool darkness of their natural habitat, the enclosed studio space, in order to truly thrive. BNTC would like to provide this habitat to actors in the Austin area but we need your help.


The Nitty Gritty 

The Brand New Theatre Co. is dedicated to training actors, developing playwrights and creating brand new theatre. Your donations to this campaign will be set aside to fund our move into a new studio location in Austin, Texas. We are giving serious consideration to a location in North Austin and are also checking out options in the same price range ($1,000 to $1,500) on the East side. We hope to have a contract by the end of October but before we sign the lease we want to ensure that the initial moving expenses and the first three month's rent are fully covered. This will give us time to establish a presence in the area, apply for production grants, enroll new students and identify regular monthly supporters (perhaps ones that bear an uncanny resemblance to yourself). 


Some Questions You May Be Asking Yourself

Question:  What if BNTC doesn't meet their fundraising goal?

Answer: If we don't feel that we are close enough to meeting our goal before signing a lease the money will be held by Fractured Atlas (our 501(c)(3) sponsor organization) until we locate an alternative studio location or we will use the money to rent rehearsal, training and performance space on an hourly basis as we offer classes and prepare for our first Austin production.


Question: What if BNTC raises more than their fundraising goal?

Answer: First, we will throw a party (using our own money to buy the chips and soda of course). Then we will use the money for paying more rent and other studio-related expenses. 

Double Question: What happens to BNTC's name when the company isn't brand new anymore? Does it just become the Theatre Co.?

Answer: Yeah...we get that one a lot...actually, BNTC isn't that new. Before we came to Austin we were training actors and producing new and improvised theatre in Tulsa, Ok starting in 2005. We're not a brand new company but we do produce brand new theatre.  We are all about producing new plays, devised productions and improvised shows all of which are, by nature, brand new. 


Exclamation!...followed by Question: BNTC sounds awesome! How can I learn more about this mind blowing organization?  

Answer: Check out or website: brandnewtheatreco.com. 


Full Disclosure: We will be considering live/work studio spaces that include attached apartments. If we select a live/work space, the attached apartment will serve as a home/office for BNTC's owner/Artistic Director. The money raised in this campaign will only pay the portion of the rent that is designated as rent for the studio. The remainder of the rent, designated as rent on the living space, will be paid directly by our AD. Feel free to contact us through our website if you have questions about this arrangement.

Then we will use the money for paying more rent and other studio-related expenses. Double Question: What happens to BNTC's name when the company isn't brand new anymore? Does it just become the Theatre Co.?Answer: Yeah...we get that one a lot...actually, BNTC isn't that new. Before we came to Austin we were training actors and producing new and improvised theatre in Tulsa, Ok starting in 2005. We're not a brand new company but we do produce brand new theatre.  We are all about producing new plays, devised productions and improvised shows all of which are, by nature, brand new. Exclamation!...followed by Question: BNTC sounds awesome! How can I learn more about this mind blowing organization?  Answer: Check out or website: brandnewtheatreco.com. Full Disclosure: We will be considering live/work studio spaces that include attached apartments. If we select a live/work space, the attached apartment will serve as a home/office for BNTC's owner/Artistic Director. The money raised in this campaign will only pay the portion of the rent that is designated as rent for the studio. The remainder of the rent, designated as rent on the living space, will be paid directly by our AD. Feel free to contact us through our website if you have questions about this arrangement.

story:
Henrik Ibsen’s Hedda Gabler, a new version by Brian Friel

Directed by Jessica Osbourne

Starring:

Sheridan Johnson, Brennan Foster, Evening Star Barron, Ron Weisberg, Alaina Warren-Zachery, Daniel Caimi , Moira Amado-McCoy.

Not only is Albuquerque a Premiere Film market, but it is also making it's mark upon the National Theatre scene. Albuquerque proudly hosts the largest number of theatres of any mid-sized city in the United States and The Aux Dog Theatre Nob Hill is a vital part of this scene with its innovative and bold programming choices.

The Aux Dog Theatre Nob Hill takes pride in approaching the development of its Artistic Associates in fresh and energetic directions. We are creating a company of Actors who are dedicated to developing their craft. A deep committment and strong work ethic is expected of our associates in both the creative and business side of the Aux Dog's development. One such example of this collaborative approach, is in supporting the passion and intellectual fervour of Jessica Osbourne's desire to bring this phenomenal new version of Hedda Gabler to the Southwest Region.

Nob Hill is the most vibrant and thriving of all the neighborhoods in Albuquerque and the Aux Dog Theatre is Albuquerque’s Premiere location for Live Performance in Nobhill. We need to embark upon a new marketing strategy to firmly embed the Theatre and its location, into the minds and hearts of a Regional audience. Extensive Marketing is sadly an expense that the Theatre is unable to accomodate for in their normal marketing budget. So through this Indie-Gogo campaign, we hope to raise the funds to enable us create a top of the line Production and Marketing strategy.

Hedda Gabler is the original lethal Desperate Housewife. Ibsen's "Hedda Gabler" has been described as the role closest to Hamlet in the female repertoire. Since Hedda was unleashed on the world in 1891, the role has attracted a formidable range of top-flight actresses keen to test themselves against its exceptional demands – from Peggy Ashcroft, Maggie Smith, Joan Greenwood and Janet Suzman to Fiona Shaw, Eve Best, Cate Blanchett, Harriet Walter and most recently Sheridan Smith. We are very excited to bring this extraordinarly complex character to it's Regional Premiere!

Brian Friel's new version of this classic, comes fresh from the London’s West-End with phenomenal reviews! This critically acclaimed classic will inspire both seasoned and new theatre-goers alike, to leave their couches and venture into the theatre for an unforgettable experience.

The Playwrights....

Henrik Ibsen is often ranked as one of the truly great playwrights in the European tradition. Richard Hornby describes him as "a profound poetic dramatist—the best since Shakespeare" He is widely regarded as the most important playwright since Shakespeare. He influenced other playwrights and novelists such as George Bernard Shaw, Oscar Wilde, Arthur Miller, James Joyce, and Eugene O'Neill.

Brian Friel is an Irish dramatist, author and director of the Field Day Theatre Company. He is considered to be one of the greatest living English-language dramatists, hailed by the English-speaking world as an "Irish Chekhov"and "the universally accented voice of Ireland". Friel is best known for plays such as Philadelphia, Here I Come! and Dancing at Lughnasa but has written more than thirty plays in a six-decade spanning career that has seen him elected Saoi of Aosdána. Aosdána is an Irish association of artists. It was created in 1981 on the initiative of a group of writers and with support from the Arts Council of Ireland. The title of Saoi (lit. "wise one") is the highest honour that members of Aosdána can bestow upon a fellow member. No more than seven living members can be so honoured at one time. Membership is by invitation from current members only. His plays have also been a regular feature on Broadway throughout his career.

The Director

Jessica Osbourne was born and raised in the small town of Cleethorpes in the North of England and has been working in the Entertainment Industry since the wee age of 11. She has worked on many film and theatre projects, ranging from Actor/Comedienne to Executive Producer. Favourite theatre roles include Puck in Midsummer Night's Dream (Santa Fe Shakespeare Society), Denise in Living Purgatory (Rodey Theatre, UNM), Beth in The Mistakes that Madeleine Made (AuxDog, ABQ) Susy in Wait Until Dark (Vortex, ABQ) & Caliban in the Tempest (Bridewell Theatre, London). Favourite film roles include The Amateur, Shocking Facts, Waste Water, Policy & Mickey.

She started doing Stand up Comedy in 2010 and had the honor of performing in LA’s World Famous “The Comedy Store”, she was also featured on the “Duke City Comedy League” television series and in their LIVE shows, as well as Third Thursday Contest, Young Dumb and Full Comedy shows, Embassy Suites Comedy Room and numerous stand up shows around town. Jessica is also the Producer of Comedy for the Albuquerque Film Festival and founding producer for the Friday Night Live and Second Saturday Standup shows at the Aux Dog Theatre Nob Hill.

Jessica directed her first play "Les Liaisons Dangereuses" at the Vortex Theatre in 2003. Recently, she directed "Two Way Mirror- two Arthur Miller one acts" at the Southwest Rural Theatre Project. This will mark the first production she helms at the Aux Dog Theatre Nob Hill.

Our Concept

Hedda Gabler is usually performed as a period drama, since this new version takes a more humourous approach to the play, we felt it was important to find a way to modernize the overall perception of the piece. Due to the social contraints that existed in Nineteenth Century society, it was vital that a common ground could be found that both complemented this periods persona yet could be rationalized in the mind of the modern American. So we're very excited to announce that our setting will be early 1960's America. Before the real feminist social revolution began, women still felt obligated to marry and settle down. As the daughter of a wealthy General, Hedda had never been forced to enter the workforce and had no knowledge or experience of what options there may be for her upon her father's untimely demise. After her fathers death, she is left with little choice but to marry someone who meets her standard of social status and conservative lifestlye. Therein lies the rub.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to get this production off the ground, we need your help! Your dollars will go towards many expenses involved.

Expenses include the following:

  • Design of Advertising Image
  • Cost of hiring billboards
  • Cost of creating and running Radio Commercial spots.
  • Cost of creating and running Television Commercial spots
  • Cost of printing and distributing posters and/or flyers
  • Cost of advertising in print media
  • Costume design, materials and seamstress
  • Set building, materials and labor
  • Dramatic Rights to perform play
  • Travel costs, wages and Expenses

For your assistance we will be giving away some of the following:

  • Prominent Sponsor acknowledgement in program and on website
  • Tickets to the show
  • Tickets/Passes to Friday Night Live! Improv shows
  • Tickets/Passes to Second Saturday Stand up shows
  • Autographed Posters
  • Autographed copy of the play
  • Advertising space in program
  • Invitation to special VIP Cast and Crew events.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tickets sales are how we keep the theatre alive! With the ever increasing cost of utilities, just keeping the theatre open can sometimes be a challenge. Other ways you can help us are:

  • donate on our website
  • by buying all your tickets in advance on our website
  • coming to see our current productions
  • Buy your tickets here: www.auxdog.com/shop

The Aux Dog Theatre Nob Hill has great hopes and dreams on making its mark on the International Theatre scene, with your help... maybe our dreams can come true!

story:
Short Summary

Hello! We're the creative team of Shatter, a new play by Anderson Cook that will be premiering as part of the Venus/Adonis Theater Festival in January 2016.

The play is about five young adults gathered one night in an East Village apartment, and deals humorously, smartly and realistically with the issues of race, sexual assault, political correctness and friendship as the unexpected complexities of these issues become clearly present in the lives of five young friends at a party that wasn't supposed to happen.

The show is one of those that begins as an unsuspecting comedy, and sneakily hits you in the heart mid-way, where each character has something you can relate to but also something that makes you squirm. It's also one of the few things I have ever seen that takes hot-button issues and incorporates them into fiction in ways that actually seem realistic rather than obnoxious and heavy-handed. It's about what happens when the things you read about and ultimately ignore stop being the elephant in the room and start living and breathing.

Shatter's History

March 2014
Anderson writes an early draft of Shatter.

November 2014 
Anderson meets Cassidy and Barrett while studying abroad in Berlin. They ask to read his writing. He sends them Shatter. They read it and react positively, sometimes with deep emotion.

December 2014
The group decides to bring this show to life in the form of a staged reading when they return to New York.

May 2015
Shatter premieres in staged reading form for two nights only to packed crowds atop Barrett and Cassidy's Bushwick rooftop on Troutman Street, affectionately titled Klub Trout. Everyone seems to have a nice time.

July 2015
Anderson submits to festivals. He gets into Venus/Adonis. Meetings begin about the future of the show. Collaborators are assembled and re-assembled.

November 2015
Rehearsals begin and fundraising is underway!

January 2016
Shatter will have its world premiere full production at the Hudson Guild Theater as part of the Venus/Adonis Festival!

Meet The Team!

Anderson Cook (Writer) is a senior in the Playwriting Program in the Tisch School of the Arts, where he has studied under playwrights like Lucas Hnath, Peter Parnell, Daniel Goldfarb, and Brandon Jacobs-Jenkins. His plays have been produced by the Tisch New Theatre, NYU’s New Works Festival, and most recently his musical The Disembodied Hand That Fisted Everyone to Death was featured in the Bad Theater Festival to sellout crowds. He’s currently ghostwriting a young adult novel for Paragraph Publishing as he wraps up his senior year.

Turner Barrett Law (Director) is a freelance theatrical artist; directing, designing, creating, and performing. He has created his own original one man show QUEERWOLF; a fangaysia on personal themes and immersive horror/comedy SÉANCE SINISTER SCIENCE; he wrote, directed, set-designed, and performed in both. When he was not developing his own work, you might have caught him designing sets for Young Gotham Arts' Antigone, or helping to build them on Woodshed Collective's Empire Travel Agency. You'll frequently find him behind the bar at Fresh Ground Pepper events all around the city, and walking dogs for app-based Wag because puppies. 

Cassidy Dawn Graves (Producer) is a performance artist, producer, and writer. She has performed her unique brand of solo work and theatre all over the city, including Under St Marks, Bizarre Bushwick, Silent Barn, Dixon Place, 440 Studios, and her Bushwick rooftop. Once, she performed naked in the street during Fashion Week. In addition to creating and producing all-female new work showcase AM I WRITE, LADIES?, she in collaboration with composer and sound designer Dan Rider co-produces SoundBites, an evening of live radio dramas and curated food. She is also a writer, reporting on arts and culture for NYMag's Bedford + Bowery and NYU Local, and has had theatre criticism published in Howlround. She recently concluded a sold-out production of 50 Shades of Graves (her interactive sex education musical) and will appear in the chorus of Erin Markey's performance art musical A Ride On The Irish Cream at Abrons Arts Center in January.

We also have some nice acting being done by Erica Pappas, Kenny Mai, Yael Leberman and James Skarren, graphics by Jesse Jae Hoon Eisenberg, stage management by Jenna Hoffmann, and good ol' design elements by Ben Lapidus, Andrey Ketchell, Patrick Korkuch, and Kyle Hill.

What We Need & What You Get

We're aiming to raise $1700 to get this show on the road (well, not literally on the road.) Why that number? We'll tell you.

$750 will allow us to pay every single person involved with the show a $50 stipend. Production team, designers, actors, graphic designer, and photographer, for a total of 15 stipends. Because unpaid work is so last year, and even the smallest amount helps to break down the longstanding assumption that it's ok to just not pay people for their work and time.

$200 will earn us back the participation fee we had to pay out of pocket to submit this show to the Venus/Adonis Fest.

$150 will go to scenic and props design.

$100 will go to costume design for five characters.

$100 will pay for printing of promotional materials.

$150 will go toward a special sneak peek party event.

$200 will go towards purchasing tickets for donors and generally funding any perks that require advance purchase on our part.

Total: 1700

If the smooth sensation of typing in your credit card number and thinking of our smiling faces isn't enough to satisfy you, we have some fun lil perks for those who decide to be generous. These include:

- A special haiku / just for you by director / Turner Barrett Law

- A custom-written monologue by the playwright himself!

- A wacky online thank you graphic created by a real life milennial who may or may not be known as Cassidy Dawn Graves!

- A free ticket to the show!

- A character from Shatter's first impression of you!

- A secret event!

The Impact

Still not sure you want to sling dough our way? Flour up those hands and roll out that dough, because it's more useful than buying a drink.

  • Helping us mount this play is a way of saying you trust this team of artists, and gives us the knowledge that you support the work we make and want to see more.
  • Our team has experience independently producing work, so you can trust that we will do this and do it well. You're empowering an up-and-coming wave of theatre artists!
  • A play like this does not roll around every day. There is a lot of bad theatre out there, I'm sure everyone has experienced this. Donating to Shatter is a vote for supporting quality new work.

Risks & Challenges

Ok, so we're not going to pretend you haven't seen a thousand of these crowdfunding pages before. This is nothing new. But the truth is that as early career artists, it's hard to get monetary assistance like grants when one is just starting out. The money you give us will not only help us with this project now, 

  • Even if we don't get all the money we asked for, we can make it work. Our team has experience making work on pretty much literally a dime. But wouldn't it be so much nicer not to?

Other Ways You Can Help

Many people aren't swimming in spare cash and sometimes eat dollar pizza for dinner because they have too much money anxiety to buy anything more! We have all been there. Some of us are even there now. That is okay. Something you can do that isn't monetary is share this campaign! Tell your friends with your mouths and your keyboards! They make buttons now to make doing that easy! Don't you love technology?

story:
The Tiger’s Bride
by Angela Carter 


Who We Are

Marvellous Machine is made up of a couple of friends living in Oxford who’ve decided to make a show!

Lou is a Theatre Maker with a passion for homespun retellings of classic tales and Becki is a musician who writes and performs her own music.


What We Want to Do

“My father lost me to the Beast at cards”

We absolutely love Angela Carter’s vivid and witty feminist twists on traditional fairy tales. The theatricality of her writing makes her a wonderful subject for a stage adaptation.

The Tiger’s Bride is a modern reworking of Charles Perrault’s Beauty and the Beast. Having fled abjection in Russia, Beauty and her father arrive in a small Italian village to find that all who come here must play a hand with La Bestia.

Turning the conventional fairy-tale on its head, The Tiger’s Bride is a story of desire, rebirth and embracing the Beast in all of us.


How You Can Help

We really are a brand new company. Think of us as a sort of theatrical embryo! As any Theatre Maker knows, costs can quickly mount up! We need help raising funds for the following (but not limited to)

  • Rehearsal space
  • Venue hire
  • Rights to adaptation fees
  • Ticketing fees
  • Publicity
  • Travel costs
  • Props and costumes

With your generous support, we can create something really special. We want to take our time with this project so that we can explore the text to the best of our ability, so hire of rehearsal space is a big priority!


Grrrl Power

The Tiger’s Bride is ultimately a story about a woman overcoming objectification and becoming the agent of her own lifestory.

In a society where women are constantly dehumanised by messages about having perfect bodies in order for corporations to sell their products; where women who dare to have a voice are threatened with rape and violent death; and where a young man felt justified in carrying out an extreme act of terrorism because of a woman's right to say "No", we believe it’s important to tell women’s stories in order to normalise the female voice and to claim women’s bodies for their own.

By flipping the traditional story of Beauty and the Beast on its head, Angela Carter begins to unpick the gender norms represented in Charles Perrault’s original fairy tale, and the limitations placed on both males and females by Western society.

Marvellous Machine are proud to bring this magnificent story to the stage.


Other Ways You Can Help

Money can be tight – we totally get it if you don’t feel you can contribute but here are some other ways you can help:

  • Volunteer! We’d love to hear from anybody who's interested in collaborating with us in any way they can, be it prop making, promoting the show or even just manning the theatre bar! Get in touch with us: info@marvellousmachine.com
  • Follow us on Twitter @MarvMach
  • Tell your friends! Please share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter or however you prefer.
  • Finally, come and see the show! Booking info will be shared here nearer the time. Or join our (very irregular) mailing list to stay up to date: http://marvellousmachine.com/mailing-list/

You’re awesome ;D

The Tiger’s Brideby Angela Carter 

Who We Are
Marvellous Machine is made up of a couple of friends living in Oxford who’ve decided to
make a show!

Lou is a Theatre Maker with a passion for homespun retellings of
classic tales and Becki is a musician who writes and performs her own
music.
What We Want to Do
“My father lost me to the
Beast at cards”
We absolutely love
Angela Carter’s vivid and witty feminist twists on traditional fairy tales. The
theatricality of her writing makes her a wonderful subject for a stage adaptation.

The
Tiger’s Bride is a modern reworking of Charles Perrault’s Beauty and the Beast. Having fled abjection in Russia, Beauty and her father
arrive in a small Italian village to find that all who come here must play a
hand with La Bestia.
Turning the conventional fairy-tale on
its head, The Tiger’s Bride is a
story of desire, rebirth and embracing the Beast in all of us.
How You Can Help
We really are a brand new company. Think of us as a sort of theatrical embryo! As any
Theatre Maker knows, costs can quickly mount up! We need help raising funds for
the following (but not limited to)

Rehearsal space
Venue hire
Rights to adaptation fees
Ticketing fees
Publicity
Travel costs
Props and costumes

story:
The project: Secret Service

An abandoned warehouse. A group of mannequins. A masked figure. Mysterious agents.  Darkness. The scene is set for the ultimate Canadian spy story, which mixes hilarity and horror with an equal blend of eroticism Canadian-style; that is, hockey, high tech and whips. 

This is the setup for Fugue Theatre's new show, Secret Service, which we are working to bring to Granville Island' s Performance Works this fall from September 28 to October 5th. With libretto by Kico Gonzalez-Risso and all original music by Neil Weisensel, this original commissioned 90-minute operetta will explore a world where nothing is what it appears to be, and where no one can hide, telling the story of a politician at a secret meeting with his mistress. Over the course of their time together, this operetta questions the roles and responsibilities of knowledge and power.

Who are we? 

Fugue Theatre is a professional Vancouver theatre company spearheaded by Laura Di Cicco and Shannon Macelli, our Artistic and Managing Director and General Manager, dedicated since its formation in 2004 to the production of original Canadian operettas and music theatre. 

Secret Service is our fourth full-length operetta, and is our most ambitious project to date! After a very successful series of workshops this spring, we are in full production mode, and need your help to bring this show to the stage in all its glory. And psst! tickets are available here! As well as in some of the perks...

How you can help!

To bring this show to life will cost approximately $91,000. We have wonderful sponsors and funders, but we're not all the way there. Ideally, we'd like to be able to employ up to 18 people for a 1 to 2 month period, including Artistic & Musical Directors, 3 performers, 3 designers (set/lighting, costumes, sound), Production Manager, Stage Manager, Props/Set/Costume builders, Technical crew & Front of House staff.

The closer we can get to a full budget, the more polished and ready the show will be. Please help us any way you can: by pre-buying tickets, sponsoring a performance or a performer, or by backing one of our "just for fun" perks.

If you can’t contribute, please use the Indiegogo share tools to help us tell others about what we're up to... your word of mouth is hugely important to the success of this show. Thanks so much for your support.

story:
Help Snapped Productions produce Shakespeare's Much Ado About Nothing, directed by Gregory Couba!

Love. War. Conspiracy. Sex. Betrayal. Death. Could all these things truly amount to Nothing?  In Shakespeare’s beloved comedy Much Ado About Nothing, Don Pedro and his men return victoriously from war to the house of Leonato, Governor of Messina.  Proven in battle, Claudio proposes to Leonato's dutiful daughter Hero, to the dismay of his comrade, Benedick, who wittily battles with the Lady Beatrice on the demerits of love.  The stage is set for merry conflict as those who jest at love are caught in a hilarious conspiracy to make them fall in love.  Meanwhile a sinister plot brews to unmake Claudio and Hero's nuptials, setting in motion a series of events that challenge loyalties, test character, and examine the fickleness of life and love.

Incorporating a vibrant and diverse cast, Snapped Productions deconstructs outdated female archetypes, challenges masculine stereotypes, and advances the classic ideas about male/female relationships, seen here through a modern lens. Much Ado About Nothing is exactly that—the whimsy of human beings taking what should be simple – love – and making it absurdly (and often times, laughably) complex.

Donating to Much Ado means that you are helping:

  • to bring accessible theater to Harlem
  • to support culturally diverse and relevant storytelling
  • to provide opportunities for professional actors, design and production staff to advance in their careers
  • make people laugh through this delightful comedy (which, frankly we all need a little more of right now!)

The donations given to this campaign will go directly to our stipend fund for the production's cast and crew.  

SNAPPED PRODUCTIONS creates work that builds community and realizes artistic expression, in an environment that supports the upward careers of company members.

With a focus on “new voices”--supporting new plays and playwrights, breathing fresh ideas into classic works, offering unique opportunities to emerging actors and stage managers, and showcasing the work of imaginative, up-and-coming directors and design staff—Snapped Productions ensures that the vital human need for storytelling grows limitlessly.  Through a commitment to diversity, Snapped Productions brings audiences relevant, truthful productions representative of personal and community expression.

story:
My Story

Hello! My name is Morgan Sheehan. I am 15 years old from the US. I've been dancing for 11 years now and I'm now on my way to hopefully become a professional. My passion is ballet. I also do jazz, modern, and character. My performance resume is long. I've been in the BalletMet Nutcracker since 2007 and have played many roles including young Clara. I've also been in BalletMet's Alice in Wonderland in 2009, BalletMet's Swan Lake in 2009, and BalletMet's Cinderella in 2011. Over the last four years, I've been to 3 different intensives, including BalletMet Columbus, ABT Austin, and Orlando Ballet School. This summer, I will be attending Ballet West's summer intensive for 8 weeks, and I would be grateful if you could help me get there! 

What We Need & What You Get

As you may or may not know, intensives are expensive! My goal is $4800, but realistically, I would like it to be at least $300, so my parents can come see me at the end of the program and it can also cover some pointe shoe costs. More than $500 will start going to my tuition and room/board. 

If you help my cause, you will get some handy dandy perks! A $25 donation is "apprentice" level. With that donation, you will get a personal thank you email from my me. A $50 donation is "corps de ballet" level. With that you will get a hand written thank you note and picture of me from this summer! A $75 donation is "soloist" level. If you are kind enough to donate this much, you will get a picture of my from this summer, and a video of me expressing my thanks! A $100 donation is "principle" level. This is the highest level, so you will get a picture of me from this summer, a video of me expressing my thanks, and a video of me dancing! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please take the time to share my campaign with friends who also appreciate the arts! Thank you!

story:
About the Project...

Dance... Visual Art... Murals... Photography... Film Making... Dreaming... and... Community Participation! 

The Sideshow Saturdays Project involves a series of interdisciplinary events at Goldenflower Tai Chi Studio in Winston-Salem, NC. During the months of June, July and August, Sideshow Saturdays invites audience members to step into a performance installation or creative project that weaves together dance and movement with various arts mediums including photography, visual art, music, and even dreaming. Audience participation may vary according to each project and relative to audience member interests; however, everyone present co-creates each event.

We call our series of events Sideshow Saturdays because they take place in tandem with an already existing event, Summer On Trade – a street concert every Saturday evening in the heart of downtown Winston-Salem. Not only will the hundreds of audience members who gather for Summer on Trade enjoy listening to great music, Sideshow Saturdays offers everyone an opportunity to explore their own creativity through a variety of artistic projects and performance installations.


About Event Director/Choreographer, Ashlee Ramsey...

As a dance artist I am interested in the concepts of creative participation and co-creativity. I love to create dance-based performance art that offers audience members more than an opportunity to enjoy the artistry of someone else, but  also acknowledges audience member creativity, giving everyone present an opportunity to participate in a creative process. As the director of The Sideshow Saturdays Project I hope to broaden the term "creative" to refer not just to artists, but to all humans. Indeed, whether we realize it or not, as individuals and as a community, we make choices in our daily lives that play a part in creating the fabric of our living experience. It is my hope that audience members will come away from each Sideshow Saturdays event with a deeper appreciation of their own involvement in life not as a silent spectator but as an active and valuable participant. 


Why The Sideshow Saturdays Project Is Important...

The Sideshow Saturdays Project benefits local and regional artists, enriches Summer on Trade audience member experiences and strengthens the Winston-Salem community. Not only do involved artists receive a platform to share their work with potentially hundreds of audience members, but Sideshow Saturdays offers audience members a variety of sources for creative exploration and expression. Each event in the Sideshow Saturdays Project helps to foster an evening where audience members do not just arrive and enjoy the show, they have the choice to engage more deeply through participation or immersion. The Sideshow Saturdays Project exemplifies and progresses Winston Salem’s new slogan of “The City of Arts and Innovation” – it’s not just what we have here, it’s what we do. 


Where The Money Goes...

Supporting the Sideshow Saturdays Project means helping to create an event where community members receive an opportunity to encounter their inherent artistry and discover new outlets of creative expression, all the while building relationships with and learning from one another. Your donation will go towards the many expenses needed to make this project happen with success. Funding will be allocated towards the materials and supplies needed for each event, the cost of running the space for the evening, publicity and artist pay. Free to the public and focused on community inclusion, Sideshow Saturdays has very little outside income and we need your help!
Budget
Artist Pay:  $200/artist x 10 = $2000
Supplies/Materials:  $100/artist x 10 = $1000
Publicity (posters, postcards, flyers, website):  $400
Space Rental:  $50/night x 10 = $500
Total:  $3900


Our Creative Partners...

Imagination Installations - Imagination Installations, an organization dedicated to dreaming, will work with a group of dancers who engage audience members in activities that help them bring their dreams to life through movement. Using Imagination Installations’ process of gathering participant dream statements – sentences that start with “Imagine When...” and finish with dreams for the future – Ashlee Ramsey and fellow dancers will engage audience members in art and dance projects that move their “Imagine When...” statements beyond words. Imagine when all individuals feel free to explore their creativity through many mediums of expression!

Courtney Belle Branch and Ashlee Ramsey - Visual artist and film maker Courtney Branch along with dance artist Ashlee Ramsey are collaborating on an evening that offers audience members an interdisciplinary approach to creative investigation and co-creativity utilizing visual art, dance and film. Under the guidance of Courtney, participants have the opportunity to create smaller works of visual art that are then compiled into a larger mural. With direction from Ashlee, participants will engage in movement activities that translate their work of art into a short dance phrase. Just as the works of visual art are compiled into a group mural, these dance phrases will be filmed and channeled into a culminating video project that serves to both document the creative process and to weave together participants’ creative contribution. Using several mediums of artistic exploration, Courtney and Ashlee hope to offer participants multiple avenues for encountering and engaging in creative exploration and discovery. At the same time this event promotes connection and co-creativity, encouraging audience members to recognize how personal creative investment and local involvement contributes to a greater mural of relationships within a community.

Amy Love Beasley  - Amy Love Beasley is excited to present a dance/drawing performance piece performed by local dance artists Ashlee Ramsey and Brianna Taylor. The piece is based on breath, pairings, and is a combination of movement and mark making with charcoal on paper. The audience will be invited to participate as mark-makers in this piece as we create a visual record of our time together.

Emily Morgan - Choreographer, Winthrop University faculty member and Winston-Salem part-time resident Emily Morgan offers participants an opportunity to engage in creating a movement experience that builds into a community dance. Using a few simple choreographic tools and a movement donation from participants, Emily and dancers will foster an event where audience members come into contact with both the creative process of dance-making and their inherent, perhaps yet discovered, choreographic abilities!

Steve Clarke - Photographer and filmmaker Steve Clarke will present a performance installation that involves a dancer (Jessi Knight) interacting with video images over which she will have some degree of control.  The images may include projected shadows, mirroring with live camera feed, and archival video serving as the dancer’s only source of light.  In our society today, images are easily made and widely disseminated.  This piece will explore the split between who we are in images and who we are in reality, seeking to pierce the barrier between these two aspects of the person. 

Brianna Taylor - Dance artist Brianna Taylor, director of Greensboro based Confluence Performance Projects, will facilitate a performance installation experience utilizing movement, sound and saran wrap. Members of the also Greensboro-based experimental music/art ensemble Collapss will contribute a soundscape based on an improvisational score, constantly shifting in relation to participants’ choices. Audience members are invited to join dancers and musicians in movement, sound making, as well as saran wrapping the space/objects/each other, offering a visual and tactile representation of the interconnectedness of the human experience.

And that's not all... our group of creative partners is growing! Stay tuned to our updates to learn when we add new artists and events to our project. (Just a sneak peak at future possibilities... think Indian classical dance... and there is buzz about tarot card readings involving a special dance performance and the opportunity to create your own spirit card using a collage technique... burgeoning ideas are so exciting!) 


Thank You!!

Thank you so much for checking out our Indiegogo Campaign. Please do consider supporting this project, either through a monetary contribution or by coming to an event... we would love to see you there!

Thank you so much for checking out our Indiegogo Campaign. Please do consider supporting this project, either through a monetary contribution or by coming to an event... we would love to see you there!

story:
Who We Are

We are Mikaela Clark and Mackenzie Valley- dancers, choreographers, freedom-fighters.  Our journey, though not it's beginning, really took off in 2009 when we were struck with the reality of modern day slavery, specifically the global sex trade.  As artists, we felt compelled to do something: learn more about the issue and create dance about it. That was just the beginning. Since then, we created Without Words Movement.  Our mission:  reclaiming freedom through dance. 

We believe dance has a way of speaking to people- of passing the intellect and going straight to the heart and emotions.   Like many forms of art, it can challenge us, inspire us, touch us and even move us to look at the world differently.  This is why we create.  We strive to create high-quality dance performance, speaking on issues of social justice and the need for freedom in every human heart.  The other way we reclaim freedom through dance is to give others the opportunity to express themselves through dance.  Our work has taken us, outside of Cleveland OH to South East Asia, Romania and Italy. 

The Campaign

We have now been invited to Malawi, Africa to partner with Ancient Path.  There is a group of children in Malawi, who are not only getting food to eat and help to go to school, but the opportunity to grow through the arts.  These young children, many orphaned or at risk, come alive when they have an opportunity to dance, we are told.  It gives us great joy to share dance with these precious lives, hopefully leaving them with a sense of empowerment and greater freedom.  Not only that, but we truly believe this is an opportunity to see and hear from those who are otherwise  unseen.  These children represent the many children, all over the world who have no voice, yet they have something to say.  We want to go, listen and to come back to Cleveland better inspired and equipped to be a voice.  

The impact: 

1. Bring joy and empowerment to these children in Malawi, who deserve to live a life beyond just survival.  

2. Research the face of human trafficking in this region.

3.  Create new work upon returning to Cleveland.


Our goal is to raise: $8,500 

This covers all of our travel expenses: plane tickets, hotel, food, shots, etc.  It will also help cover any cost of living that we need while we are gone.

We also will be collecting fabric while we are there to create unique merchandise when we return. (Please see our ReClaim site for what we did returning from Europe).

By giving to this project, you are giving so much more than the cost of traveling. You are giving to freedom, to stories that need to be heard and to faces that need to be seen.  


It is sometimes difficult to measure the impact of the work that we do.  It's not always tangible.  However, we are encouraged at every performance by the audience feedback. There are often many tears, opened eyes and opened hearts.  We have seen the looks of joy on the faces of shy children in villages in Thailand.  We have witnessed crowds of people stop in metro stations to watch us dance. And with every opportunity to travel, we find ourselves growing as people and as artists.  Our own work is challenged and expanded.  Every experience has brought us to deeper places. See a glimpse from our trip in Romania.

Without Words Movement

Ancient Path


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation, that's okay!  You can still help:

Share this link on your Facebook page.

Email or call 3 of your friends and encourage them to support this campaign.
