story:
A Single Spark

In Seattle, a new dance company is forming with a contemporary and cutting-edge mixture of belly dance/ hip hop/ & ballet. FORGE DANCE THEATRE will focus on representing dance fusion in the thriving Seattle arts scene.  We are committed to unique presentations that engage and inspire audiences from all walks of life.

This fundraising campaign is designed to fund our start-up costs and the creation of an amazing production in February 2015,  entitled "Gazing West," in which we will debut our founding dance repertoire (6 pieces of choreography, each with a different stylization and intention). 

Please help us get started. Each contribution helps us get a little closer. Even a $5 gift is a huge help!  If you are unable to donate, please share. The more funders we have, the more likely it is that we will be featured on indiegogo. With your help, together we will make amazing dance art! Please know you have our deepest gratitude for your support. <3

Ring of Fire

A brief summary of our goals, both immediate and stretch:

Basic funding goals:

  • Rehearsal space fees: $420
  • Costuming for 4 choreographies: $1800
  • Theater rental & production costs for February show: $1500
  • Promotional materials (photography, flyers, posters, advertising): $500
  • Graphics/Logo design: $300
  • Merchandise printing (T-shirts, stickers, hoodies, etc): $500
  • Fees and taxes on this campaign (10-15%)

Stretch Goal 1: DANCER PAY!
Raising an additional $2500 would allow us to give our hard-working artists an honorarium for their work this season. 

Stretch Goal 2: Website
Raising an additional $750 would allow us to launch our website at www.forgedance.com

Stretch Goal 3: Guest artists! 
Raising an additional $2000 would allow us to bring two guest artists from California, in February, to work with us on our production. While in Seattle, we will sponsor these artists to teach community workshops also. 

Stretch Goal 4:  Dance Music Video!

Raising an additional  $1700 would allow us to fund one of our next projects, an online dance music video that would be permanently accessible via online access from our website - a lasting piece of work that our fans can enjoy anywhere, anytime! This project will require paying music licensing costs, renting equipment and studio space, and hiring a filmmaker.


Stretch Goal 5: Tour!
Any additional funds raised will be used to offset FORGE dancer travel costs for performances at dance festivals & productions nationwide- allowing us to bring FORGE to a town near you!!!

All funding for stretch goals will be applied in the order given above. Thank you for your contribution!

FORGing Community

Our fearless director, Kitiera, has been a dancer for 23 years and a choreographer/director for more than 15 years. Her leadership is strong and her commitment is total. FORGE will continue dancing toward our goals regardless of funding amounts, but each contribution will help us to move forward faster, and will better the production value of what we have to offer.

The Seattle arts community has a niche for us, and we're excited to give of ourselves to the "Emerald City" and to the world.  We believe in producing events that showcase local artists using many different disciplines. We are committed to bringing high-level guest dancer/choreographers to Seattle to enrich not only our own work, but that of countless other dance artists here in the NW. 

Each dancer in FORGE joined our force with a calling to better themselves and their art. Your support enables us to do so, without the worry of how  we are going to produce these projects with enough quality to be worthy of the intention. 

Smoldering Obstacles

Art is a difficult business. In a city as large as Seattle, there is always something to see and experience. Lacking the marketing and publicity resources of a larger arts company, getting the word out about a new project is an uphill battle. 

In spite of these circumstances, we believe that the unique nature of our group and our style make us special. We have a lot to offer this community, and obstacles will be met with determination and grit. None of our dancers are new to adversity. We know that staying focused and committed is the pathway to success.

    Shine the Light

    Can't afford to contribute? That's OK! Please help us by sharing this campaign. By sharing this campaign, you increase our visibility and network of support.  Please let your friends know what we're up to, and why it's important. Thank you in advance for your good wishes!


    Read & listen more about FORGE here:

    https://www.facebook.com/forgedancetheatre

    http://kitierapen.blogspot.com/2014/07/forge-inception.html

    http://suaspodcast.com/podcast/suas-006-kitiera/


    Photos by Chris Yetter: www.cjyphoto.com

story:
What We Need 

Musicians: The Kander and Ebb score requires depth! Currently, we only have a budget for 3 musicians. Ideally this score requires a band of 10. We are paying NYC's finest for their time and talent...to make this Bob Fosse classic razzle dazzle!

Costumes and Set: The show takes place in a  1920's Chicago jail.  With a cast of 25 of New York City's most talented young performers, we need extensive scenic materials to put them in their "Cell Blocks" to tango on the PPAS stage! 

The Impact

The PTA is very generous with helping with the majority of the cost of the show, but with a production of this magnitude, we need extra help. For the third year in a row, we're asking for additional support to be able to present a production that is up to NYC industry standards. Please make a tax deductible donation today!

Other Ways You Can Help

Help out by posting the link to this page anywhere you can (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr).

SPREAD the WORD.

story:
Who We Are

The Accidental Shakespeare Company is a classical theater company in Chicago. The Accidentals want to bring a high level of dramaturgy and acting skills to an affordable storefront theater space. We are raising money for our second main stage show, Macbeth. We are raising the funds to cover the production costs so that we can maintain a very affordable ticket price for all.

The Production

One of Shakespeare's greatest plays, Macbeth tells the story of the treacherous rise and bloody fall of the King of Scotland. Informed by a trio of witches that he is destined to become King, Macbeth and his wife go to greater and greater lengths to attain and to hold onto this goal.

The costumes, scenic elements, and aesthetic tone of this production will be informed by the 2002-era Bush administration White House. 2002 was a time in which even Bush's critics had not yet realized the lengths to which he would go, or the mess which he would leave behind. It was a time in which loyalty was paramount, and questioning authority was considered "unpatriotic". It was a time in which authority very badly needed to be questioned.

The Characters

Lord and Lady Macbeth (Andrew Mehegan and Sherry Legare) are the titular power couple, with her steel backbone keeping her less-grounded husband on track and his disconnection from reality driving them further into the darkness than she would have gone on her own.

Director Angeli Primlani specializes in examining theatrical works through the eyes of the "minor" characters who are thrust in the middle. For this production her point of view character is Ross (Rocco Renda), a minor nobleman in Duncan's court. Ross begins the play as a loyal friend to Macbeth, and a member of the inner circle, but ultimately his eyes are opened to his true nature.

Finances

We have already raised the funds for the performance space (the Side Project Theatre, at 1439 W. Jarvis) and we have finalized the (extremely talented!) cast. So there will definitely be a production of Macbeth in October! However, in order to bring this vision fully to the stage, we need your help. Specifically, there are four areas that need funding:

The Production Team

Accidental Shakespeare is fortunate enough to have some extremely talented artists on board for this production, but as excited as they are to work with us they still need to pay their rent.

This production is not just "Macbeth in modern dress", but rather "Macbeth, as influenced by a very specific time and place in American History", and for that we need someone who is equally creative and talented. We need someone who won't have to rely on the usual creepy makeup and spooky clothing, but will be able to produce the same chilling effect with business suits and enamel tie pins. Kate Kamphausen is a Jeff-Award-winning Chicago costume designer... and she's really great! 

One of the key elements of this production is that in the first two-thirds of the play although there is a great deal of violence, it is remote, removed, and sterile. It all comes home to roost by the end, however, and only a veteran choreographer can make the savage, brutal retribution that we need be safe for the actors and entertaining to the audience. The man for this job is H. Russ Brown, an SAFD Certified Teacher and Advanced Actor Combatant who is currently serving as Head of Performance and an Assistant Professor at Lon Morris College.


Set Construction

The second major area that needs funding is our set design. Although we plan to have a simple set for the most part, it must be absolutely sturdy. The safety of our actors is one of our greatest concerns, and for a physically active production like this one, it is vital that they feel secure. And we want H. Russ Brown to feel free to have our actors jump on tables and dive over chairs, which means that everything on stage must be firm and durable.

Publicity

Finally, we need money for publicity. We know how great the production will be, and you know that it's going to be fantastic, but the rest of Chicago is still ignorant! Posters, fliers, advertisements, and celebrity endorsements aren't cheap, but it no one knows about the show, they (literally!) won't know what they're missing.

Prices

We as a company are committed to low ticket costs, so that people who cannot afford the high ticket prices of many Chicago theaters will be able to come to our show. This means that we cannot count on paying for our productions via ticket sales alone!

If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help:

Share this campaign with your friends,- be sure to use Indiegogo's share tools.

Follow us on Twitter (@accshakes) and like us on Facebook 

Spread the word about Accidental Shakespeare Company and our upcoming production of Macbeth!

And last but not least come see our show: Side Project studio space, 1439 W. Jarvis, Chicago from October 18-November 2, 2014.

story:
Who We Are...


  • Not Too Tame: We are an ensemble company of actors who are firmly founded on the belief of ‘Theatre for All’. Focusing specifically in creating work that breaks the boundaries of tame, polite theatre, we aim to engage those who feel that theatre isn’t a place where they belong.

The company’s stated intention is to engage audiences who don’t feel they belong in “tame, polite theatre”, and they do this with great charm and energy"

The Telegraph


  •  As we are still an emerging company which is yet to receive any annual funding, we are living 'hand to mouth' and project to project. Your generous contributions are vital to us at this stage, to get the work on it's feet and out to venues in towns, villages and cities near you. Without you, there is no NTT shows and consequently we can't share these 'everyman' stories and voices. 
"If it doesn't mean anything to our community, what's the point in doing it?" Pete Postlethwaite

  • Getting to Edinburgh with 2 shows this year is a huge deal to us. We're hoping that after this outing at the International Fringe, we can really start to make waves and stand up to be counted amongst the UK's theatre scene and beyond! In order to achieve this, we first have to get up to Edinburgh - for that...we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

  • Edinburgh this year is costing us over £20,000 - Our accommodation alone costs £5,000 + £1000 deposit and we are paying all of our actors (and there are 8 of them). You can quickly see how things start to add up! We are asking you guys to help us reach £3,500 towards our accommodation. Keeping a roof over our heads will at least keep us safe, warm and dry :) 
  • We have a series of great perks that you will receive in return for helping us reach our goals, including free theatre tickets, free gig tickets, VIP meet and greets, personalised thanks and even personalised video thank you responses.
  • WARNING: if we don't end up reaching our full total goal....we're really down the creek without a paddle! 

The Impact
  • You guys helped us achieve £5,000 in 2014 and we went up to Edinburgh and won a 'sell out' award and 4/5* reviews in National Press. We couldn't have done that without your help. We smashed that together! Because of that we were able to book a UK and Ireland tour in 2015 - In 2016 we hope to entertain sell out audiences again and get back out on the road to meet so many of our new friends and audiences face to face and bring a 2nd instalment of cracking entertainment to a venue near you! 
  • Without your help, well...well it doesn't bare thinking about to be honest. At the moment, we can only survive with the help and support of generous benefactors and friends. Please, give whatever you can - the price of a pint, a meal out or whatever you can. Anything you can would mean the world to us.  

  • Not Too Tame; Together!
  • As a company we have learnt so much in 2 years and spoken to so many of our audiences face to face. We've played in umpteen pubs, met hundreds of new friends and listened to thousands of stories and comments - but what this means is we've learnt. We are coming back bigger, better and bolder. We want you to always be a a part of NTT. We want you to celebrate our success and come with us on our journey. We are a family of actors who I can safely say put a huge amount of graft and heart into what we do. We know how hard you guys work for your money, so we really appreciate what you can give to hep us create and produce this work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can give we'll bloody love you to bits! Even if you can't, and we understand some people just can't - you can still help and you can share this with your friends and family and then we'll still love you to bits!!! (We'll love you either way....but shhhh...don't tell anyone :) ....)



Big Thanks to Slydigs for belting soundtrack. 

www.slydigs.co.uk 

@slydigsband 



And Conduit Productions and Orlando James for supplying the video and my double chin :)

In order to achieve this, we first have to get up to Edinburgh - for that...we need your help!

   What We Need & What You Get 
Edinburgh this year is costing us over £20,000 - Our accommodation alone costs £5,000 + £1000 deposit and we are paying all of our actors (and there are 8 of them). You can quickly see how things start to add up! We are asking you guys to help us reach £3,500 towards our accommodation. Keeping a roof over our heads will at least keep us safe, warm and dry :)  We have a series of great perks that you will receive in return for helping us reach our goals, including free theatre tickets, free gig tickets, VIP meet and greets, personalised thanks and even personalised video thank you responses. WARNING: if we don't end up reaching our full total goal....we're really down the creek without a paddle! 


The Impact
 
You guys helped us achieve £5,000 in 2014 and we went up to Edinburgh and won a 'sell out' award and 4/5* reviews in National Press. We couldn't have done that without your help. We smashed that together! Because of that we were able to book a UK and Ireland tour in 2015 - In 2016 we hope to entertain sell out audiences again and get back out on the road to meet so many of our new friends and audiences face to face and bring a 2nd instalment of cracking entertainment to a venue near you! 
Without your help, well...well it doesn't bare thinking about to be honest. At the moment, we can only survive with the help and support of generous benefactors and friends. Please, give whatever you can - the price of a pint, a meal out or whatever you can. Anything you can would mean the world to us.  


Not Too Tame; Together!
  As a company we have learnt so much in 2 years and spoken to so many of our audiences face to face. We've played in umpteen pubs, met hundreds of new friends and listened to thousands of stories and comments - but what this means is we've learnt. We are coming back bigger, better and bolder. We want you to always be a a part of NTT. We want you to celebrate our success and come with us on our journey. We are a family of actors who I can safely say put a huge amount of graft and heart into what we do. We know how hard you guys work for your money, so we really appreciate what you can give to hep us create and produce this work.    Other Ways You Can Help If you can give we'll bloody love you to bits! Even if you can't, and we understand some people just can't - you can still help and you can share this with your friends and family and then we'll still love you to bits!!! (We'll love you either way....but shhhh...don't tell anyone :) ....)


Big Thanks to Slydigs for belting soundtrack. 
www.slydigs.co.uk 
@slydigsband 


And Conduit Productions and Orlando James for supplying the video and my double chin :)

story:
Help--I'm poor.

Wuz ha'nin hoes?! It's your local neighborhood De De T and this year I'll be recording and producing my very first comedy album, We're All Gonna Die, on 9/30/2018 in New Orleans. In stand-up any comic worth her weight in pens and notebooks knows that even the best bits have to be laid to rest in order to transition to the next phase of creative growth. While I may have an unhealthy attachment to the material I composed in my comedic infancy, they're old now. This album represents a body of work that's been over 5 years in the making and it's time for these bits to die already. For the sake of closure (and diva-like dramatic display) I'm going to formally eulogize these jokes that I once loved in the most dignified way possible--with a dumb, concept-driven comedy special.

Hey De De, why this macabre funeral business?

My sense of humor has always been pretty dark and irreverent (much to the embarrassment of my parents). It was how I dealt with my fear, anger, insecurity, vulnerability and general discomfort in social settings. Even as a kid, somehow I knew that the only appropriate outlet for it was stand-up comedy. Turns out I was right. 

The subject matter of this album (death, depression, gun violence, racism, etc.) is not intended for shock value (or to embarrass my folks). My brashness is but a vehicle to make people laugh at some of the things that scare us most in an effort to empower us to face them. 

On a more personal note, even though comedy writing is more than mere free therapy to me, I can't help but notice how liberating it feels to drag my fears out in the open and make fun of them. At the moment what I'm most afraid of is this album. My fear is that if I get rid of this material that I'm really proud of (and took a LONG time to stitch together), I won't be able to duplicate it's singularity with the next 30/45/60 minutes I write. I'm afraid that by putting myself out there, I'll find out the hard way that what I thought was a really good set kinda sucks. I'm afraid that this will be a failure and I will have wasted all my efforts of over half a decade. Hell, I'm afraid that it'll be successful and then people will push me in to the spotlight when I am MUCH more comfortable in the shadows. All these fears are exactly why I'm compelled to take my chances.

*List of Demands*

My primary expense is that of production. I have to pay my sound engineer, videographer and editor for their work and that will cost $400

An equally important expense is that of paying the comics who have been gracious enough to perform on my show. My main gripe in stand-up comedy has always been that it is SO hard to get compensated for the work one puts in to the craft, and I would be remiss if I didn't pay my peers who have agreed to bring their talents to my project. They deserve way more than I can offer but I do want to give them something. Their total compensation will be $400.

I have to get asses in the seats so that will require promotional funding for photos, graphic design and ad boosting on various social media platforms in the amount of $165

And, of course, there is the final expense of digital audio distribution at $35.

BRIBES. DELICIOUS BRIBES.

If you donate $10 you get 2 tickets* to the show (if local) AND access to an advanced free digital download of the album.

If you donate $25-49 you get everything in the $10 pkg AND reserved seating at the show (if local), and a personalized, signed copy of the It's Funny Because It's Inevitable funeral program that includes photos from the album shoot, the line-up, an obituary and more.

If you donate $50-99 you get the $25 pkg AND a digital copy of the filmed performance with bonus features not included on the digital album.

If you donate $100-199 you get the $50 pkg AND you get named as an honorary pallbearer in the program, a special thank you on the album and in the film credits.

If you donate $200+ you get the $100 pkg (except you're an official pallbearer) AND you get executive producer credit on the album and in the film credits 

*Seating is limited of course, so when I run out of seats I can no longer offer tickets with the perks.

What if you fail?

If I'm not able to amass the necessary funds by the intended recording date of 9/30/18 then everything will be pushed back until I can. That includes the performance, album release date and distribution of certain backer incentives but this show will ABSOLUTELY go on and all the incentives will be fulfilled.

I know we got this though. So no worries, love. *wink*

"Sis, I'd sit up witcha but I'm sick myself..."

If you want to help me get this figurative homegoing ceremony popping, but you don't have the funds to do so, nobody understands that more than ol De De T. You can still do me a HUGE favor by sharing this on your IG, Twitter, Facebook, Google+, whatever. I'm grateful for any support you choose to give. Thank you!

story:
Who We Are

Elysium Conservatory Theatre (a 501 c(3) non-profit organization) grows fearless artistic expression within our community of emerging artists, company membership and resident teaching artists - all invested in each other's success.

ECT breeds artists with heart, who hunger to explore, to rehearse, to journey into the creative unknown and follow that lighting bolt of inspiration - whenever it strikes.

We believe art is about getting there vs. starting there. About falling in love with discovery, and nurturing the bravery of curiosity within the crafting of story and character. We seek playgrounds of wonder and exploration, and opportunities to ADVENTURE into artistic unknowns.

And to roar into it...Fearlessly.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your generous contribution will help "Raise The Curtain" on ECT's Spring mainstage productions of ALIK + RICHARD III - opening this March!

The Goal: $1000 + that will empower each production with the resources to bring our artistic vision to life with:

+ COSTUMING 

+ LIGHTING 

+ SET 

ECT is giving supporters of our production a STAR or SHOOTING STAR credit - each with it's own perks and levels of recognition.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
About the Show

[title of show] is a musical within a musical that follows Hunter and Jeff along with their friends Susan and Heidi, on a journey of creative self-expression. Over the span of 90 minutes the struggling artists write and perform their festival show, depicting the lessons they learn about themselves as people, friends, and artists.

This full scale production acts as the senior project for Co-producers Kevin Hoover, and Abby Toll

 

CAST: 

Hunter: Aman Millions-Roman       

Jeff: Marty Power

Heidi: Andrea Rose Cardoni

Susan: Abby Wolanin

 

PRODUCTION TEAM: 

Director: Felicia Batten

Music Director: Josh Goldhaber

Lighting Designer: Jordan Petrellis 

Costume Designer: Cindi Landmesser 

Sound Design: Tanner Richardett

Scenic Designer: Kevin Hoover 

Producers: Kevin Hoover & Abby Toll

How your donation helps

Your donations will help us afford our venue and equipment rentals, as well as the materials necessary to build our production, and pay our team. As part of our senior project we saw this project, not only as an opportunity to produce a fully realized piece showcasing our own abilities, but as an opportunity to offer our director and designers a platform to present their talents on a professional stage. The Drake Theatre is a professional venue, which plays host to a variety of local Philadelphia theatre companies. While we could have performed this show at one of the venues on Drexel’s campus, we felt that a center city venue, like the Drake, gave our team the best opportunity to show the Philadelphia theatre community their skills in each of their respective departments.

story:
Short Summary

 

David Neumann and Marcella Murray are multi-disciplinary theatre artists who came together to engage in a conversation about race that went beyond their previous experiences with conversations about race. A leap of faith for both, they’ve worked hard over the past year and a half to find a theatrical form for their conversation, and they hope you find this approach inspiring. 

Distances Smaller Than This Are Not Confirmed  started with a 3-year-long ongoing conversation between David and Marcella about race. And life. And race. Three years later, and the conversation has evolved into a full-fledged theatre piece that visits different scales of experience and understanding, from intimate to microscopic to astronomical. Space, Time, and personal experience are all discussed on the set of a TV talk show where race isn’t quite avoidable, live on-air. Like everyone else, the people involved don’t know the answers even as they begin the work. Mistakes and conflict are expected. Self-care, laughter, dancing, and common trust are, too.

Marcella, David, and the rest of Advanced Beginner Group are reaching out to ask for support to help them complete their journey. They’ve been invited to three tech residencies between now and their premiere at Abrons Arts Center in January 2020: one at Mabou Mines, the second at MASS MoCA, and the third at Abrons Arts Center.  They are asking for funding to help pay for the artists’ fees, to rent the necessary equipment and otherwise support the overall design of this work as the separate elements are assembled. 

We’re very excited about the potential of this piece and are committed to raising the necessary funds to make these residency opportunities as effective as possible. Your contribution is extremely important as it will allow us to take these next steps with a group of amazingly talented artists who are passionate about this work, this conversation, and committed to creating a theatre piece that is timely, challenging, and deeply considered. 


 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We need to raise at least $12,000 by the middle of October.

 

Basically, the funds raised will go DIRECTLY toward paying for our esteemed collaborators’ time and effort as they design and construct video, costumes, lighting, sound, set and props, not to mention renting video equipment and lights, procuring costume pieces, and constructing various parts of the set. 

 

We’re not asking for exorbitant designs or construction, all we really need are some basic things like better video cameras, a few costume changes, a table that has its own personality, and time. Time with our collaborators so they can sink into the intricacies this kind of conversation asks for. 



 

And you will get any number of exciting thank you gifts in return!

Some of these include: 

-tickets to opening night

-a playlist of some of the sound and some of the music created by Tei Blow and Stew

-tickets AND a backstage tour to Hadestown on Broadway

-Our deepest gratitude

-Invites to our opening night party 

-and more….


 

 

The Impact

Making theater from scratch is a daunting enterprise and a big challenge to manifest these days. Rehearsals are costly and finding the time, space, people and equipment to build the work can be an uphill battle. We’re an industrious and hope-filled group of artists here at Advanced Beginner Group with a long history of determined and creative navigation of problems.

 

We believe that making work that lives in the present is a crucial part of the larger cultural conversation. We’re committed to sharing our ideas, images, passion and process with you.

 

We’re thrilled to be doing this exciting and challenging work with such wonderful collaborators as: Tei Blow (lead collaborator and sound designer), Hyung Seok Jeon (video designer and performer), Chris Green (set and props designer), Melanie George (dramaturg), Julius Powell (performer), Montana Blanco (costume designer), Marika Kent (lighting designer), Stew (original music), Janet Clancy (production manager), Boo Froebel (producer), and Amanda Brandes (administrative director).

 

We’re reaching out to you, our audience, our community of fellow artists, friends, art lovers, theatre nerds, dance enthusiasts, star-gazers, culture vultures, hipsters, hippies, cranky pants, people who came here by accident, intelligentsia, multi-dimensional travelers, the resistant and rebellious, the unlabelled...TO ALLLLL OF Y’ALL, in hopes that you will support this work. 

 

This work is our attempt to speak honestly with one another in the face of division, fear, and hatred. We’re committed to doing the work towards being better able to look one another in the eye. We’re committed to caring for one another in a way that is radically outside of performative kindness. We’re not the answer. We don’t know the answer, but we’re committed to the complicated pursuit of something better and more just than what we have.

We’re a small drop in the bigger bucket, but we’re working to make this drop count.

 

If you can, please donate. Help us towards making it count. If you can’t contribute money, we hope you’ll come to the show in January and join the conversation! And whether you do any of those things or not, we hope you’ll share this fundraising campaign with your community! If you ever have trouble finding this link, you can search for Advanced Beginner Group on Facebook and Instagram. The link will be posted there, as well. You can also find us online at www.advancedbeginnergroup.org

We're so grateful for your consideration. Thank you!

 

Distances Smaller Than This Are Not confirmed
co-created by David Neumann and Marcella Murray
premieres January 16-25, 2020 at Abrons Arts Center

co-commissioned and co-presented by Abrons Arts Center and the Chocolate Factory Theater
produced by Advanced Beginner Group
associate produced by Mabou Mines
and with enormous thanks to each and every one of our donors!

story:
Freaks With Lines - We are back and we are growing!

After the successful film release Trilogy of Relations, The Freaks are back and ready to present their next project: Nilus Cogus. 

Nilus Cogus  is a contemporary piece featuring seven dancers that elucidates how we humans are cogs within a machine, which is itself being manipulated by some greater and unfathomable circumstance. Dancers become cogs who adhere to various systems, which ultimately modify and control their behavior. Despite whether they believe it or not, are aware or unaware they are all simply pawns of this unknowable phenomenon. Nilus Cogus is set to premiere in late May 2021. 

The cerebral and mechanical mood in Nilus Cogus plays on the underlying voyeurism Freaks With Lines often employs in their work.  Automated and impassive movements succinctly executed by professionally trained ballet dancers awaits audiences. Unique costuming designed by professional ballerina Tiffany Smith of Supuhrdesigns denotes the sterility and uniformity of humans as cogs. Since film is quickly becoming the new medium for dance, "Getting the geometric shapes crisp and clear was very important," states Smith, "I think they will have a really bold impact on camera, especially in black and white. " 

To add to the depth of our storytelling, the lighting in Nilus Cogus is critical as it is essentially a character the dancers endearingly refer to as  simply "Nilus." "Nilus" represents the power structures we enter into, often without consent and without complete understanding. Dancers interact with "Nilus" on stage where "Nilus" is represented by a structure of lights created specifically for such interaction. Additionally, a definitive lighting schematic designed by our very own Eric Friedlander and Sadie Black and programmed by John Pennington adds to the dystopic and mechanical mood of the piece.

Backers receive a free ticket to view Nilus Cogus, which premieres on BalletProject.TV, a new digital platform that streams dance performances.
story_txt: Freaks With Lines - We are back and we are growing!After the successful film release Trilogy of Relations, The Freaks are back and ready to present their next project: Nilus Cogus. Nilus Cogus  is a contemporary piece featuring seven dancers that elucidates how we humans are cogs within a machine, which is itself being manipulated by some greater and unfathomable circumstance. Dancers become cogs who adhere to various systems, which ultimately modify and control their behavior. Despite whether they believe it or not, are aware or unaware they are all simply pawns of this unknowable phenomenon. Nilus Cogus is set to premiere in late May 2021. The cerebral and mechanical mood in Nilus Cogus plays on the underlying voyeurism Freaks With Lines often employs in their work.  Automated and impassive movements succinctly executed by professionally trained ballet dancers awaits audiences. Unique costuming designed by professional ballerina Tiffany Smith of Supuhrdesigns denotes the sterility and uniformity of humans as cogs. Since film is quickly becoming the new medium for dance, "Getting the geometric shapes crisp and clear was very important," states Smith, "I think they will have a really bold impact on camera, especially in black and white. " To add to the depth of our storytelling, the lighting in Nilus Cogus is critical as it is essentially a character the dancers endearingly refer to as  simply "Nilus." "Nilus" represents the power structures we enter into, often without consent and without complete understanding. Dancers interact with "Nilus" on stage where "Nilus" is represented by a structure of lights created specifically for such interaction. Additionally, a definitive lighting schematic designed by our very own Eric Friedlander and Sadie Black and programmed by John Pennington adds to the dystopic and mechanical mood of the piece.Backers receive a free ticket to view Nilus Cogus, which premieres on BalletProject.TV, a new digital platform that streams dance performances.

story:
Dia dhuit/Halito/Hi, 

Colm Summers and LeAnne Howe here, we are a Choctaw-Irish writing and directing team. Together, we have written a new play, The Keening about the 174 year relationship between LeAnne's people, the Choctaw Nation, and Colm's folks in Co. Cork, Republic of Ireland. 

What is the Keening?

174 years ago, the Choctaw sent a $170 gift to the Irish in the worst year of the Great Famine, known as Black '47, beginning a generations long reciprocity. The story of the Choctaw gift at the height of the Irish Famine has touched the imaginations of people around the world. Our play, The Keening, travels time and space to tell the story of how the Choctaws saved themselves from annihilation by saving the Irish from starvation. 

But how does it feel?

The Keening is a high-octane musical along the trail of American history, featuring traditional Irish and Choctaw music, dance and poetry, created in an Irish-Choctaw collaboration which itself commemorates the reciprocity shared by our ancestors. In The Keening we use the story of Andrew Jackson, an Irish immigrant who as President instigated the Trail of Tears, as a critical frame for our exploration of the reciprocal relationship between our two great cultures. 

Why now?

In an increasingly atomized era of isolation and factionalism, our play is a call not only for intercultural generosity, but more nuanced cultural histories, which invites its audience to celebrate the gifts we can give each other if we imagine that we are all kindred spirits. 

Our goal: In the next 2-5 years, The Keening will tour transatlantically bringing our story to Irish and American audiences.  To get there, we are asking you to contribute to the play's development, specifically this August at Irish Arts Centre in New York, where we will be developing the play! That means taking the play from one draft, to another, with actors, live and in-person! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need a minimum of $1200. That money goes to pay performers, book hotels for collaborators, cover travel costs, and pay administrative fees. 
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, payment of performers will be our priority! If you can help us exceed our goal, extra funds will go directly towards the next installment of The Keening's development. 
  • What you get: full credit as the funders of this new self-produced work at the development stage, a huge thank you from us,  and a full report from the rehearsal room! You become part of our ensemble through your contribution, and part of the legacy of gift-giving which is central to Irish-Choctaw history! 

Other Ways You Can Help

As artists ourselves we appreciate that financial giving isn't always easy. Here's other ways you can help us!

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our crowdfunding campaign. Share our campaign materials on Facebook, Instagram and with interested friends and family!
